Education | School of Special Education, School Psychology and Early Childhood Studies
Education | School of Teaching and Learning
Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures

matcher_questions.question: Which broad area of study interests you?
Select a specific department of interest (if applicable)
What course level are you looking for?
What type of course content do you want?
How many credit hours are you looking for?
What is your preferred time commitment?

courses.title: Retail Management Seminar
courses.description: Weekly lectures feature a different executive making a presentation in their area of expertise. Addresses major issues in retailing. Discussions of retailing career opportunities and career paths.

courses.title: Sales Seminar
courses.description: Overview of selling and managing the sales function to achieve the growth targets of a business; highlights the importance of the sales function in a firm and how it contributes to the achievement of the firm’s strategic objectives.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Projects related to business in marketing as approved by the college.

courses.title: Principles of Marketing
courses.description: Functions, institutions and methods of marketing goods and services. Relates marketing to the larger economic structure and emphasizes the importance of the consumer.

courses.title: Introduction to Retailing Systems and Management
courses.description: Functions, institutions and activities of retailing goods and services.

courses.title: Professional Selling
courses.description: Basic survey in professional selling. Teaches the importance of the selling role and provides basic professional selling skills; begins the preparation for a future role in sales or sales management.

courses.title: Consumer Behavior
courses.description: Emphasizes both descriptive and conceptual analysis of consumer behavior with a focus on theory and research essential to an understanding of individual choice behavior. Makes intensive use of contributions from the social and behavioral science literatures.

courses.title: International Marketing
courses.description: Analyzes economic, social and cultural issues affecting marketing management in the international environment.

courses.title: Retail Consulting
courses.description: Provides opportunities for working on real retail/marketing problems with clients; gain practical insights into actual retail business operations while performing problem identification, exploration for opportunities, data collection and strategy development. Teams of 4-5 students work with real clients on retail issues and design and execute all phases of the project.

courses.title: Sales Management
courses.description: Principles, methods, and problems relating to the management of a sales force. Selection and training, organization, compensation and stimulation, and control.

courses.title: Marketing Research
courses.description: Analyzes the role of marketing research in providing information for marketing decisions. Research methods and techniques involved in the development and use of primary and secondary data are emphasized. Topics include survey design, experimental design, data collection (e.g., questionnaires), data analysis, measurement and sampling.

courses.title: Marketing Management
courses.description: Development and analysis of overall marketing strategies involving product and brand development, channels of distribution, pricing, and promotion with consideration of marketplace conditions and related factors affecting implementation and execution.

courses.title: Marketing Strategy
courses.description: Emphasizes analysis, planning, and implementation of marketing strategies. Examines insights into the creative processes involved in applying marketing concepts and knowledge to the development and implementation of strategy. Features a comprehensive marketing simulation exercise and well as detailed analysis of several companies and their marketing strategies.

courses.title: New Product Development and Management
courses.description: A structured way of thinking about product development. Students are provided with an up-to-date toolbox for developing and managing new products. Includes hands-on individual assignments and a group project to simulate the development process of a new product or service.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.description: Opportunity for in-depth study not offered in other courses.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Selected rotating topics in marketing management, research and theory.

courses.title: Sales Internship
courses.description: Teaches the importance of the sales function in a firm and how the sales function contributes to the achievement of the firm’s strategic objectives. Using participative on-the-job learning methods, gain an overview of the sales function in a firm and gain a sense of the reality of business situations, which aids success in virtually any sales-oriented career assignment.

courses.title: Retail Management Internship
courses.description: A 10-12 week entry-level retail management internship that requires several papers and reports. Opportunities are available in stores, corporate headquarters and buying offices. Management training experiences in buying, store management, merchandising and customer service.

courses.title: International Studies in Marketing
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.description: A thesis is required for magna cum laude or summa cum laude designation. To qualify, students normally have completed 90 semester credits of coursework (exceptions may be made) and have at least a 3.6 GPA at the time they enroll. The thesis will be reviewed by at least one faculty member chosen by the honors coordinator from the student's department.

courses.title: Gaming War & Peace in the United States and South Africa
courses.description: Uses role-playing games to investigate conflict and its resolution by simulating the revolutionary chaos in New York (1775–76) and constitutional negotiations for post-apartheid South Africa (1993). Examines the role of the arts in remembering conflict, focusing on monuments.

courses.title: Net Art
courses.description: Explores practical and theoretical issues related to the Internet as a medium for making art rather than as a tool for delivering information. Emphasizes the creation of dynamic and interactive experiences on the web that integrate video, graphics, animation, sound, image, and typography.

courses.title: Advanced Experiments in Art and Technology
courses.description: Special topics course that explores new forms of digital media production. Topics reflect emerging forms of digital media.

courses.title: Graphic Design History II
courses.description: Investigates the diverse cultural functions and critical definitions of graphic design across places and times in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Introduces broad stylistic movements common to western Europe and North America; interrogates and re-writes a received definition of graphic design which excludes globally diverse artifacts, designers, practices, and users.

courses.title: Compassion and the Arts
courses.description: Students will explore the historical, theoretical, and cultural roots of compassion – or how people respond through empathetic action. Works of art, music, performing arts, literature, philosophy, religion, and history will help students critically reflect on the role of compassion within the human experience including quality of life and citizenship.

courses.title: Introduction to the Arts in Medicine in a Global Context
courses.description: Explores the field of arts in medicine in a global context, focusing on the many ways that the arts can be used to enhance health and wellbeing in healthcare or community settings and the relationship of culture to healing practices, systems, and health literacy in various regions of the world.

courses.title: Special Topics in Fine Arts
courses.description: Variable topics course exploring the interaction between various arts and between the arts and other disciplines.

courses.title: Visual Arts in Medicine
courses.description: Explore the intersections of the visual arts and health and investigate how the visual arts can support health and well-being. Acquire fundamental research and communication skills for scholarly discussion of arts in health as well as practical application.

courses.title: Music and Health
courses.description: Review music therapy and music in health research to assess, orally and in scholarly writing, how music can be utilized to enhance well-being, the intersections between music and psychology/cognition/human behavior, as well as health maintenance issues and medical challenges of performing artists.

courses.title: Applied Theater for Health II: Collective Creation Lab
courses.description: Apply knowledge acquired in Applied Theater for Health I to create an original project or workshop on a chosen health topic. Collaborate to research, develop, and conduct theater for health workshops in partnership with a community or campus organization.

courses.title: Arts in Medicine Practicum 1
courses.description: Provides basic to intermediate-level mentored practice in the arts in healthcare in a clinical or community environment. Emphasizes a primary discipline while deepening the understanding of the practice through documentation  self-assessment  and a culminating paper.

courses.title: Music in Medicine Capstone
courses.description: Culminating course in the Music in Medicine certificate. Conduct a thorough literature review and develop a capstone proposal and project related to the intersections of music and health in healthcare or community settings to assess, orally and in scholarly writing, and how music can be utilized to enhance wellbeing.

courses.title: Fine Arts Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Provides an opportunity for firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or creative application, depending on the topic. Projects are supervised by an advising faculty member or a grad student working under faculty supervision.

courses.title: Special Topics in Fine Arts
courses.description: An upper division general fine arts special/rotating topics on various subjects in the arts.

courses.title: Overseas Studies in Fine and Performing Arts
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study-abroad program can be recorded on the transcript and counted toward UF graduation.

courses.title: Programming for Artists
courses.description: Introduces understanding interactivity as an art form, providing an in-depth exploration of the tools, theories and applications of interactive media as they are used for creative inquiry, research and production.

courses.title: Introduction to Financial Accounting
courses.description: Conceptual introduction to financial accounting. Emphasis is placed on wealth and income measurement and the preparation and interpretation of conventional financial statements.

courses.title: Introduction to Managerial Accounting
courses.description: Accounting for cost reporting and control. Reports, statements and analytical tools used by management.

courses.title: Exploring Careers in Accounting
courses.description: Introductory overview of accounting as a field of study and the career opportunities available within accounting, in sectors such as public accounting, professional and financial services, industry, government, entrepreneurship, and other.

courses.title: Financial Accounting and Reporting 1
courses.description: Covers the theoretical structure of financial accounting, required financial statements, revenue recognition, operating assets and current liabilities.

courses.title: Business Processes and Accounting Information System
courses.description: Examination of the accounting information systems in a business organization. Coverage extends over topics such as business processes, internal controls, and the fundamentals of accounting information systems analysis, design, implementation and control.

courses.title: Professional Speakers Series
courses.description: To expose students to technical topics and emerging issues in accounting, business and related professions such as law. The course addresses career opportunities in the practice of public accounting, industry, financial services, government, and in business more generally.

courses.title: Financial Accounting and Reporting 2
courses.description: Continuation of ACG 3101 and includes coverage of accounting for investments, non-current liabilities and equities, accounting for income taxes, derivatives, accounting changes, statement of cash flows and earnings per share.

courses.title: Cost and Managerial Accounting
courses.description: Extends cost and managerial coverage beyond that covered in ACG 2071. Topics include quantitative cost estimation, standard costing, flexible budgets, inventory management, pricing decisions, balanced scorecard, costs of quality, capital budgeting, transfer pricing and performance evaluations.

courses.title: Introduction to Auditing
courses.description: Introduces the basic concepts, principles and environment of financial statement auditing. The course emphasizes the audit decision-making process, researching audit standards, audit planning, evidence evaluation, audit reports, ethics and legal liability.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Opportunity for in-depth study of topics not offered in other courses and of topics of special current significance.

courses.title: Supervised Accounting Internship
courses.description: Applied work in professional accounting. Requires several papers and reports.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.description: The thesis must be submitted to the Fisher School no later than the published deadline and includes an abstract.

courses.title: Introduction to Federal Income Tax
courses.description: Introduces federal income taxation to those who pursue careers in accounting; develops a basic understanding of the federal income tax laws relating to businesses and provides a framework for integrating income tax planning into the business decision-making process.

courses.title: Special Topics in Taxation
courses.description: Course provides an opportunity for in-depth study of topics not offered in other courses and of topics of special current significance.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Variable subjects provide content for the study of agricultural topics not offered in other courses.

courses.title: The Meat we Eat
courses.description: Consumer-oriented elective covering meat as a food, its inspection for wholesomeness, meat grading, identification, processing, selection, preparation, and serving. Emphasizes preparation of economical, nutritious, and palatable meals centered on meat.

courses.title: The Role of Animals in Human History
courses.description: Surveys the importance of animals through human history from the Stone Age to the present. The domestication of dogs, cats, major farm animals, as well as some less familiar, such as camels, reindeer, and buffalo, and the role they played in different societies and cultures across human history.

courses.title: Survey of Veterinary Professions
courses.description: Introduces careers in the veterinary medicine profession with discussions related to career exploration, career preparation, and the procedure of job placement.

courses.title: Introduction to livestock and meat evaluation
courses.description: Basic elements of live animal evaluation, selection and carcass evaluation.

courses.title: Careers in Animal Sciences
courses.description: Interactive exposure to employment opportunities in the animal sciences.

courses.title: Introduction to Animal Science
courses.description: Role of beef cattle, dairy cattle, swine, sheep, poultry, and horses in serving humans. Introduces anatomy and physiology of digestion, growth, reproduction, and the application of genetics to livestock improvement.

courses.title: Introduction to Animal Science Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory experiences designed to accompany ANS 3006; must be registered for ANS 3006 concurrently or have already completed the lecture course.

courses.title: Domestic Animal Behavior and Welfare
courses.description: Introduces basic principles and applications of animal behavior, including approaches to improve animal welfare through an understanding of animal behavior. Examples are drawn from a wide range of species, but the focus is on applying concepts to understand the behavior and welfare of domestic animals under human care, including livestock, companion, and laboratory species.

courses.title: Growth and Development of Farm Animals
courses.description: An integration of the physiological, genetic, and nutritional bases of animal growth, development, and body composition with application to livestock production.

courses.title: Introduction to Equine Science
courses.description: For those with an interest in equine sciences but with limited equine experience. Principles of equine selection, care, and utilization.

courses.title: Equine Health Management
courses.description: Principles and practices for planning, implementing, and maintaining equine herd health.

courses.title: Techniques in Equine Science
courses.description: Introduces the knowledge, horseback, and management skills required for proper daily horse care and conditioning. Designed for those seeking employment requiring basic horse care skills and for novice horse owners.

courses.title: Beef Production Practicum
courses.description: Participate in beef cattle production systems under close supervision of faculty and staff; gain knowledge of best management practices regarding cattle handling, tractor, and equipment use, as well as cattle hauling by participating in experiential learning opportunities.

courses.title: Dairy Cattle Practicum
courses.description: Practical application of the principles of biology and management of dairy cattle. Topics include milking procedures, behavior, cattle handling, records, and computer applications in dairy production; body condition, lameness and hygiene scoring; dairy farm evaluation; on-farm practica and field trips.

courses.title: Biology and Management of Dairy Cattle
courses.description: Biology of dairy cattle and the interrelationship between biology and management. Topics include anatomy and physiology, nutrition, reproduction, genetics, behavior, diseases, dairy products, housing, management, economics, and the environmental impact of dairy production.

courses.title: Reproductive Physiology and Endocrinology in Domestic Animals
courses.description: Principles of reproduction in avian and mammalian farm animals including factors related to the estrous cycle, pregnancy, lactation, semen-production, artificial insemination, pregnancy diagnosis, and environmental factors affecting reproduction.

courses.title: Genetics of Domestic Animals
courses.description: Basic principles of Mendelian, population, and quantitative genetics as applied to improvement of domestic animals. Selection, inbreeding, and crossbreeding strategies for genetic improvement of livestock.

courses.title: Food Animal Nutrition and Feeding
courses.description: Studies the basic nutrient requirements of food animals, primarily beef cattle and swine, at specific stages of growth, production, and reproduction; and how scientific methods and experimentation are applied to animal nutrition.

courses.title: Equine Nutrition and Feeding Management
courses.description: The influence of growth, reproduction, and work on the nutrient requirements of horses and the application of that information to the planning of life cycle feeding programs.

courses.title: Principles of Animal Nutrition
courses.description: The nutrients required by animals, their functions interrelationships, and processes of utilization; feedstuff composition and their use in diet and ration formulation.

courses.title: Chicken Growth and Development
courses.description: Practical application of the principles of animal growth and development. Uses the chicken as a model to examine how a particular factor such as genetics, sex, nutrition, and more affect growth and development. Also explores broader implications for animals, producers, and consumers.

courses.title: Value determination of meat animals
courses.description: Principles and procedures involved in evaluation, grading, and economic value determination of meat animals and the carcasses they produce.

courses.title: Meats
courses.description: Integrated studies of the science and technology involved in the utilization of meat animals for food with focus on animal growth, carcass cutability, wholesomeness, palatability, and merchandising of red meat.

courses.title: Practicum: Weanling Behavior Modification
courses.description: This practicum examines equine behavioral modification methods that emphasize a balanced approach for developing an adaptable, responsive young weanling horse using reasonable, achievable training methods.

courses.title: Relationship of Form to Function in Horses
courses.description: Principles of conformation and performance evaluation of horses. Studies the anatomy, physiology, and dynamics of the horse as it affects athletic potential and performance.

courses.title: Techniques in Farrier Science
courses.description: How to evaluate and to trim the horse's hoof and to develop a working knowledge of corrective farrier techniques.

courses.title: Horse Psychology and Training
courses.description: Horse behavior, instinct and senses as they relate to training. Principles of training the young foal; ground work, liberty training, and starting the young yearling under saddle; and principles of performance training.

courses.title: Practicum in Horse Management and Training Technique
courses.description: Practicum in horse management and training technique

courses.title: Horse Enterprise Management
courses.description: Management principles essential to the planning and operation of commercial horse enterprises.

courses.title: Discovery of Sustainable Cattle Systems
courses.description: Multidisciplinary experiential learning focused on development of sustainable practices through comprehension and critique of cattle production systems. Encompasses multiple aspects related to cattle systems, including agronomy, human and animal health and nutrition, sociology, and soil science. A key element is the hands-on learning experience where students select a project to carry out on one of the UF/IFAS beef or dairy units.

courses.title: Intermediate Horse Training
courses.description: Continue the training of a recently started under-saddled horse, exhibit horse to potential buyers, and produce annual performance horse sale.

courses.title: Beef Cow-Calf Management
courses.description: Development and implementation of management programs for commercial cow-calf and purebred beef cattle enterprises.

courses.title: Beef Background and Feedlot Management
courses.description: Management, marketing, and utilization of beef cattle after weaning. Spring break field trip required.

courses.title: Equine Reproductive Management
courses.description: Equine reproduction to include anatomy, the estrous cycle, hormones and pharmacologic manipulation, gametogenesis, embryonic and fetal development, parturition, foal care, assisted technologies, and management strategies.

courses.title: Applied Livestock Reproduction
courses.description: Provides unique experiences in applied reproductive techniques and management of livestock with rotation through numerous animal teaching units reinforcing classroom curriculum in beef, dairy, equine, small ruminants, and porcine reproduction. Topics include estrus detection, synchronization, management, artificial insemination, ultrasonography, assisted reproductive technologies, semen collection and evaluation, sperm freezing, and embryo handling.

courses.title: Equine Genetics
courses.description: Examines the underlying mechanisms and inheritance of a number of traits in the horse; includes the impact of domestication on the genome, relationships between breeds, coat color, genetic disease and complex traits of performance and behavior.

courses.title: Genetic analyses of complex traits in livestock
courses.description: Comprehensive examination of principles of livestock inheritance, QTL mapping strategies and functional genomic approaches used for genomic selection and improvement programs in farm animals.

courses.title: Canine and Feline Genetics
courses.description: Lectures, seminars, and lab exercises on application of genetic principles to canine and feline characteristics provide an in-depth understanding of how these traits are inherited and analyzed. Information on new genomic technologies and their impact on studying specific traits, including coat color and genetic disorders, are discussed.

courses.title: Molecular Techniques in Domestic Animal Genetics
courses.description: Studies the principles of basic domestic animal molecular biology techniques and provides hands-on experience through laboratory exercises.

courses.title: Animal and Products Evaluation
courses.description: Intensive training in animal and animal products evaluation.

courses.title: Pork Production
courses.description: Principles of modern pork production, including all aspects of swine production management systems (breeding systems, disease control, applied economics, housing, marketing, pork quality, and nutrition in a systems approach), relative to the US/Global pork supply.

courses.title: Meat Processing
courses.description: Basic principles of the use of muscle as food, process technology, meat inspection, regulations, quality control procedures, and marketing aspects.

courses.title: Physiology of the Mammary Gland and Lactation
courses.description: Insight into the endocrinology and physiology of the defining characteristics of mammals: the mammary gland and lactation, focusing on the anatomy and development of the mammary gland with an overview of the biochemical, cellular and molecular processes controlling lactation emphasizing on livestock species.

courses.title: Supervised Extension Experience in Animal Sciences
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in animal sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.title: Problems in Animal Science
courses.description: Qualified students are assigned a problem involving care and management of livestock or the investigation of a current topic in animal science.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Animal Sciences
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in animal sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Animal Sciences
courses.description: Independent research in animal sciences leading to an honors thesis, mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application. (S-U)

courses.title: Senior Seminar
courses.description: Oral presentation and papers on issues facing the livestock industry.

courses.title: Special Topics in Animal Sciences
courses.description: Special topics in Animal Sciences.

courses.title: Full-Time Practical Work Experience in Animal Science
courses.description: Credit is earned on the basis of one hour per month of employment.

courses.title: Companion Animal Biology and Management
courses.description: Principles and practices of proper selection, care, nutrition, genetics, reproduction, and training of companion animals, with emphasis on dogs, cats, and selected bird species.

courses.title: Livestock Health/Disease Prevention
courses.description: The principal diseases of livestock and practical methods for their prevention and control.

courses.title: Arabic Literary Heritage 1
courses.description: Surveys classical Arabic literature in translation. Covers pre-Islamic poetry and early Islamic poetry, Omayyad, Abbasid and Andalusian literatures. All readings are in English.

courses.title: Arabic Culture
courses.description: Introduction to Arabic culture with special reference to art, literature, religion, and society. Emphasizes Arab contributions to philosophy, medicine, mathematics, and architecture. All readings in English.

courses.title: The Qur'an as Literature
courses.description: Approaches the Qur'an from a literary standpoint by examining its history, structure, style, major themes, and impact on Arabic literature, Islamic thought, and Muslim culture.

courses.title: Beginning Arabic 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Arabic 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Arabic 1
courses.description: Continuation of the study of standard Arabic language. Develops reading, writing, listening and speaking skills and helps with comprehension of written and audio texts. Students can use their knowledge of the Arabic language to clearly express their personal views in a meaningful and well-structured language.

courses.title: Intermediate Arabic 2
courses.description: Continues the study of Arabic language at the intermediate level. Emphasizes developing reading comprehension, writing, listening and speaking, and vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Spoken Arabic
courses.description: Develops listening and conversational skills at an intermediate level of proficiency. Focuses on a middle variety of Arabic known as Educated Spoken Arabic that enables successful communication with educated Arab speakers from virtually any country in the Arab world.

courses.title: Advanced Arabic 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Arabic 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study.

courses.title: The Arab Woman
courses.description: Examines the role and status of Arab women in their respective societies; specifically examines the internal dynamic of Arab culture that influences the role of the Arab woman.

courses.title: Fourth Year Arabic 1
courses.description: Development to an advanced level of speaking, hearing, reading and writing of spoken and mass communication and literary Arabic.

courses.title: Fourth Year Arabic 2
courses.description: Continuation of ARA 4400. Development of a more advanced level of speaking, hearing, reading and writing of spoken and mass communication and literary Arabic.

courses.title: Arabic through the Texts
courses.description: For advanced students of Arabic. Teaches the more complex grammar, idiomatic expressions and sophisticated stylistic forms of the language. Required for the Arabic minor.

courses.title: Arabic Sociolinguistics
courses.description: Focus on the relationship between language and society in the Arab world. An examination of the different varieties of Arabic and the relation between linguistic variation and other social variables, such as ethnicity, religion, urbanization, social class, gender, power and ideology.

courses.title: Structure of Standard Arabic
courses.description: Describes and analyzes the sound system, word structure, and sentence structure of Arabic.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: One of the core courses in the Middle Eastern languages and cultures major offered through interdisciplinary studies. Also useful for linguistics, religion, Arabic, Hebrew, and Jewish studies.

courses.title: Overseas Studies 1
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Architecture and Humanity
courses.description: Introduces the issues and opportunities derived through actively engaging the sustainable and ethical design of the environments in which people live: urban, landscape, and architectural.

courses.title: Introduction to Architecture
courses.description: An introduction to the principles of architectural design. The course includes project-based exercises, lectures, and discussions.

courses.title: Places and Spaces
courses.description: Examines the way humankind has shaped its world while framing particular relationships with nature and asks: what does it mean to make a mark upon the land? What does it mean to dwell, and what do the inhabited places mean to people?

courses.title: Architectural Design 1
courses.description: Introduces interfacing communication skills with design thinking. Emphasizes awareness and understanding of basic organization ideas in design.

courses.title: Architectural Design 2
courses.description: An analysis course that uses the study of architectural precedent as a foundation for the development of communication and design skills.

courses.title: Architectural History 1
courses.description: General survey of social, political, and cultural factors that have generated art and architecture. (H and N) (WR)

courses.title: Architectural History 2
courses.description: A survey of the history of architecture from 1400 to 1850. Lectures examine the effects of social, political, material, technological and cultural forces on the design and construction of the built environment and explore the role of the architect in civil society. Emphasizes the theoretical positions of the architects and architectural schools. (H and N)

courses.title: Survey of Architecture History
courses.description: A survey of monumental buildings and their embodied architectural intentions from the pre-historical ages to the current age. Demonstrating interactive relationships between form and idea in architecture throughout history across cultural and regional differences. (H and N) (WR)

courses.title: Introduction to Digital Architecture
courses.description: Introduces computer-aided design programs currently utilized by professional practices.

courses.title: Theory of Architecture 1
courses.description: Critical study of the processes that influence the form and image of architecture with an emphasis on an understanding of ordering principles and concepts of how space and architecture systems are interrelated. (H)

courses.title: Architectural Design 3
courses.description: Studio course explores the influence of history and culture on design decision-making.

courses.title: Architectural Design 4
courses.description: Explores context as a generator of architectural design ideas. Contemporary cultural influences also are examined and incorporated in the design process.

courses.title: Materials and Methods of Construction 1
courses.description: The nature of materials used in construction. Criteria for evaluation and selection related to design decision-making.

courses.title: Intro to Building Technologies
courses.description: First course in a sequence that addresses the relationship between building technologies and design thinking by introducing fundamental concepts of materials and methods relative to building design and construction. Also offers digital design modules that develop problem-solving and representational skills.

courses.title: Integrated Building Tech 1
courses.description: As the second course in a multi-year integrated building technology sequence, there will be an emphasis on further developing components of materials and methods, digital design and on the introduction of environmental design that will increase the student’s understanding of the impact of context and building technologies on design decisions.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Digital Architecture
courses.description: Continued investigation of computer-aided design programs currently utilized by professional practices.

courses.title: Special Studies in Architecture
courses.description: Special studies in architecture adjusted to individual needs of undergraduate students.

courses.title: Architectural Design 5
courses.description: Investigates architectural design and its relationship to regional contextual influences through a range of projects which vary in scale and complexity.

courses.title: Architectural Design 6
courses.description: Architectural design within a large scale urban context. Theory, methodology and evolution of urban form in response to social, cultural, economic and technological forces.

courses.title: Materials and Methods of Construction 2
courses.description: Methods of assembling and selecting materials; detailed systems of construction are investigated.

courses.title: Integrated Building Tech 2
courses.description: As the third course in a multi-year integrated building technology sequence, there will be an emphasis on further developing components of environmental design, materials and methods, and building structures, in addition to a digital design module that will concurrently develop student abilities to problem solve and represent ideas.

courses.title: Integrated Building Tech 3
courses.description: As the fourth course in a multi-year integrated building technology sequence, there will be an emphasis on further developing components of environmental design, materials and methods, and digital design skills that will allow students to apply their knowledge to mid-rise buildings of increasing complexity.

courses.title: Introduction to Architectural Structures
courses.description: A foundation course that investigates principles of structural behavior in withstanding gravity and lateral forces; consider structural layout, load distribution and preliminary design techniques; and examines contemporary structural systems through case studies emphasizing trussed, framed, funicular and shell structural systems.

courses.title: Environmental Technology 1
courses.description: Principles and practices relating to control of the thermal/atmospheric environment and to plumbing in buildings.

courses.title: Architectural History 3
courses.description: A survey of the history of architecture from 1850 to present. Lectures examine the effects of social, political, material, technological and cultural forces on the design and construction of the built environment and explore the role of the architect in civil society. Emphasizes the theoretical positions of the architects and architectural schools.

courses.title: Sustainable Architecture
courses.description: How environmentalism informs architectural discourses and how discourses on the built environment and urbanism impact environmentalism globally.

courses.title: Core Studio 1
courses.description: Introduces a variety of design techniques, including design theory, three-dimensional development, and spatial relationships.

courses.title: Core Studio 2
courses.description: Continuation of core studio sequence with increased emphasis on manipulation of architectural elements.

courses.title: Core Studio 3
courses.description: Continuation of core studio sequence with studio projects related to program development, structural integration, energy analysis and introduction to mechanical integration systems.

courses.title: Core Studio 4
courses.description: Continuation of core studio sequence with increased emphasis on complex building types.

courses.title: Architectural Theory 2
courses.description: Investigates the theoretical, historical and ideological ideas in architecture that took place during the early decades of the twentieth century.

courses.title: Building Information Modeling
courses.description: Emerging technology in building information modeling (BIM) in the context of architectural design development and documentation. Theoretical and technological evolution of different typologies of software with hands-on experience designing and modeling with BIM software.

courses.title: Architectural Design 7
courses.description: Emphasizes the notion of control over architectural design processes needed to arrive at solutions that respond to needs through appropriate use of program development and construction technology. Course emphasizes the complete building as a final product and focuses on the urban and suburban housing project.

courses.title: Architectural Design 8
courses.description: Architecture designs focus on architectural detail and articulation. An investigation of landscape provides the context for this study.

courses.title: Integrated Building Tech 4
courses.description: Emphasizes the development of structures, materials, and methods, and environmental design skills that apply to high-rise, long-span, and large-scale building design. Provides focus to both the technical knowledge of macro-scale design-drivers and the detail implications of structure, environmental performance, and building assemblies.

courses.title: Structural Modeling
courses.description: Introduces the fundamentals of structural modeling including building information modeling (BIM), digital design, and approximate systems analysis and detailing for architectural structures. Students will learn how to efficiently implement building information modeling to organize, coordinate and communicate information to convey data necessary for structural systems.

courses.title: Environmental Technology 2
courses.description: Fundamentals of architectural lighting, acoustics, electrical power distribution and building communications.

courses.title: LEED for Sustainable Design and Construction
courses.description: Campus projects demonstrate design and construction of high performance buildings and application of green building technologies. Economics and market development associated with the application of green building rating systems, with a focus on LEED. Successful completion helps prepare for LEED V4 Green Associate exam credentials.

courses.title: Vernacular Architecture and Sustainability
courses.description: Investigates vernacular architecture in the discourse of architectural sustainability with an emphasis on the way that vernacular architecture has been constructed, represented and consumed in the environmental histories of architecture.

courses.title: Special Topics Seminar in Architecture
courses.description: Miscellaneous topics in architecture and related fields.

courses.title: Architectural Education
courses.description: Provides an awareness of curriculum development, project preparation, program/project presentation, constructive criticism and evaluation techniques.

courses.title: Vicenza Institute of Architecture: Italian Language and Culture
courses.description: Taught through the Vicenza Institute of Architecture, located in Vicenza, Italy. It is intended for architecture students participating in the VIA program. The course establishes a basic level of competency in Italian language and culture as it relates to the architectural goals of the VIA program.

courses.title: Vicenza Institute of Architecture: Architectural Design Studio
courses.description: Architectural design examining the regional contextual relationships found in northern Italy as well as central and southern Europe. Design exercises focus on the immediate relationships of European urban space, ideas of building program and the potential development of architectural details and material systems.

courses.title: Vicenza Institute of Architecture: Analytical Sketching
courses.description: Introduces sketching as an analytical skill in understanding constructed space within the context of Italy's Veneto region as well as central and southern Europe.

courses.title: The Tales of King Arthur
courses.description: The great literary works of the Arthurian tradition and the manner in which the tales of King Arthur serve, from their 6th century Celtic origins to the present, to articulate the interests and values of different social groups throughout history. (H and N)

courses.title: Introduction to the Medieval World
courses.description: Chronological and topical introduction to history of the medieval millennium (400-1400).

courses.title: Castles and Cloisters: An Introduction to Medieval Communities
courses.description: Studies monastic and courtly-chivalric communities as these evolved in the Middle Ages. Explores architecture, art, literature, and music illustrate how different monastic and chivalric communities saw the world and their place in it.

courses.title: Palaces and Cities: An Introduction to Early Modern Communities
courses.description: Explores the new kind of European culture that emerges with early modern residential palaces and cities. The study of seminal texts in poetry, politics and theology, and of early modern cities and palaces shows the new operant principle in cultural processes to be the primacy of the individual. (H)

courses.title: Engineering the European Middle Ages
courses.description: Explores technological innovations in the cultural domains of power generation, agriculture, sacred spaces, warfare, and textiles. Analyzes their interactions with belief- and value systems that shaped the European Middle Ages.

courses.title: Studies in the Holy Roman Empire
courses.description: Variable content examines the political and religious ideas and the literary and artistic productions associated with significant stages in the history of the Holy Roman Empire.

courses.title: Variable Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Studies
courses.description: Provides intermediate study in medieval and early modern studies.

courses.title: Independent Study in Medieval and Early Modern Studies
courses.description: Independent work in medieval and early modern studies.

courses.title: Special Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Studies
courses.description: Advanced study in medieval and early modern studies.

courses.title: Survey of American Literature
courses.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of American literature. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H) (WR)

courses.title: Issues in American Literature and Culture
courses.description: Introduces some of the most important issues that arise in the study of American literature and culture. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of the topic. (C or H) (WR)

courses.title: American Literatures 2
courses.description: Selected texts from 1865 to the present, in diverse historical and cultural contexts, usually organized around a theme or several themes.

courses.title: Surveys in American Women's Literatures
courses.description: Surveys traditions in American women's writings, covering a wide range of texts or focusing on a single theme, genre, period, literary movement, or cultural tradition. Topics may include women's writings about feminism, family, work, nationalism, or social justice; women's autobiography, poetry, experimental prose, or domestic fiction; 19-century literature by women, contemporary women's poetry or colonial women's writing; realist, postmodern, or sentimental fiction by American women; African American, New England, Native American, Southern, or working-class writing; Chicano, Latina, or lesbian literary traditions. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Variable Surveys of American Literatures
courses.description: The rich cultural traditions found in American literature. Topics may include gay and lesbian, Jewish American, Chicano/a, Latino/a, Native American, Southern, and other literatures. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: African American Literature 1
courses.description: Surveys the development of African American literature from its beginning to 1945.

courses.title: African American Literature 2
courses.description: Surveys the development of African American Literature from 1945 to the present.

courses.title: Asian American Studies
courses.description: Variable topics or survey focus on the major issues, movements or themes in the study of Asian American literature and culture from the beginnings to the present. Topics may include Kung Fu films, cultural nationalism and feminism, model minorities, Angel Island literature, Asian Americans in film and media, and several major authors.

courses.title: Studies in American Literary Forms
courses.description: Study of genre, such as the novel, detective novel, political novel, historical novel, utopian fiction, or Western; drama; short story; sermon traditions; African American cultural forms, African American folklore; long poem, lyric, philosophical poem, oral poetry; nature writing, autobiography, captivity narrative; narratives of exploration; political oratory; postmodernism; coming-out stories; humor. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Studies in American Literature and Culture Before 1800
courses.description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the major issues, movements, forms, or themes in the study of American literature and culture before 1800. Topics may include narratives of exploration and encounter, Puritan and/or Enlightenment writings, captivity and slave narratives, traditions of spiritual autobiography, post-colonial approaches to colonial rhetoric and poetry, and/or in-depth studies of selected writers. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Studies in Nineteenth-Century American Literature and Culture
courses.description: Variable topics focus on the major issues, movements, forms or themes in the study of American literature and culture before 1900. Topics may include the American Renaissance, literature and abolition, African American novels and poetry, romance and romanticism, race and sexuality, the rise of the short story, realism, naturalism, representations of the city, representations of the South, tropes such as the Noble Savage or the American Girl, and/or in-depth studies of selected writers. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Studies in Twentieth-Century American Literature and Culture
courses.description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the major issues, movements, forms or themes in the study of 20th-century American literature and culture. Topics may include Modernism, Post-Modernism, the Harlem Renaissance, Depression-era literature, American writers in Paris, consumer society, American fiction since 1945, poetry, Civil Rights literature, rhetorics of imperialism, and/or several major authors. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Studies of Genders and Sexualities in American Literature and Culture
courses.description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the major issues, movements, forms, or themes in the study of American literature and culture. Topics may include masculinity and femininity in literature, lesbian possibilities in popular culture, feminism and womanism, traditions of gay self-representation. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Major Figures of American Literature and Culture
courses.description: In-depth focus on one major author, such as Dickinson, Twain, Faulkner, Hurston, or Morrison. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Studies in American Literature and Culture
courses.description: Variable topics examine issues, movements, forms, or themes that cross traditional period boundaries. Topics may include the city and the country in American fiction, Southern masculinity, reading and literacy in America, representations of class and religion in American literature, the body and technology, American regionalisms, the Pragmatist tradition, and nature and eco-criticism in American letters. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Race and Ethnicity
courses.description: Variable topics examine issues, movements, forms, or themes related to race and ethnicity in American literature. Topics may include Pacific Rim cultures in America, Chicano-Latino literature, the Black Arts Movement, constructing Native America, border-crossing and migration, post-war Jewish fiction, literature and the psychology of prejudice, comparative representations of racial and ethnic experience, representing whiteness, literatures of assimilation and multi-racial identities. Refer to the department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Beginning Fiction Writing
courses.description: Beginning writing fiction workshop which starts with the basics. Read a lot of fiction (authors can't be a fiction writer without reading shelves of fiction) and write stories to be discussed.

courses.title: Beginning Poetry Writing
courses.description: Workshop that concentrates on the basics of reading and writing poetry (writers must read, and readers must be critics). Write poems and discuss some in workshop.

courses.title: Fiction Writing
courses.description: Continues instruction in basic techniques of voice, plot and character, while introducing advanced ones. Students read a lot of good stories and write a few themselves. Samuel Johnson said, "No man but a blockhead ever wrote, except for money." Juniors or seniors who have not taken CRW 1101 or CRW 1301 must have strong composition skills. (C) (WR)

courses.title: Poetry Writing
courses.description: Writing poetry may become an addiction. This workshop continues with matter-of-fact techniques and some fancy ones as well. Students write poems and read some difficult and thrilling poetry of the past and present. By the end, students may be able to say, with Humpty Dumpty, I can explain all the poems that ever were invented - and a good many that haven't been invented just yet. Juniors or seniors who have not taken CRW 1101 or CRW 1301 must have strong composition skills. (C) (WR)

courses.title: Advanced Seminar in Fiction Writing
courses.description: Small workshop for students who have made their way out of beginner's workshops with sanity intact. Now the work gets more difficult, more deranged and more delightful. Emerson said, "People do not deserve to have good writing, they are so pleased with bad." Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

courses.title: Advanced Seminar in Poetry Writing
courses.description: More reeling and writhing," as Lewis Carroll said. An intense workshop for a small group of poets who have stared at the Pacific with a wild surmise. Like Balboa - or was it Cortez? Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

courses.title: Creative Nonfiction
courses.description: Creative writing workshop which introduces genres of creative nonfiction (e.g. memoir, personal essay, travel writing) and provides training in those genres. Appropriate for, but not limited to, English majors.

courses.title: Senior Advanced Workshop in Fiction Writing
courses.description: For students who want to trouble the literary editors and readers of the future. Many members of this class have gone on to graduate school in writing. Ants eat everything that is written, said an explorer. This is a workshop for ants. Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

courses.title: Senior Advanced Workshop in Poetry Writing
courses.description: George I said, "I hate all Boets and Bainters." For battle-scarred veterans of previous workshops who now want the full treatment, this is a small workshop for serious poets who want to write their names in water, as long as they are also in the Norton Anthology. Students often go from this class into MFA programs in poetry. Admission by manuscript review during advanced registration (refer to department website); by prerequisite during drop/add.

courses.title: Multimodal Writing and Digital Literacy
courses.description: Teaches digital literacy and digital creativity. Compose and convey creative, well-researched, carefully crafted information through digital platforms and multimodal documents. Also promotes digital writing and research as central to academic, civic, and personal expression.

courses.title: Topics for Composition
courses.description: Instruction in expository-argumentative writing related to one special topic selected by the instructor. Readings include variable genres from different disciplines. (C or H) (WR)

courses.title: Technical Writing
courses.description: Surveys the forms and methods of communication used in business, industry and government, including informal and formal reports, letters, resumes, and proposals.

courses.title: Professional Communication
courses.description: Professional writing course relevant in business, industry, government and other institutional settings. Covers major elements of organizational communication with emphasis on composition of letters and memos, reports, proposals and manuals. (WR)

courses.title: Advanced Exposition
courses.description: Advanced composition course in methods of exposition: definition, classification, comparison and contrast, analysis, illustration and identification. (WR)

courses.title: Advanced Argumentative Writing
courses.description: Advanced composition concerned with the writing of argument and critical analysis. (WR)

courses.title: Environmental Nonfiction
courses.description: A survey of compositional forms and techniques for communicating information about the environment and environmental change. Focuses on the art and practice of literary storytelling as a communication strategy to prompt greater understanding of environmental transformation and to catalyze ecological awareness and civic engagement.

courses.title: Hypermedia
courses.description: The study and production of digital media with emphasis on the World Wide Web.

courses.title: Professional Editing
courses.description: How to perform different levels of editing on a range of professional texts, including both printed and online texts as well as both technical and literary ones.

courses.title: Advanced Professional Writing
courses.description: Administrative communication, professional papers, research reports, proposals and other major professional documents, depending on the needs of the students who must have developed communication skills. (WR)

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Writing through Media
courses.description: This media studies equivalent of ENC 1102 explores the practices of literacy in the context of popular culture, including cinema, television, advertising, popular fiction, and journalism.

courses.title: Introduction to Popular Film
courses.description: For non-majors seeking humanities credit in the areas of film and popular culture. Introduces the study of contemporary movies through attention to film form and structure, film genres, and attention to popular culture. Requires viewing new movies off campus.

courses.title: Film Analysis
courses.description: Introduces thinking and writing about the cinema by means of film theory and history. (C or H) (WR)

courses.title: What is the English Major?
courses.description: Introduces the English major at UF and to career tracks for which the major is useful.

courses.title: English: College Honors 1
courses.description: Writing about novels, short stories, film, and cultural studies primarily by American and British authors. Text and assignments match the abilities of honor students.

courses.title: The Theory and Practice of Modern Criticism
courses.description: Intensive introductory study of 20th-century criticism theory.

courses.title: The Theorists
courses.description: Studies one or more theorists, contemporary or historical.

courses.title: Advanced Grammar: Analysis and Application
courses.description: An extensive and sophisticated study of grammar, as well as a practical appreciation of its rhetorical purposes.

courses.title: The Movies as Narrative Art
courses.description: Examines movies as a mode of storytelling by emphasizing the difference between verbal and visual narration, and relation to contemporary thought and values.

courses.title: Introduction to Film: Criticism and Theory
courses.description: Introduces the principal theoretical and critical issues raised by the first century of the cinema.

courses.title: History of Film, Part 1
courses.description: History of film from its beginnings to the introduction of sound.

courses.title: History of Film, Part 2
courses.description: History of film from the introduction of sound to 1960.

courses.title: History of Film, Part 3
courses.description: History of film from 1960 to the present.

courses.title: CINEMA OF ENVIRONMENTAL CRISIS
courses.description: Surveys global cinema of environmental crisis with a focus on historical and contemporary experimental, fiction, and nonfiction films’ representations of human responses to environmental change. In addition to the three hours of weekly lectures, requires attendance at a weekly film screening (up to three hours).

courses.title: Psychological Approaches to Literature
courses.description: Use of various psychological concepts to the application of literary study. Refer to department website.

courses.title: Race and Ethnicity in Film
courses.description: Critical and historical study of films and videos by and about people of color in the Americas, Africa, Australia, and Europe.

courses.title: Film Studies
courses.description: Variable topics provide in-depth study of film genres, notable film directors, and other significant topics on subjects related to film.

courses.title: Women and Film
courses.description: Studies the roles and function of women in mainstream and alternative cinema, including study of feminist film criticism and theories of gender.

courses.title: National Cinemas
courses.description: Variable topics study of the films of historically important national cinemas, such as American, French, German, Italian, Russian, Japanese.

courses.title: Film and Video Production
courses.description: Seminar on the independent and experimental uses of small-format film and video production.

courses.title: Television and Electronic Culture
courses.description: Explores the development of new modes of thought, forms of art, popular culture, and social practices based on the electronic technology of video and computers.

courses.title: Advanced Film and Video Production
courses.description: Variable topics focus on one or more advanced aspects of film and video production, including such topics as editing of film and video or the production of 16mm films.

courses.title: Film Genres, Directors, and Periods
courses.description: Variable topics on film genres (e.g. documentary, the musical, melodrama, film noir), film directors, or periods in cinematic history.

courses.title: Queer Theory
courses.description: Overview of major concerns, methodologies, and texts in queer theory, illuminating the theoretical insights, assumptions, and implications of various constructions of gender, sex, and sexuality.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.description: For advanced students who desire to supplement the regular courses by independent reading or research under guidance.

courses.title: Topics in Collaborative Research
courses.description: Provides supervised research in English in a group context, with emphasis on collaborative learning using variable content and methods.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in English
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in English. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in English.

courses.title: Honors Seminar
courses.description: Open to English majors who have maintained an overall junior/senior level GPA of 3.5. Small seminar classes study topics in English and American literature or film.

courses.title: English Internship
courses.description: Admission requires a written proposal of appropriate work experience from the student and a written acceptance for employment from the employer, including designation of a supervisor. Successful completion requires a written summation of the work experience from the student and a written evaluation of performance by the supervisor.

courses.title: Department Seminar
courses.description: Seminar offered on a space-available basis allowing department majors to develop their individual programs of study while focusing on a common topic.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Project
courses.description: Student selects an English faculty member to act as director for an independent research project that culminates in preparation of an honors thesis. An abstract and one copy of the thesis must be delivered to 101 Academic Advising Center by the semester deadline specified by the Honors Office.

courses.title: Survey of English Literature: Medieval to 1750
courses.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H) (WR)

courses.title: Survey of English Literature: 1750 to the Present
courses.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H) (WR)

courses.title: Introduction to Shakespeare
courses.description: Introduces the pleasure and wisdom of Shakespeare's plays. Various approaches are used: movie versions of the plays, staging of scenes from the plays and discussion.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Variable topics focus on major issues and themes in British literature and culture.

courses.title: The British Novel: 18th Century
courses.description: Covers a wide range of eighteenth-century British novelists, from Aphra Behn, Daniel Defoe, and Samuel Richardson to Henry Fielding, Frances Burney, and Jane Austen. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of each course; refer to department website.

courses.title: The British Novel: 19th Century
courses.description: Includes works by such novelists as Austen, Dickens, Gaskell, Brontë, Eliot, Hardy. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of each course; refer to department website.

courses.title: The English Novel: 20th Century
courses.description: Includes works by such writers as Conrad, Lawrence, Joyce, Forster, Woolf, Greene, and Waugh.

courses.title: Twentieth-Century British Poetry
courses.description: General study of the most prominent British poets of the 20th Century with particular emphasis on Yeats, Lawrence, Graves, Eliot, Sitwell, Dylan Thomas, and Ted Hughes.

courses.title: Medieval English Literature
courses.description: Surveys representative works of the Middle English period such as Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Pearl, Malory's Morte D'Arthur, and selections from medieval drama, lyric poetry, mystical writings, and writings by and about women.

courses.title: The Age of Dryden and Pope
courses.description: Selections from the best works of such writers as Dryden, Congreve, Addison, Swift, and Pope.

courses.title: The Long Eighteenth Century: Themes and Interpretation
courses.description: Rotating topics courses on eighteenth-century British literature, with an emphasis on themes rather than genres. These include but are not limited to literature's engagement with social issues, material history, and the history of ideas. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this course; refer to department website.

courses.title: The Long Eighteenth Century: Imaginative Genres
courses.description: Rotating topics courses on eighteenth-century British literature, focusing on imaginative genres; especially genres other than the novel, such as drama, poetry, and non-novelistic prose fiction. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this course; refer to department website.

courses.title: The Romantic Period
courses.description: The Romantic Period

courses.title: Victorian Literature
courses.description: Selections from Tennyson, Browning, C. Bronte, Wilde, G.M. Hopkins, and Arnold. Examines the beliefs and paradoxes of Victorian culture through the poetry, fiction, drama, visual arts, and critical theory of representative figures. Investigates the social and cultural assumptions which underlie the artists' approaches to their themes as well as the themes themselves. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Age of Johnson
courses.description: Age of Johnson

courses.title: Renaissance Literature: 16th Century
courses.description: Variable topics in Tudor literature and culture, 1485-1603. Focuses on or combine topics such as the development of literary genres; the works of single or paired authors; the social institutions and material conditions of textual production; thematically organized studies of cultural relations between literary and nonliterary texts; issues of gender, religion, nationhood and race; and writing in the emergence of an English literature. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Renaissance Literature: 17th Century
courses.description: Variable topics in Stuart Literature and Culture, 1603-1700. Focuses on or combine topics such as the progress of literary genres; the works of single or paired authors; the social institutions and material conditions of textual production; thematically organized studies of cultural relations between literary and nonliterary texts; issues of gender, religion, nationhood and race; and writing in the era before, during and after the English Revolution. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Twentieth Century British Literature
courses.description: Variable topics on major works of drama, poetry or prose from twentieth-century Britain. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Major Figures of British Literature and Culture
courses.description: In-depth focus on one or two major cultural figures, such as Marlowe, Austen, Scott, Eliot, Dickens, Yeats, Smith, Ishiguro, Kureishi, etc.

courses.title: Chaucer
courses.description: Reading and critical study of Chaucer's poetry with emphasis on the Canterbury Tales and Troilus and Criseyde, in addition to some attention to the minor works.

courses.title: Shakespeare
courses.description: Studies selections from Shakespeare. Topics include tracing Shakespeare's dramatic career, concentrating on one or several genres including histories, comedies, tragedies, and romances; developing the history of Shakespeare reception; approaching Shakespeare through performance, including acting and directing; and approaching Shakespeare through feminist, materialist, or psychoanalytic methods.

courses.title: Introduction to Morphology
courses.description: Theory of word structure, derivation and inflection, with examples and problems from a variety of languages. Includes the position of morphology in grammar, the relationship between morphology and grammar, typology, cultural and conceptual categories, and predictions of various theories of morphology. May be taught in conjunction with a graduate course that bears the same title.

courses.title: Introduction to Literature
courses.description: In this course, students will be assigned readings representative of a broad range of literary genres and cultures. These readings will cover a variety of literary movements and historical eras. The readings will include selections from the Western canon. Written analysis of literary works may be required. Students will be provided with opportunities to practice critical interpretation.

courses.title: Survey of World Literature: Ancient to Renaissance
courses.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in the history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H, and N) (WR)

courses.title: Survey of World Literature: 17th Century to Modern
courses.description: Introduces some of the major writers, issues and forms found in history of the period. The instructor determines the breadth and focus of this survey. (C or H, and N) (WR)

courses.title: The Forms of Narrative
courses.description: A close reading and critical analysis of representative forms and styles of narrative, to improve the student's ability to study narrative structures and theories of narrative. Refer to department website.

courses.title: Studies in Poetry
courses.description: Variable topics provide in-depth study of genre such as the lyric, epic, or sonnet, or of developments in periods of literature such as the medieval, American, or African. Emphasizes refining the ability to read and analyze texts carefully and accurately. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Studies in Drama
courses.description: Variable topics provide an in-depth study of genre such as comedy or tragedy, or of developments in periods such as the Elizabethan, Jacobean, or Restoration. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Studies in Modern Drama
courses.description: Representative selections from continental, British, and American playwrights. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Jewish Literature
courses.description: Variable topics in the Jewish literary experience, from the biblical narrative and classical tales to Yiddish and Hebrew literature, the modern European novel, and American Jewish fiction.

courses.title: The Age of the Avant-Garde
courses.description: Examines the revolutionary experimentalist aspects of modern and contemporary culture, such as cubism, surrealism, structuralism, and conceptualism.

courses.title: The Bible as Literature
courses.description: Literary analysis from the Hebrew and Christian Bibles with an emphasis on poetry and narrative.

courses.title: Women in Literature
courses.description: Critical and thematic study of women in literature that may include fiction, poetry, or drama in English, American, or world literature. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Interdisciplinary Topics in Literature
courses.description: Interdisciplinary variable-topics study of the vital relationship between literature and other creative arts, other humanistic disciplines, or the sciences and technology. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Literature of Sustainability & Resilience
courses.description: Survey of literary nonfiction, fiction, memoir, and poetry addressing human responses to environmental change and crisis.

courses.title: World English Language Literatures
courses.description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the diverse English language literary traditions, including those of Ireland, Scotland, India, Nigeria, the Caribbean, Canada, and Australia. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Caribbean Literature in English
courses.description: Variable topics focus on the critical and analytical study of representative Caribbean authors writing in English. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: African Literature in English
courses.description: Critical and analytical study of representative Black-African authors writing in English, notably Achebe, Awoonor, Ngugi, Aidoo, Soyinka, Armah, Ekwensi, Mphalele, and p'Bitek'.

courses.title: Postcolonial Literature, Culture and Theory
courses.description: Variable topics explore the issues, questions, and themes raised in the rich literature, culture, and theory that emerge as a response to and in contestation of the experiences of the colonial and postcolonial worlds. Refer to department website for offered content.

courses.title: Comics Studies
courses.description: Variable topics provide an opportunity for the in-depth study of comics genres, notable comics writers, and illustrators and other significant topics on related subjects.

courses.title: The Folktale
courses.description: Reading folktales, myths, and legends, particularly those told orally by ethnic, indigenous, and emigrant cultures within the USA. Attention is paid to critical theory and the scholarly study of the folktale. In addition, the use of the folktale by creative writers and teachers is discussed.

courses.title: Children's Literature
courses.description: Arouse a genuine interest in children's books and obtain a critical knowledge of the literature.

courses.title: Literature for Young Children
courses.description: Explores kinds and qualities of literature for the younger child, examining the child's first experience with literature in oral forms, then moving on to picture and story books and poetry.

courses.title: Literature for the Adolescent
courses.description: Studies the types of literature read by adolescents, emphasizing the criteria for the choice of good books and developing a familiarity with the many books available.

courses.title: Golden Age of Children's Literature
courses.description: Origins and evolution of the Anglo-American tradition in literature for young readers, 1720-1920, with an emphasis on the Victorian era. Authors may include Defoe, Scott, Cooper, Dickens, Alcott, Twain and Stevenson.

courses.title: Issues and Methods in Cultural Studies
courses.description: Introduces the issues and methodology used in cultural studies and encourages the exploration of a number of methods by which culture is analyzed, understood, and disseminated. Refer to department website.

courses.title: Feminist Theories
courses.description: Introduces a variety of analytic, theoretical and interpretive approaches under the general rubric feminist theory; concentrates on current issues in literary and cultural studies, but also discusses other disciplines.

courses.title: Variable Topics in Literature and Language
courses.description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for the in-depth study of various topics, such as the literature of war and peace, of death and of courtly love. Refer to department website for offered topics.

courses.title: Reading and Writing Content Area
courses.description: Covers the fundamentals of beginning college writing and critical reading skills.

courses.title: Advanced Public Speaking
courses.description: Studies principles and methods of selected forms of public speaking for various purposes, audiences and contexts.

courses.title: Rhetorical Criticism
courses.description: Critical analyses of rhetorical elements and processes in oratorical and non-oratorical forms.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Biochemistry
courses.description: Introducing biochemistry with emphasis on intermediary metabolism.

courses.title: Community Nutrition
courses.description: Role of nutrition in promoting, maintaining and improving health in the community.
