courses.description: Examines the major sub-fields of linguistics by means of the Haitian Creole language. Introduces Haitian Creole syntax, morphology, phonology, semantics, and lexicon, as well as sociolinguistics, dialectology, language planning, bilingualism, and language contact.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in English, Haitian Creole or French
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application in some combination of English, Haitian Creole or French.

courses.title: Jamaican Creole, Reggae, and Rastafari
courses.description: Studies Jamaican Creole, reggae music, and Rastafari religion and culture; introduces the language, music, and religion of the Caribbean island. Methodology includes linguistics, ethnomusicology, and religious studies to read Jamaican Creole, interpret reggae songs, and analyze the Rastafari culture to which they link.

courses.title: Beginning Modern Hebrew 1
courses.description: Beginning Hebrew covers four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing. For those with no prior exposure to the language.

courses.title: Beginning Modern Hebrew 2
courses.description: Continues beginning Hebrew, covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.title: Intermediate Modern Hebrew 1
courses.description: Intermediate Hebrew study covers four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Modern Hebrew 2
courses.description: Continues intermediate Hebrew covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.title: Advanced Modern Hebrew 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with attention to more complex structures. (H and N)

courses.title: Advanced Modern Hebrew 2
courses.description: Continues advanced Hebrew study of the four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with attention to more complex structures. (H and N)

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: Individual work on an approved topic.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for in-depth study of special topics in Israeli literature, history, or culture.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Introduction to Israeli Culture
courses.description: Presentation and analysis of some key facets of Israeli culture. Topics include Jewish vs. Zionist (and Israeli non-Jewish) identities, Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Israeli-American relations, gender, and function of art in Israeli society.

courses.title: Identity and Dissent in the Hebrew Short Story
courses.description: Traces the tension between the individual and the collective in Zionist/Israeli society over the last 100-plus years as illustrated in Hebrew short fiction.

courses.title: Israeli History and the Contemporary Novel
courses.description: Studies Israeli history through the lens of the contemporary novel.

courses.title: Readings in Modern Hebrew Literature 1
courses.description: Readings in modern Hebrew novels, short fiction and poetry. While the study of literature is emphasized, some language work is presented to help with reading comprehension. Texts and instruction are in Hebrew.

courses.title: Readings in Modern Hebrew Literature 2
courses.description: Readings in modern Hebrew texts, including recently published stories and poems. Class is instructed in Hebrew.

courses.title: Special Topics in Hindi-Urdu
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in and in-depth study of prose or poetic genres in Hindi and/or Urdu. Supplementary critical readings in English.

courses.title: Beginning Italian 1
courses.description: ITA 1130 and its sequel, ITA 1131, constitute the basic sequence in Italian. Emphasis on the development of broad competence in the language. Oral-aural approach ensures competence in the four skills.

courses.title: Beginning Italian 2
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence in Italian. Emphasis on the development of broad competence in the language. Oral-aural approach ensures competence in the four skills.

courses.title: Intermediate Italian 1
courses.description: Enhances knowledge of Italian in all four skills: listening, reading, speaking and writing. The goal is to create communicative competence that enables students to advance to third year study and to benefit from their visits to Italy. (H and N)

courses.title: Intermediate Italian 2
courses.description: Completes second year sequence with emphasis on composition, literature and communication skills. (H and N)

courses.title: Accelerated Introduction to Italian
courses.description: Intensive course designed primarily for speakers or students with knowledge of another Romance language or strong linguistic abilities in another foreign language. Assumes no prior study of Italian and offers a complete four-skill (listening, speaking, reading and writing) introduction to the language.

courses.title: Italian Enhancement Section
courses.description: Italian-language reading and discussion to accompany and complement courses in other departments. Readings and discussions are in Italian to develop vocabulary and fluency related to the content of the companion course and to provide an international perspective on the issues of the main course. (N)

courses.title: Italian Conversation
courses.description: Develops and refines Italian oral and comprehension skills through exposure to and discussion of a range of topics relating to contemporary Italian society. Discussion and assignments address different registers of speech, from the colloquial to the formal. Active in-class participation is essential.

courses.title: Grammar and Composition 1
courses.description: Intensive language course designed to master grammatical principles, increase vocabulary and enhance writing and composition skills.

courses.title: Italian Civilization
courses.description: Variable topics introduce Italian civilization in historical, artistic, and literary contexts.

courses.title: Naples: Culture and History
courses.description: Historical, cultural, and socio-political exploration of the Italian city of Naples from its foundation by the Greeks to its present-day position within the Italian State. Readings, discussion, and analysis encompass the city’s rich literary, artistic, architectural, theatrical, and musical traditions as well as the socio-political history of Naples and the region of Campania.

courses.title: Contemporary Italian Culture
courses.description: Variable topics focus on modern Italy through literature, art and mass media, and current events.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: For advanced minors who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Italian faculty. Only three credits can count toward the minor.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Language or History/Culture in Italian
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Italian Literature and Film
courses.description: Study of modern Italian narrative and its adaptation to film by major Italian directors.

courses.title: Italy and Pilgrimages
courses.description: Through lectures, readings, and discussions, considers the continuing presence of Rome and other Italian cities as metaphors and focal points of Italian artistic and literary sensibilities. Taught in English.

courses.title: Italian Cinema
courses.description: Critical and historical study of Italian film and directors. Topics may vary.

courses.title: Murder Italian Style: Crime Fiction and Film in Italy
courses.description: Explores Italian crime fiction and film. Analysis considers specificity of Italian tradition while placing texts and films in a broader cultural and historical context, enabling critically and politically informed reading of the many applications and subversions of the generic formula. Taught in English.

courses.title: Gangsters and Godfathers: Italian Mafia Movies
courses.description: Examines Italian cinematic representations of organized criminality, in particular Sicilian Cosa Nostra and Neapolitan Camorra. Analysis considers specificity of Italian tradition while placing films in a broader history of the gangster genre to allow for a critically and politically informed reading of Italian generic subversions. Taught in English.

courses.title: The Demolition of Man: Italian Perspectives on the Jewish Holocaust
courses.description: Explores a sampling of Italy's texts on the Jewish Holocaust, centering on the work of survivor and theorist of the camps, Primo Levi. Material also encompasses the history of the Italian-Jewish community, as well as a selection of Italian films dealing with the realities and ethical implications of the camps.

courses.title: Special Topics in Italian Literature and Culture
courses.description: Selected topics in Italian literature, civilization and culture, including crossover influence of media. Can focus on one epoch's influence on another.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Italian in English Translation
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Introduction to Italian Literature 1
courses.description: The origins of early Italian literature, its central themes, and the cultural factors that influenced its development. Develops an ability to read critically in Italian.

courses.title: Introduction to Italian Literature 2
courses.description: The major Italian authors from the Renaissance through the 20th century.

courses.title: Italian Play
courses.description: Italian Play

courses.title: Boccaccio's Decameron
courses.description: Analysis of Giovanni Boccaccio’s canonical Decameron with a focus on the literary Dimension of Text as well as the political, historical, and religious context in which the work was written.

courses.title: Representing the Humble Italy: Literature and Cinema of the Italian South
courses.description: Examines texts and films that address the so-called Southern Question; namely, the socioeconomic and cultural disparities between northern and southern Italy. Explores or contests topics and concepts including southern exclusion from official history, southern fusion of religion and superstition, resistance to modernity and mafia-related political corruption. Taught in Italian.

courses.title: Delitto all'italiana: Crime Fiction and Film in Italy
courses.description: Explores a sampling of Italian crime fiction and film through the lens of a range of conceptual categories, including British intellectual model vs. American noir; rational inquiry vs. uncertainties of sensory perception; canon vs. popular; cosmopolitan vs. provincial; order vs. chaos; political conservatism vs. social critique. Taught in Italian.

courses.title: Italian Theater from the Renaissance to the Early Modern Era
courses.description: Overview and analysis of evolution of Italian theater, with focus on a selection of specific examples drawn from Italian theater from the Renaissance to the early modern era. Taught in Italian.

courses.title: Mad Love in Modern Italian Literature
courses.description: Exploration of a sampling of modern Italian literary manifestations of a love that strays beyond the conventional. Language skills addressed through discussion, oral presentations, creative writing assignments, and short papers.

courses.title: Animals and Animality in Italian Culture
courses.description: Presentation and exploration of the figure of the nonhuman animal in the work of several modern Italian authors and poets. Analysis addresses the literary dimension of the selected animal portraits as well as any philosophical and ethical questions raised by these literary animals. Taught in Italian.

courses.title: Dante's Inferno
courses.description: Semester-long, in-depth examination of Dante Alighieri's text, Inferno, with the support of a variety of visual materials and digital resources devoted to Dante and his world. Special attention paid to the political, historical, and religious context in which Dante wrote. Taught in Italian.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Literature in Italian
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Literature in Italian. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Literature in Italian.

courses.title: Beginning Japanese 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Japanese 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Japanese 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Japanese 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study.

courses.title: Advanced Japanese 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Japanese 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study in Japanese.

courses.title: Business Japanese
courses.description: Provides grammatical structures and essential business vocabulary, develops conversation strategies and presentation skills, and raises awareness of the customs and cultural differences in Japanese business interactions.

courses.title: Language in Japanese Society
courses.description: Analysis of variation in regional dialects: gender-based differences, pragmatics of interpersonal communication, language acquisition, and discourse structure.

courses.title: Japanese Translation: Theory and Practice
courses.description: Key concepts and approaches of translation studies applied to the translation of Japanese to English, and English to Japanese, in a variety of media, genre, and text types.

courses.title: Structure of Japanese
courses.description: Linguistic analysis of modern standard Japanese. Topics include phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics and writing. Readings and discussions in English. (S and N)

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Language or Linguistics
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Language or Linguistics. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Language or Linguistics.

courses.title: Special Topics in Japanese Studies
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in and in-depth study of special topics in Japanese studies.

courses.title: Senior Honors Thesis
courses.description: Select a Japanese faculty member to act as director for an independent research project that culminates in an honors thesis.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Faculty (or delegated authority) supervised internship. Requires a written post-internship report.

courses.title: Overseas Studies 1
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Overseas Studies 2
courses.description: Revolving topics provide a mechanism for coursework taken at a foreign university as part of an approved study abroad program to be transferred to UF. Credits taken will be entered in the student's transcript and may or may not count toward graduation, at the discretion of major's advisors.

courses.title: Tales of Kyoto
courses.description: An investigation of literary texts from the 8th through the 17th centuries presented within the framework of Western literary and feminist criticism.

courses.title: Modern Japanese Fiction in Translation
courses.description: Critical examination of stories, autobiographies, and secondary criticism from the 19th century to the present. Become familiar with the forms and topics of criticism through Japanese and Western sources.

courses.title: Contemporary Japanese Literature: Postwar to Postmodern
courses.description: Companion to JPT 3120 that reflects the increasing clarity with which contemporary Japanese literature (1945 to present) is emerging as a separate field with its own set of issues, major texts and significance for the American student of Japan. Writers range from Dazai and Oe Kenzaburo to Murakami Haruki, and issues range from subjectivity to cybernetics.

courses.title: Modern Women Writers
courses.description: Examination of narratives written by women who published during the Taisho (1912-25), Showa (1925-89) and Heisei (1989 to present) periods.

courses.title: Classical Japanese Poetry
courses.description: Historical survey of traditional Japanese poetry (waka) from the 8th to the 16th century.

courses.title: Samurai War Tales
courses.description: Explores the historical and cultural stimuli that led to war, recorded later as war narratives. Supported by images of architecture, narrative picture scrolls, and extant military accoutrements. (H and N)

courses.title: Early Modern Japanese Literature
courses.description: Surveys Japanese literature of the Early Modern period (also called the Edo period), 1600-1868. Introduces and analyzes historically significant, foundational works of Early Modern Japanese literature and theater. Explores the history of the period and the development of print technologies and new genres, and introduces critical aesthetic and cultural concepts.

courses.title: Introduction to Japanese Film
courses.description: Introduces the formal and historical features of Japanese film that have given it a unique position in film history. Emphasizes formal and critical analysis as well as the intellectual stakes of studying non-western film.

courses.title: Japanese Culture
courses.description: Introduction to Japanese culture with emphasis on tracing the origin and development of important aspects of Japanese literature, art, religion, and society. All readings in English.

courses.title: Japanese Visual Culture
courses.description: Explores issues within Japanese visual culture, and uses visual-cultural products to explore Japanese political, cultural, social, and historical issues. Introduces and analyzes historically significant, foundational works of Japanese visual culture, unpacks genre and genre tropes in contemporary works, and analyzes several visual-cultural works that tackle significant social issues.

courses.title: The Tale of Genji
courses.description: Investigation of the 11th-century masterpiece and its pervasive influence on Japanese literature, past and present.

courses.title: Japanese Folklore
courses.description: Study of native belief systems and the supernatural as reflected in the folk practice of ritual observance and in tales, myths, songs, and proverbs.

courses.title: Representations of Japan's Modern Empire
courses.description: Examines a variety of literary, historical, anthropological, and theoretical texts to explore racial and social issues related to Japan's imperial past. (H and N)

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in English Translation
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Overseas Studies 1
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Overseas Studies 2
courses.description: Revolving topics provide a mechanism for coursework taken at a foreign university as part of an approved study abroad program to be transferred to UF. Credits taken will be entered in the student's transcript and may or may not count toward graduation, at the discretion of major's advisors.

courses.title: Classical Japanese 1
courses.description: Introduction to classical Japanese texts with emphasis on reading comprehension, grammar analysis and translation.

courses.title: Classical Japanese 2
courses.description: Complex texts in classical Japanese with focus on comprehension, grammar, literature and culture.

courses.title: Readings in Japanese Literature
courses.description: A fourth-year language course based on literary texts, incorporating advanced reading skills and the analysis of literature in the original. (H and N)

courses.title: Japanese Texts and Contexts
courses.description: Complements JPW 4130, Readings in Japanese Literature, and focuses on contemporary issues as encountered in a variety of Japanese media.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Target Language
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Target Language. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Target Language.

courses.title: Beginning Korean 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural interaction.

courses.title: Beginning Korean 2
courses.description: Continued study of speaking, listening, reading, writing and cultural interaction.

courses.title: Intermediate Korean 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Korean 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Special Topics in Polish Studies
courses.description: Variable topics in Polish literature, culture and society. Taught in English.

courses.title: Introduction to Polish Language and Culture 1
courses.description: A two-semester Polish language sequence that introduces the basics of Polish language and culture.

courses.title: Introduction to Polish Language and Culture 2
courses.description: Second in the two-semester sequence. Helps to expand vocabulary, command of Polish grammar, and the ability to speak Polish.

courses.title: Intermediate Polish 1
courses.description: Improve speaking, reading, writing, and listening comprehension skills by reviewing and expanding the language principles introduced in POL 1130 and POL 1131.

courses.title: Intermediate Polish 2
courses.description: Improve speaking, reading, writing, and listening comprehension skills by reviewing and building upon the language principles introduced in POL 2220.

courses.title: Introduction to Russian Language and Culture 1
courses.description: RUS 1130 and its sequel, RUS 1131, offer a comprehensive introduction to Russian, using interactive methods to develop competence in speaking, listening, reading, writing and cultural interaction.

courses.title: Introduction to Russian Language and Culture 2
courses.description: Continuation of introductory language and cultural study.

courses.title: Intermediate Russian 1
courses.description: Intermediate study with exercises in sentence patterns, vocabulary building and oral and written discourse in Russian.

courses.title: Russian for Heritage Learners
courses.description: A practical overview of Russian grammar and writing for those with significant bilingual speaking and listening backgrounds. Devotes special attention to reading, writing and vocabulary development.

courses.title: Oral Practice in Russian
courses.description: Development of advanced speaking and listening skills in conversational Russian.

courses.title: Intermediate Russian 2
courses.description: Continued study with exercises in sentence patterns, vocabulary building and sustained oral and written discourse.

courses.title: Advanced Russian 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Russian 2
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Grammar and Composition
courses.description: Study of advanced grammar and composition in Russian.

courses.title: Advanced Oral Practice
courses.description: Continued development of advanced speaking and listening skills based on authentic written, audio and video texts from contemporary Russian culture.

courses.title: Russian Studies Research Seminar
courses.description: Introduces significant trends and ideas in Russian literary, cultural, historical, and critical studies. Develop the ability to understand and produce critical scholarly argument in a variety of formats, including class discussion, formal presentation, and a written research project.

courses.title: Language and Culture of the Russian Business World
courses.description: Combines advanced language training, a practical introduction to the language and culture of the contemporary Russian business world, and extensive practice translating and interpreting texts used in business settings. Focuses on issues such as starting companies and joint ventures, advertising, and setting up and conducting official meetings and telephone calls. Basic Russian business ethics are also studied.

courses.title: Theory and Practice of Russian-English Translation 1
courses.description: First part of a two-part translation series focusing on the theory and practice of conveying word semantics in Russian-English and English-Russian translation.

courses.title: Theory and Practice of Russian-English Translation 2
courses.description: Second part of the translation series focusing on the theory and practice of conveying sentence and paragraph semantics in Russian-English and English-Russian translation.

courses.title: Structure of the Russian Language
courses.description: Introduction to the phonology, morphology and syntax of contemporary standard Russian from a formal and semantic standpoint. Also includes the development of Russian word stress and a survey of the development of Russian verb tense, aspect and mood.

courses.title: Corrective Phonetics and Intonation
courses.description: Develops advanced-level phonetic and intonational skills via a variety of genres of authentic texts from Russian culture.

courses.title: Individual Work in Russian
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Russian Language
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Russian Language. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Russian Language.

courses.title: Special Topics in Russian
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Russian studies. New, experimental, or one-time offerings.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Russian Masterpieces
courses.description: Introduces the Russian literature of the 19th-21st centuries. Read some of the most influential works by Pushkin, Gogol, Tolstoy, Dostoevsky, Chekhov, Nabokov, Pasternak and Sorokin, thereby gaining essential knowledge of Russian history, culture and the authors personal lives. Readings and discussions in English. (H and N)

courses.title: Tolstoy and Dostoevsky
courses.description: Introduction to the major 19th century Russian novelists and their contemporaries. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Themes from Russian Literature
courses.description: Examines Russian everyday life and institutions of the 19th and 20th centuries through the media of literature and film.

courses.title: War and Peace
courses.description: Offers a close reading of Tolstoys epic novel War and Peace. Examines the literary and historical origins of the novel, its reflection of Tolstoy's obsession with history, and the emerging picture it presents of Russian identity. Taught in English.

courses.title: Russian Literature of the Twentieth Century
courses.description: Authors, movements, and genres in Russian literature from the Revolution of 1917 to the present. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Russian Cultural Heritage
courses.description: Introduces the culture of pre-revolutionary Russia. Philosophical, religious, artistic, and literary currents in relation to Western civilization. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Contemporary Russian Culture and Society
courses.description: Patterns of continuity and change in the philosophical and cultural values of Russian society as they explain the Soviet Union and contemporary Russia. Readings and discussions in English. (H)

courses.title: Violence and Terror in the Russian Experience
courses.description: Examines the impact of violence and terror on the human condition as reflected and expressed in well-known works of Russian literature (fiction and historical narratives), art and film. Taught in English. No knowledge of other languages required.

courses.title: Russia Today
courses.description: Patterns of continuity and change in the philosophical and cultural values of Russian society as they explain the Soviet Union and contemporary Russia. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Creative Lives: Writers, Artists, and Extraordinary People
courses.description: Explores Russian visions of creativity and creative people in Russian culture by placing them in dialogue with broader European and American models and considerations of creativity.

courses.title: Russian Fairy Tales
courses.description: Critical introduction to Russian fairy tales and folklore and an examination of the aesthetic, social, cultural, and psychological values they reflect.

courses.title: Russia through Film
courses.description: Examines Russian life, institutions, and the arts against the background of period-defining historical, political, and cultural events from the early twentieth century to the present day as reflected and refracted in some emblematic feature films, documentaries, and animated cartoon films produced in the Soviet Union and post-Soviet Russia.

courses.title: Russia's Struggle with Nature: Legacies of Destruction and Preservation
courses.description: Explores competing concepts of nature in modern Russian culture through works of Russian fiction and non-fiction in translation. Emphasis falls on environmental problems in Russia and the former Soviet Union (desiccation of the Aral Sea, pollution of Lake Baikal, the Chernobyl nuclear accident etc.) and their impact on Russian thought.

courses.title: The Twentieth Century through Slavic Eyes
courses.description: Introduces the literature, film, and culture of 20th century Eastern and Central Europe.

courses.title: Variable Topics in Russian Studies
courses.description: Variable topics in Russian studies, taught in English translation.

courses.title: Pushkin and Gogol
courses.description: Major works of Russian literature written in the first half of the 19th century. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Russian Modernism
courses.description: Introduces the major artistic contributions of Russian modernism in the context of the political, social, and cultural upheavals of late Imperial to Stalinist Russia (1890 - 1939).

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Russian Studies, English Translation
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Variable Topics in Russian Studies
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Russian studies, taught in English translation.

courses.title: Reading Russian Literature
courses.description: In-depth study of the vocabulary, structures, reading strategies and cultural background needed for understanding and interpreting a broad range of Russian prose fiction.

courses.title: Russian Drama and Poetry
courses.description: Study of plays and poems by major Russian writers from the 19th and 20th centuries. Readings in Russian.

courses.title: Russian Media Culture
courses.description: In-depth study of the history and recent trends in the Russian mass media and web-based technology and their impact on culture and society.

courses.title: Russian Short Prose
courses.description: Critical study of selected Russian short stories. Readings in Russian.

courses.title: Reading Eugene Onegin: Pushkin and Nabokov
courses.description: An in-depth study of one of Russia's most revered literary works, combining close readings of Pushkin's original with analyses of operatic, artistic and cinematic adaptations by Chaikovsky, Nabokov and others. Readings and discussions primarily in Russian.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Russian Studies, Target Language
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Selected Readings in Russian
courses.description: Special topic, author, genre, or movement in Russian literature.

courses.title: Swahili Oral Literature
courses.description: Introduces various genres of Swahili oral literatures and shows their importance, relevance, and function within Swahili culture.

courses.title: Beginning Swahili 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Swahili 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Swahili 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Swahili 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Advanced Swahili 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Swahili 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course.

courses.title: Readings in Swahili
courses.description: Readings in Swahili

courses.title: Beginning Vietnamese 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Vietnamese 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Vietnamese 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Vietnamese 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Vietnamese for Heritage Learners 1
courses.description: For those with significant speaking and listening skills, but limited reading and writing skills. Emphasis on developing latter two skills.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: For independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.title: Special Topics in Vietnamese Studies
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Vietnamese studies. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.title: Vietnamese Culture
courses.description: Overview of Vietnamese culture, language and history. Focuses on Vietnamese cultural norms, attitudes, values and culture through an examination of history, religious practices, language, literature, family structures, cuisine, daily life and the arts. (H and N)

courses.title: Beginning Wolof 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Wolof 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Wolof 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Wolof 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study.

courses.title: Advanced Wolof 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Wolof 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Language in African Society
courses.description: The role of language in the development of African societies. Language and nation building.

courses.title: Beginning Yoruba 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Yoruba 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Yoruba 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Yoruba 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Advanced Yoruba 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Yoruba 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course.

courses.title: Yoruba Diaspora in the New World
courses.description: Introduction to the scope and importance of Yoruban culture in the New World and its role and significance in the resilience of African cultures in North America, South America and the Caribbean. (WR)

courses.title: Readings in Yoruba Literature
courses.description: Reading skills and the analysis of literature in the original language.

courses.title: Introduction to African American Studies
courses.description: integrated interdisciplinary exploration of selected themes and representative materials in the African American experience in North America, emphasizing continuity and change.

courses.title: Surveying African-American Culture
courses.description: In-depth exploration of the rich and vast cultural heritage of African Americans. An interdisciplinary approach examines various modes of expression such as art, literature, music, sports, fashion, and social movements that have shaped African American culture from its roots in African aesthetics to modern-day popular culture. Highlights the significant contributions of African Americans to American culture, much of which are inspired by the pursuit of freedom, equality, and justice.

courses.title: Race and Sports in America
courses.description: Examine race, racism, and racialization in the sporting context in order to understand many salient issues in American society such as nationalism and patriotism, capitalism, sexism, oppression, etc. See the ways sports influence racial ideologies as well as the pervasiveness of racial oppression that exists on and off the playing field.

courses.title: Key Issues in African American and Black-Atlantic Thought
courses.description: The leading voices of resistance and social change that have influenced African American intellectual history, black public consciousness, political action and social theory.

courses.title: African American History: 1865 to Today
courses.description: Examines the history of African Americans in the United States from the end of the Civil War in 1865 to the present day. Through readings, lectures, discussions, and research, explores the major political, social, and cultural events and movements that have shaped the lives of African Americans during this period.

courses.title: The African Diaspora
courses.description: Overview of transnational fields of cultural contact, power and competing economic interests in which the African Diaspora developed.

courses.title: The Wire
courses.description: Critically examine various themes presented in the television show, The Wire. Major topics include the illegal drug trade, race and ethnicity, sexuality, public policy and politics, K-12 education, and the news media.

courses.title: Black Feminist and Womanist Theory
courses.description: Interdisciplinary survey of African American and Afro-descendant women's contributions to feminist theory.

courses.title: Black Power Movement
courses.description: An examination of the Black Power Movement, including major themes, roots in previous black organizing, associated groups and figures, and its influence on present society and activism.

courses.title: African Diaspora, Women, and Medicine
courses.description: Analyzes the history of African and African American healing traditions in medicine, beginning in West Africa and ending in the United States, paying particular attention to the role of women in ethnomedical traditions.

courses.title: Black Masculinity
courses.description: Integrated interdisciplinary exploration of selected themes and resources that represent the Black Masculine experience in North America, emphasizing continuity and change. (C, H, D, and E6)

courses.title: Race, Religion, and Rebellion
courses.description: Examination of the interplay of religion, race, and rebellion in the organization and execution of the various revolts, insurrections, and social movements of black people in the US from the slavery period through the Civil Rights and Black Power Eras.

courses.title: African American Religion
courses.description: Explores the African American religious experience from the beginning of the African sojourn here in North America until the present.

courses.title: Civil Rights and Religion
courses.description: Examination of the role of religion in the African American Civil Rights Movement from the 1950s through the 1980s.

courses.title: Archaeology of African American Life and Culture
courses.description: Historical overview of African American archaeology, including important cases, key figures, major issues, and development of the field.

courses.title: The Black Experience: Psychological Perspectives
courses.description: Interdisciplinary examination of themes, premises, and theories presented by major psychological theorists in their depictions and accounts of the behavior of Black people in America; the growth of Black psychology.

courses.title: History of Hip-Hop
courses.description: Examines the blossoming of hip-hop as a musical genre and as a cultural and political youth movement from the 1970s to the present, extending from its origins in New York city to the rest of the nation and the world.

courses.title: Black Digital Humanities
courses.description: Introduces Black Digital Humanities as a discipline. Examines Black life using computational tools, methods, and approaches combining computational and humanistic inquiry. Explores different modes of inquiry through readings, lectures, discussions, and research.

courses.title: Research Methods in African American History
courses.description: Research methods in African American history.

courses.title: Mentoring At-Risk Youth
courses.description: A community service-learning course that develops mentoring and critical-thinking skills though instruction, analysis and service. (S and N) (WR)

courses.title: Special Topics in African American Studies
courses.description: Lectures and seminars covering selected topics of current interests in African American studies.

courses.title: Theories of Black America
courses.description: A multi-disciplinary examination of some of the important theories and concepts used to explain Black social, political and cultural behavior in the United States for the past 150 years.

courses.title: African American History: 1619 to 1865
courses.description: Explores the history of African Americans from their arrival in the United States in 1619 to the end of the Civil War in 1865. Examines the experiences of enslaved Africans and African Americans, their resistance to slavery, and the various social, cultural, economic, and political forces that shaped their lives during this time period.

courses.title: Blacks in Florida
courses.description: Addresses the history and themes of Blacks in Florida between 1492 and 1975.

courses.title: Black Hair Politics
courses.description: Provides a comprehensive interdisciplinary examination of the history, sociology, psychology and economics of Black hair. Students will explore the textures, styles and meanings of Black hair as they relate to identity and power in society.

courses.title: Black Lives Matter
courses.description: Examination of the particular historical, geographical, cultural, social, and political ways in which race was, and continues to be configured and deployed in the United States.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: Directed individual reading or research on topics in African American studies.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Selected topics in African American studies.

courses.title: African American Studies Senior Integrative Seminar
courses.description: Examination of bibliographic resources and analysis of theory, method, and special problems in the field of African American studies.

courses.title: African American Studies Internship
courses.description: Complete internships with companies, individuals, institutions, or organizations whose work adds to the knowledge and well-being of the African American community.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.description: Comprehensive research paper that examines a relevant topic in the discipline of African American studies.

courses.title: Chemistry for the Liberal Arts
courses.description: This course provides students with an introduction to chemical principles and applications for the non-science major. Students will engage in problem solving and critical thinking while applying chemical concepts. Topics will include the scientific method of problem solving, classification of matter, atomic theory, the periodic table, gases, chemical reactions, energy, and chemical bonds.

courses.title: Introduction to Chemistry
courses.description: Introductory readiness course in general chemistry for those with weak yet satisfactory backgrounds in high school chemistry and algebra. (P)

courses.title: Basic Chemistry Concepts and Applications 1
courses.description: This course provides students with an introduction to chemical principles and applications for the non-science major. Students will engage in problem solving and critical thinking while applying chemical concepts. Topics will include the scientific method of problem solving, classification of matter, atomic theory, the periodic table, gases, chemical reactions, energy, and chemical bonds.

courses.title: Basic Chemistry Concepts and Applications 2
courses.description: The second half of CHM 1030/CHM 1031 sequence. Topics in organic chemistry and biochemistry. (P)

courses.title: General Chemistry 1
courses.description: This course is designed for students pursuing careers in the sciences or who need a more rigorous presentation of chemical concepts than is offered in an introductory course. Students will engage in problem solving and critical thinking while applying chemical concepts. Topics will include the principles of chemistry including atomic theory, electronic and molecular structure, measurement, stoichiometry, bonding, periodicity, thermochemistry, nomenclature, solutions, and the properties of gases.

courses.title: General Chemistry 1 Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to reflect the topics presented in CHM 2045. (P)

courses.title: General Chemistry 2
courses.description: The second semester of the CHM 2045/CHM 2045L and CHM 2046/CHM 2046L sequence. Students who completed CHM 2045 or equivalent at another institution should consult a chemistry advisor before registering for this course. Acids and bases, additional aspects of chemical equilibria, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, complex ions and descriptive chemistry.

courses.title: General Chemistry 2 Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to reflect the topics presented in CHM 2046. (P)

courses.title: One-Semester General Chemistry
courses.description: Designed for entering (not transfer) students who wish to move more quickly into advanced coursework. Electronic structure and bonding, gases, liquids, solids, kinetics, equilibria, acids and bases, thermodynamics, oxidation-reduction, metals and non-metals.

courses.title: One-Semester General Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 2047.

courses.title: Honors General Chemistry 1 for Majors
courses.description: First semester of the CHM 2050/2045L and CHM 2051/2046L sequence. Stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and equilibria.

courses.title: Honors General Chemistry 2
courses.description: Second semester of the CHM 2045/CHM 2045L and CHM 2051/CHM 2046L sequence. Open to students with superior performance in CHM 2045 or its equivalent. Acids and bases, additional aspects of chemical equilibria, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, complex ions, descriptive chemistry and instructor-chosen topics. (P)

courses.title: Accelerated General Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: A cross-disciplinary, inquiry-based curriculum that focuses on major themes and concepts in chemistry with an emphasis on their application in modern, quantitative life sciences research. Equivalent to CHM 2045L and CHM 2046L or CHM 2047L.

courses.title: Chemistry for Engineers 1
courses.description: The first semester of the CHM 2095/CHM 2096 sequence. Topics include stoichiometry, energy and thermodynamics, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and introduces chemical equilibria. All topics are taught in an engineering case-study context. (P)

courses.title: Chemistry Lab 1 for Engineers
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to complement CHM 2095.

courses.title: Chemistry for Engineers 2
courses.description: Second in a two-semester sequence. Topics include chemical equilibria, acid-base and solubility equilibria, entropy, free energy, electrochemical devices, solution dynamics, and descriptive inorganic and organic chemistry. All topics taught in an engineering case-study context. (P)

courses.title: Chemistry Lab 2 for Engineers
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to complement CHM 2096.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Organic Chemistry
courses.description: An elementary course embracing the more important aspects of organic chemistry. Intended for students in programs requiring only one semester of organic chemistry. Not intended for pre-med, pre-dentistry or pre-vet students.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Organic Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Organic laboratory experiments to accompany CHM 2200.

courses.title: Organic Chemistry 1
courses.description: The first half of the CHM 2210/CHM 2211 sequence intended for majors and preprofessional students. A study of the structures, syntheses and reactions of organic compounds.

courses.title: Organic Chemistry 2
courses.description: The second half of the CHM 2210/CHM 2211 sequence intended for majors and preprofessional students. A study of the structures, syntheses and reactions of organic compounds.

courses.title: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Organic laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 2210/CHM 2211 or CHM 3217/CHM 3218.

courses.title: Organic Chemistry 1 for Majors
courses.description: First half of the CHM 2212/CHM 2213 sequence for chemistry majors. A study of structures,  synthesis, and reactions of organic compounds,  with emphasis on mechanism and spectroscopy.

courses.title: Organic Chemistry 2 for Majors
courses.description: Second half of the CHM 2212/CHM 2213 sequence is for chemistry majors. Study of structures,  synthesis, and reactions of organic compounds, with emphasis on mechanism and spectroscopy.

courses.title: Introduction to Analytical Chemistry
courses.description: Principles involved in quantitative analysis. Topics include acid-base equilibria and titrations, precipitation and complex formation, oxidation reduction and statistical treatment of data. Introduces spectrochemical and electrochemical methods of analysis and chemical separations.

courses.title: Analytical Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 3120.

courses.title: Organic Chemistry/Biochemistry 1
courses.description: A rigorous, one-semester overview of the structure, properties and reactions of organic compounds. This is the first half of a two-semester sequence in biochemistry. Students are expected to take CHM 3218 after completing CHM 3217.

courses.title: Organic Chemistry/Biochemistry 2
courses.description: Introduces the basic concepts of biochemistry and molecular biology from the structural and mechanistic perspective of organic chemistry.

courses.title: Physical Chemistry for the Biosciences
courses.description: Thermodynamics, electrochemistry, transport, chemical kinetics and molecular structure with emphasis on biological systems.

courses.title: Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Basic theoretical concepts involved in inorganic chemistry. Periodic trends, chemical bonding, structure and reactivity.

courses.title: Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Synthesis and characterization of inorganic and organometallic compounds.

courses.title: Advanced Biochemistry and Chemical Biology
courses.description: Secondary metabolism and biosynthetic pathways, bioinorganic chemistry, protein folding and trafficking, cellular signaling, replication and translation from a chemist's perspective. Applications in bioanalytical chemistry and in molecular and cell biology.

courses.title: Instrumental Analysis
courses.description: Concepts of instrumentation for chemical analysis. In-depth examination of spectrochemical and electrochemical methods and chemical separations.

courses.title: Instrumental Analysis Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 4130.

courses.title: Electronics and Instrumentation
courses.description: Principles of operation of instrumentation, optimization of instrumental conditions, and interpretation of instrumental data for qualitative and quantitative analysis. Application of electronic principles necessary to code for automated electronic measurements in chemical research.

courses.title: Organic Spectroscopy
courses.description: Characterization and identification of organic compounds by spectral methods including IR, UV, NMR and mass spectrometry.

courses.title: The Organic Chemistry of Polymers
courses.description: Classification of polymerization types and mechanisms from a mechanistic/organic point of view. The structure of synthetic and natural polymers and polyelectrolytes. Reactions of polymers and practical synthetic methods of polymer preparation.

courses.title: Laboratory in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
courses.description: Introduces experimental techniques in biochemistry, especially those used in DNA isolation and manipulation, protein purification and enzyme kinetic studies.

courses.title: Chemical Aspects of Cellular Control
courses.description: Control of information, materials and energy within cellular systems. Examples taken from the biochemistry of plants, bacteria and higher organisms.

courses.title: Introduction to Enzyme Mechanism
courses.description: Principles of enzyme structure, isolation and purification and principles of the physical chemistry of enzyme/substrate interactions. Overview of concepts of biological catalysis, including transition state theory, descriptions and examples of mechanisms of biochemical catalysis, survey of co-factors, and catalytic antibodies, ribozyme structure and catalysis.

courses.title: Physical Chemistry: Thermodynamics and Kinetics
courses.description: Gas laws, kinetic theory, classical and statistical thermodynamics and applications to solutions, phase equilibria, chemical equilibria and electrochemistry.

courses.title: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: A series of laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 4411.

courses.title: Physical Chemistry: Chemical Bonding and Spectroscopy
courses.description: Introduces quantum theory, atomic and molecular structure, chemical bonding and spectra, chemical reaction rate laws and mechanisms, and statistical and collision theories of reaction rates.

courses.title: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: A series of laboratory experiments designed to accompany CHM 4412.

courses.title: Biophysical Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory experiments to demonstrate basic concepts of the physical chemistry of biological systems.

courses.title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: Introduces advanced concepts of modern inorganic chemistry. Major themes include application of group theory to structure and bonding, molecular orbital treatment of reactivity, fundamental organometallic chemistry and introduces vibrational and electronic spectroscopy.

courses.title: Bioinorganic Chemistry
courses.description: From an inorganic perspective, introduces the structure and function of a variety of metalloproteins and metalloenzymes, concentrating on systems containing transition metals. Emphasizes the role that metal ion(s) play in the function of the biomolecules.

courses.title: Individual Problems
courses.description: Double registration permitted. An assigned reading program or development of an assigned experimental problem.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Laboratory or literature investigations of chemical problems of current interest.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics in chemistry.

courses.title: Supervised Teaching
courses.description: Supervised teaching, usually at the general chemistry level. Required is a superior record at UF in the course in which the student will assist and evidence that the student's own progress will not be delayed.

courses.title: Interdisciplinary Junior Honors
courses.description: Special topics restricted to those in the university-wide honors program.

courses.title: Chemistry in the Cocina Latina
courses.description: Cross-disciplinary exploration of the intersection between the science of chemistry and the culture of the Spanish-speaking world. Studies the chemical reactions inherent in cooking while considering the role of food in the development and maintenance of culture. Active learning in laboratory and kitchen settings enhance the course content.

courses.title: Secrets of Alchemy
courses.description: Multi-disciplinary exploration of the history of alchemy, the precursor to modern chemistry. Studies the multi-dimensional relationships with philosophy, religion, and the natural sciences from antiquity to the modern era. Recreation of alchemical recipes in the teaching lab enhance the course content.

courses.title: Cross-Disciplinary Laboratory 1
courses.description: First course in a two-semester inquiry-based laboratory focusing on major themes and concepts in biology, chemistry and physics with an emphasis on their integrated applications in modern, quantitative research. Satisfies course requirements for BSC 2010L, CHM 2045L and PHY 2053L.

courses.title: Cross-Disciplinary Laboratory 2
courses.description: Second course in a two-semester inquiry-based laboratory focusing on major themes and concepts in biology, chemistry and physics with an emphasis on their integrated applications in modern, quantitative research. Satisfies course requirements for BSC 2011L, CHM 2046L and PHY 2054L.

courses.title: Research Methods
courses.description: The tools scientists use to solve scientific problems, including use of experiments to answer scientific questions, design of experiments to reduce systematic and random errors, use of statistics to interpret experimental results and deal with sampling errors, mathematical modeling of scientific phenomena and oral presentation of scientific work.

courses.title: Chemistry in the Cocina Latina
courses.description: Cross-disciplinary exploration of the intersection between the science of chemistry and the culture of the Spanish-speaking world. Studies the chemical reactions inherent in cooking while considering the role of food in the development and maintenance of culture. Active learning in laboratory and kitchen settings enhance the course content.

courses.title: Introduction to Literature
courses.description: In this course, students will be assigned readings representative of a broad range of literary genres and cultures. These readings will cover a variety of literary movements and historical eras. The readings will include selections from the Western canon. Written analysis of literary works may be required. Students will be provided with opportunities to practice critical interpretation.

courses.title: Beginning Spanish 1
courses.description: First in the basic Spanish language sequence, developing basic communication skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening.

courses.title: Beginning Spanish 2
courses.description: Second in the basic Spanish language sequence, continuing development of basic communication skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening.

courses.title: Accelerated Spanish Review
courses.description: Provides a rapid review of basic communicative Spanish as preparation for intermediate Spanish courses. For those with previous Spanish study but insufficient placement scores to move to the 2000 level.

courses.title: Elementary Spanish: Review and Progress
courses.description: Alternative to SPN 1130, for students who have previous experience in Spanish. Covers the material of SPN 1130 and meets three times weekly. SPN 1131 follows this course.

courses.title: Las Americas: Comida y Conflicto
courses.description: This course uses literature, film, art, music, and a variety of historical texts, both written and visual, to examine conflicts regarding the use of natural resources, specifically food production, in México, Central America and the Caribbean, at two key moments: the colonial period and the twentieth century.

courses.title: Accelerated Spanish Review for Heritage Speakers of Spanish
courses.description: Supports, strengthens, and develops the cultural and linguistic knowledge of Spanish heritage language learners with a focus on oral communication and writing development.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish 1
courses.description: First of the intermediate Spanish language sequence. Develops intermediate skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Builds communicative competence and enhances social and cultural awareness of the Spanish-speaking world. Taught entirely in Spanish.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish 2
courses.description: Second course in the intermediate Spanish language sequence. Continues development of intermediate skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Continues to enhance communicative competence and social and cultural awareness. Taught entirely in Spanish.

courses.title: Intensive Communication Skills
courses.description: Develops the ability to understand oral and written Spanish and is required of all majors and minors who are not bilinguals, unless they initially placed above this level. Preparation for 3000-level courses.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish Abroad
courses.description: Equivalent to SPN 2240, the obligatory first course in the Spanish major and minor for non-bilinguals. Preparation for upper-division Spanish courses. Promotes cultural awareness and develops an active command of the language by means of intensive interaction with the people and current issues and events of the Spanish-speaking host city and surrounding area.

courses.title: Accelerated Intermediate Spanish Abroad
courses.description: Students acquire intermediate communicative skills in Spanish through interaction in Spanish-speaking communities. Offered abroad only, course depends on intensive language immersion for successful acquisition in a shortened period of time. Successful completion is comparable to having passed SPN 2200 and SPN 2201.

courses.title: Introduction to Reading and Writing Spanish for Heritage Learners
courses.description: Intermediate-level course for heritage learners with some speaking and listening ability from exposure outside the classroom but with little or no formal exposure to the language. Emphasizes reading and vocabulary, introduces grammar and orthographic rules.

courses.title: Accelerated Spanish Abroad
courses.description: Reviews major aspects of grammar in a context that enhances understanding of the Spanish or Spanish-American way of life and modes of expression. Reading comprehension and composition are developed through readings on diverse topics related to Latin America and Spain.

courses.title: Spanish for Health Professions
courses.description: Provides students with the linguistic and cultural skills necessary for effectively treating Spanish-speaking patients with medical emergencies, illnesses and other health issues.

courses.title: Applied Spanish
courses.description: Spanish-language section designed to accompany and complement courses offered in other departments. Readings and discussions are in Spanish to develop vocabulary and fluency related to the content of the companion course and to provide an international perspective on the issues of the main course. (N)

courses.title: Spanish Grammar and Composition 1
courses.description: Intensive language course to develop mastery of grammatical principles, increase vocabulary and enhance writing and composition skills. This course (or SPN 3350 for bilingual speakers) is a prerequisite for most 3000/4000-level Spanish courses.

courses.title: Spanish Grammar and Composition 2
courses.description: Continues review of Spanish grammar begun in SPN 3300 and concentrates on intensive writing practice in expository Spanish. Highly recommended for Spanish majors and minors who are not taking the bilingual sequence; a prerequisite for SPN 4420, Advanced Composition and Syntax.

courses.title: Spanish Grammar and Composition for Heritage Learners
courses.description: Emphasizes aspects of the language and grammar for those who have learned Spanish through exposure outside the classroom in addition to some formal exposure in school settings, and whose speaking and comprehension abilities are generally more developed than their writing and reading skills.

courses.title: Spanish Conversation, Film and Culture
courses.description: Enhances students' oral skills in Spanish through movie reviews, oral reports, debates and class discussions. Introduces students to current social, economic and political issues in Latin-America and Spain through the critical analysis of contemporary Spanish-language films.

courses.title: Advanced Spanish Conversation 2
courses.description: Authentic materials of the Hispanic world are used to improve listening, comprehension and speaking skills. Oral expression is used in conversation and in formal and informal presentations on a variety of topics.

courses.title: Creative Writing in Spanish
courses.description: Provides the opportunity to develop and focus on using Spanish creatively in the writing of fiction. Emphasizes expanding vocabulary and language usage and encourages students to find their own voice by exploring topics and genres that they find meaningful and appealing.

courses.title: Commercial Spanish
courses.description: Introduces the vocabulary and business practices of the Hispanic world with an emphasis on oral and written business communications. Overview of cultural differences within the Hispanic world and between the US and the Hispanic world, with emphasis on the business impact.

courses.title: Marketing and Advertising in the Spanish-Speaking World
courses.description: An introduction to the related fields of marketing and advertising as they pertain to the Spanish-speaking world. Focuses on marketing campaigns and advertising strategies, in print and on television. Emphasis on the cultural element(s) and context(s) of marketing/advertising campaigns. Covers a representative sampling of Spanish-speaking countries, with special attention to Spain, Mexico, Argentina and the United States. Group work required for some class projects.

courses.title: Spanish Translation: Bridging Cultures
courses.description: Provides an introduction to the principles of translation, combined with practice in English-to-Spanish and Spanish-to-English written translations. Working individually and in groups, students will improve their reading and writing skills in both languages, hone their research skills, and work collaboratively to think critically about how best to use language to bring cultures into dialogue.

courses.title: Advanced Communicative Spanish Abroad
courses.description: Practical, in-class communication exercises in comprehension, speaking, reading and writing. Classroom activities are coordinated with homework to emphasize communication. The foreign setting also serves as a living language laboratory.

courses.title: Culture and Civilization of Spain
courses.description: A survey of Spanish history, customs and the arts from ancient times to the present; devotes considerable attention to life in contemporary Spain since the death of General Franco in 1975. (H and N)

courses.title: Culture and Civilization of Spanish America
courses.description: The rich and often conflicting diversity of the Americas as well as the historical experiences that allow us to speak of the Americas as a whole: The conquest, the colonial period, the struggles for independence against (neo)colonialism, the clashing and mixing of cultures, the yoke of slavery and servitude, the formation of rigid social hierarchies, and the frustrated search for democracy and economic development. These phenomena are followed in a variety of artistic media, from painting to poetry and from music to film. (H and N)

courses.title: Theater for Social Justice
courses.description: Fosters the ability to apply theater as a change-agent on social justice issues in the US and Latin America. Includes reading texts, writing scripts and essays, role plays, and Theatre Sports. Based on Augusto Boal's Theater of the Oppressed.

courses.title: Spanish for Educators
courses.description: Designed for learners interested in teaching Spanish as a world language and/or increasing their linguistic and cultural expertise to work with educational stakeholders. Improve Spanish proficiency, learn methods for teaching Spanish, and gain awareness of Hispanic cultures as they relate to educational settings.

courses.title: Revolving Topics Abroad
courses.description: Rotating topics focus on Spanish culture and civilization.

courses.title: Immersion in a Hispanic Community
courses.description: International service-learning course and immersion experience abroad. Comprises significant hours of community service in a Hispanic city, plus group discussions. Reflecting on learning is an important course component.

courses.title: Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics
courses.description: Initial overview of central theories and applications of linguistic analysis in the study of Spanish. The phonological, grammatical, discursive and social structures of Spanish are considered within five areas of popular inquiry in Hispanic linguistics: history of Spanish, language variation and change, Spanish in contact with other languages, political and educational linguistics, and acquisition of Spanish as a first and second language. Conducted entirely in Spanish and is a prerequisite for all 4000-level courses in Hispanic linguistics.

courses.title: Spanish for the Legal Professions
courses.description: Prepares students for professional work in legal professions in a Spanish-speaking environment. Enables students to understand legal texts and arguments, write documents and express themselves using legal vocabulary. Covers a broad mix of practical legal terminology, vocabulary and conversational skills. Conducted entirely in Spanish.

courses.title: Topics in Spanish and Spanish American Culture and Civilization
courses.description: Variable topics in Latin American culture and civilization, including racial identity, feminism, regionalism, music, film, art, religion and sports.

courses.title: Internship in Spanish
courses.description: This course complements the students' internship with guided reflection. Students can complete the internship wherever there is interaction with Hispanic communities. This program offers an open alternative so that students can customize their professional interests.

courses.title: Spanish in the Community
courses.description: Engages students in the local Spanish-speaking community through academic investigation and service work. Consists of classroom meetings, community projects outside of class, and reflective assignments; may be taken a maximum of one time on UF's campus and one time abroad.

courses.title: Advanced Spanish Composition and Structure for Heritage Learners
courses.description: Emphasizes aspects of Spanish style, syntax and registers that can be problematic for the heritage learner. Some prior formal training in the language is expected (SPN 3350 or equivalent in a Spanish-speaking country).

courses.title: Developing and Assessing Second Language Fluency
courses.description: Examines notion of fluency and oral proficiency in a second language, focusing on linguistic description and analysis. Provides the opportunity to practice and perfect fluency in Spanish.

courses.title: Advanced Composition and Syntax
courses.description: Emphasizes the finer aspects of Spanish syntax, vocabulary and style that give the advanced student difficulties. Class discussion, drills and written compositions.

courses.title: Spanish Second Language Acquisition
courses.description: Overview of second language acquisition theory with discussion of empirical studies on the acquisition of Spanish. Emphasis on research design and the analysis of oral or written production of learners of Spanish.

courses.title: Spanish First Language Acquisition
courses.description: Introduction to the field of first language acquisition, with special emphasis on the acquisition of Spanish. Presents the main theories of first language acquisition including the development of speech perception and production, the acquisition of the lexicon, and the emergence of syntax in Spanish speakers.

courses.title: The Spanish Sound System: Phonetics and Phonology
courses.description: Focuses on the precise description of Spanish pronunciation with some attention to dialect features and contrastive English phonetics.

courses.title: Bilingual Language and Thought
courses.description: Evaluates the interaction between linguistic and cognitive processes in bilinguals. Examines the primary psycholinguistic themes and the notion of embodied cognition through the perception of sound, space, time, and color. Explores how sensory perception is affected by language and the effect that bilingualism has on these processes.

courses.title: Sociolinguistics of the Spanish-Speaking World
courses.description: General overview of sociolinguistic issues of the contemporary Spanish-speaking world: language variation, language contact, discourse analysis, language attitudes, policy and planning, and social factors in language acquisition and use.

courses.title: Introduction to Spanish and Spanish American Dialectology
courses.description: Principles and methods of dialectology applied to the study of regional varieties of Spanish in Spain and in Spanish America.

courses.title: Introduction to the History of the Spanish Language
courses.description: The phonological, morphological, syntactic and semantic evolution of the Spanish language from Latin.

courses.title: Introduction to Spanish Syntax
courses.description: Explores syntactic, morphological and semantic aspects of the Spanish language.

courses.title: Spanish Bilingualism
courses.description: Examines the internal and external factors that lead to and result from bilingualism in regions where Spanish is spoken. Organized into three primary components: social aspects; linguistic aspects; political and educational aspects.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: For advanced majors and minors who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Spanish faculty. For honors thesis use SPN 4906.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.description: Honors thesis preparation.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Spanish
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Revolving Topics in Linguistics and Culture
courses.description: Variable content provides opportunity for in-depth study of linguistic and cultural topics not offered in other courses and of topics of special current significance.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Topics in Latin American and Spanish Culture and Film
courses.description: Provides a broad survey of topics and issues pertaining to Latin American (including Brazilian) and Spanish contemporary culture through the analysis and interpretation of texts and films. Coursework is organized by country, theme, or genre on a rotating basis.

courses.title: Survey of Spanish-American Literature: From Discovery to Independence
courses.description: Overview of Spanish-American literature and its cultural context from the European conquest of the Americas to the 19th century. Introduces principal literary movements and authors, and trains students to read critically and to appreciate literary Spanish.

courses.title: Survey of Spanish-American Literature: From Independence to Contemporary Times
courses.description: End of the 19th century to the present. Introduces principal literary movements and authors, and trains students to read critically and to analyze literary Spanish. Reading of major authors who may include Borges, Garcia Marquez, Neruda, Fuentes and Ferre.

courses.title: Crescent; Cross; Star of David: Iberian Cultural Crossroads 1100-1700
