courses.description: Introduces safety, health and environmental regulations on the state and federal levels that impact the delivery of fire and emergency services. OSHA, EPA and NFPA regulatory requirements are introduced along with methods and techniques to implement compliance programs.

courses.title: Fire and Emergency Services Human Resource Management
courses.description: Major human resource management functional areas for fire and emergency services agencies. Topics include organizational employment planning, employment regulation, job analysis, performance assessment, recruitment and regulation, job analysis, performance assessment, recruitment and selection, training and development, employee/labor relations and compensation.

courses.title: Fire and Emergency Services Public Relations
courses.description: Implementation of principles and methods in advocating factual claims and policy proposals: prepositional analysis, evidence as demonstration, effective reasoning processes and ethics in controversy. Also focuses on public speaking and presentations, especially in the areas of technology, defense of budgets and political leadership.

courses.title: Management of Mass Casualty Incidents
courses.description: Covers systematic approaches to triage, treatment and transport in response to large-scale emergency medical services incidents. Resource planning and coordination with hospital systems is also emphasized.

courses.title: EMS Special Operations
courses.description: Discusses the various special roles in which EMS personnel may serve, such as hazardous materials, water rescue, and technical rescue.

courses.title: EMS Community Risk Reduction
courses.description: Provides a theoretical framework for the understanding of the ethical, sociological, organizational, political, and legal components of community risk reduction, and a methodology for the development of a comprehensive community risk reduction plan.

courses.title: Legal, Political, and Regulatory in EMS
courses.description: Introduces the EMS professional to the legal aspects of Emergency Medical Services. Explores issues in malpractice, consent and refusal of treatment, OSHA, employment issues, and risk management. EMS students gain insights into the legal liabilities in Emergency Medical Services.

courses.title: Quality Management and Research in Emergency Services
courses.description: Introduces the EMS professional to benefits of quality improvement, the history of quality in EMS, measuring quality, and the uses of quality in EMS.

courses.title: Management of Fire Prevention Programs
courses.description: Planning, promoting and executing fire prevention functions, including an emphasis on legal responsibilities, needs assessments, negotiation and planning activities.

courses.title: Fire Investigation and Analysis
courses.description: Examines the technical, investigative, legal, and social aspects of arson, including principles of incendiary fire analysis and detection, environmental and psychological factors of arson, legal considerations, intervention, and mitigation strategies.

courses.title: Disaster Recovery and Mitigation
courses.description: Provides the opportunity to understand real world disaster response efforts through academic study and interactive applied activities. Topics include the Incident Command System (ICS), Emergency Operations Center (EOC) management, Resource Management (RM), and Command-Communications-Coordination (C3).

courses.title: Critical Incident Management for Emergency Managers
courses.description: Examines disaster planning and emergency management. Focuses on the four phases of planning, mitigation, response, and preparedness. Includes FEMA and federal government NIMS ICS-700 and ICS-800 certifications.

courses.title: Disaster Planning and Control
courses.description: Examines concepts and principles of community risk assessment, planning and response to fires and natural and human-caused disasters, including National Incident Management System--Incident Command Systems (NIMS ICS), mutual aid and automatic response, training and preparedness, communications, civil disturbances, terrorist threats/incidents, hazardous materials planning, mass casualty incidents, earthquake preparedness, and disaster mitigation and recovery.

courses.title: Natural Disaster Phenomena in Florida
courses.description: Natural disasters prevalent in Florida: past, present, and future, including hurricanes, flooding, freezes, and agricultural emergencies. Also addresses planning, operations, mitigation, recovery, and evaluation concerns.

courses.title: Introduction to Terrorism in Emergency Management
courses.description: Introduces the fundamental concepts, theories, principles, and practice of terrorism and terrorist events.

courses.title: Special Studies in Fire and Emergency Services
courses.description: Special areas of study in fire and emergency services adjusted to the needs of individual students.

courses.title: Current Issues in Fire and Emergency Services
courses.description: Information and direction for fire service administrators on current legislative, legal, labor and/or technology concerns facing fire and emergency services agencies.

courses.title: Africa in World History
courses.description: One-semester introduction to African history for undergraduates. Links the history of African societies with other world civilizations by focusing upon major historical themes. (H and N)

courses.title: Africa to 1800
courses.description: Ancient Africa, the expansion of Islam, savannah kingdoms, East African trading cities, maritime contacts with Europe, the slave trade.

courses.title: Africa Since 1800
courses.description: End of the slave trade and the growth of legitimate commerce; Islamic renewal and revolution; the European partition and the colonial era; the growth of nationalism and the reemergence of independent Africa.

courses.title: History of West Africa
courses.description: History of West Africa, from the Ghana Empire to the contemporary period.

courses.title: Special Topics in African History
courses.description: Selected variable topics in the history and culture of Africa.

courses.title: Modern Africa
courses.description: Selected topics in 19th and 20th century African development; pre-colonial conditions, colonial rule, nationalist movements, and the problem of independence.

courses.title: African Women in the Twentieth-Century
courses.description: Explores themes of politics, social structure, and cultural change by examining the historical experiences of African women.

courses.title: Southern Africa
courses.description: History of southern Africa from the pre-European era to the present.

courses.title: History Research Seminar: Africa
courses.description: Through rotating content, this seminar has two distinct goals: historiography of a specific topic and production of a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

courses.title: Fight for Your Rights: The Long Civil Rights Movement
courses.description: A multidisciplinary examination of one of America’s most defining social justice movements, the long civil rights movement.

courses.title: United States to 1877
courses.description: Examine United States history from before European contact to 1877. Topics include but are not limited to indigenous peoples, the European background, the colonial period, the American Revolution, the Articles of Confederation, the Constitution, issues within the new Republic, sectionalism, manifest destiny, slavery, the American Civil War, and Reconstruction.

courses.title: United States Since 1877
courses.description: In this course, students will trace the history of the United States from the end of the Reconstruction era to the contemporary era. Topics will include but are not limited to the rise of Industrialization, the United States’ emergence as an actor on the world stage, Constitutional amendments and their impact, the Progressive era, World War I, the Great Depression and New Deal, World War II, the Civil Rights era, the Cold War, and the United States since 1989.

courses.title: History of Sustainability
courses.description: Explores the history of sustainability as an idea and practice in the US from the time of European settlement to the near present.

courses.title: The Gilded Age
courses.description: Changes that occurred in America between 1877 and the advent of WWII, emphasizing the meaning of Americanism, conflicts between labor and capital, and the relations between historical events and race, gender and politics.

courses.title: America in the Sixties
courses.description: Social and political movements of the turbulent era of 1960s America, covering primarily the civil rights, feminist and anti-war movements.

courses.title: History of Disability in America
courses.description: How disabilities have been labeled, identified, and treated over time and in light of broad social trends.

courses.title: Florida to 1845
courses.description: Exploration, settlement, and colonial history of Spanish and British Florida from US territorial days to statehood.

courses.title: Florida Since 1845
courses.description: Statehood and secession, Civil War, Reconstruction, reform, and reaction, Progressive Era, boom and bust, diversification, and growth of Florida since World War II.

courses.title: US Urban History
courses.description: Analyzes the growth and development of urban civilization in the US, emphasizing how cities began and their impact on politics, economics, and culture.

courses.title: US Labor History
courses.description: Emphasizes the history of America's working-class people and addresses such issues as working class consciousness, theories of organized labor, methods of organization, and class relationships.

courses.title: American Foreign Relations and Expansion Since 1914
courses.description: Focuses on the origin, conduct, and consequences of American diplomacy during an era of global conflict and revolutionary upheaval.

courses.title: US - Middle East Relations
courses.description: Examines US - Middle East relations in historical context, including culture, US - Israeli relations, nationalists, radicals, events, and issues that impact this relationship.

courses.title: The American Jewish Experience 1880-2000
courses.description: Introduces the major events and issues in American Jewish history and offers a sense of why Jews felt at home in America. Focuses on immigration, assimilation, and collective survival.

courses.title: Constitutional History of the United States to 1877
courses.description: Analyzes the development of constitutionalism from English colonial origins to the end of Reconstruction, emphasizing the inherent tension between concepts of power and liberty.

courses.title: Constitutional History of the United States Since 1877
courses.description: Continues AMH 3551, giving special attention to the way in which constitutionalism has adapted to the growth of an urban and industrial society, to the extension of civil liberties and civil rights, and to the growth of executive authority.

courses.title: United States Legal History
courses.description: Nontechnical survey of American legal development from its English common law origins to the present.

courses.title: American Women in the 19th Century
courses.description: Examines women's history during the 19th century with a focus on how women gradually entered the public arena as laborers, reformers, writers, and performers.

courses.title: Women in Modern US
courses.description: Introduces major events, trends, and issues in the history of US women from the Civil War to the present.

courses.title: Diversity in American History
courses.description: Examines the diversity of the American people and its changes over time from first European contact to the present. Focuses on the interaction between different ethnic groups in American history and how the changing notions of race have helped shape the contours of that history.

courses.title: African American and Latino Histories
courses.description: Comparative examination of the histories of African Americans and Latinos from the early 19th century to present. Major themes include the social construction of race, the development of state policies that enforced racial inequality, struggles for equal citizenship, cultural and social movements for change.

courses.title: Oral History
courses.description: Introduces the theory and practice of oral history. Examines key issues in historical memory, interviewing, and community-based fieldwork; also examines scholarly debates on oral history as a dialogic mode of knowledge production. Learn digital humanities production methods to bring historical knowledge to broader audiences.

courses.title: American Environmental History
courses.description: Substantive and interpretative inquiry of the historical roots of the nation's contemporary environmental issues. A comprehensive overview of the relationship between people and their natural physical surroundings from the Columbian explorations to the 1980s.

courses.title: Native American History to 1815
courses.description: Examines the representations and realities of North American Indian history from the pre-Columbian period through the early 19th century.

courses.title: Native American History Since 1806
courses.description: Examines the representations and realities of North American Indian history from the early 19th century to the present.

courses.title: African Diaspora in the Americas
courses.description: Explores the centrality of Africa in the Americas by studying revolutions against slavery and colonialism in the African Diaspora from the 18th century to present with a special emphasis on the development of democratic ideologies among people of African descent in the Americas.

courses.title: American Slavery and Abolition
courses.description: History of American slavery and abolition from the 1600s through emancipation and the Reconstruction Era.

courses.title: Special Topics in American History
courses.description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of America.

courses.title: Early America
courses.description: Origin and development of an American society along the eastern seaboard of North America.

courses.title: New World Encounters
courses.description: Analyzes the intellectual, cultural, and social changes which resulted in a mixture of ideas and cultures from Europe, Africa, and native America.

courses.title: American Revolutionary Era, 1760-1789
courses.description: Analyzes the background of, and reasons for, the American Revolution, the social, military, political, diplomatic aspects of the era, as well as the constitutional developments of these years.

courses.title: The Early Republic, 1789-1848
courses.description: Social, political, cultural and economic history of America in its formative years. The Age of Jefferson (1789-1824) and the period of the first party system, including the policies and the wars of the Virginia dynasty. The second half, the Age of Jackson (1824-1848), discusses the rise of the Democratic and Whig parties, Native American removal, trends in religion and reform, further western expansion and the sectionally divisive Mexican War. (H) (WR)

courses.title: US World War I to World War II
courses.description: Post-World War I America: the Twenties, the Depression and the New Deal, WW II.

courses.title: US Since World War II
courses.description: Post-World War II America: America as world power, social revolution, Vietnam, Watergate, and after.

courses.title: History of Sexualities
courses.description: Social history of sexuality, tracing history of ideas about and attitudes toward sexuality in law, politics, medicine, and science from ancient Greeks to the present; emphasizes the North American experience.

courses.title: Violence and Social Conflict in American History
courses.description: Changing patterns and levels of violent behavior during the last four centuries of American history, including rioting, lynching, domestic violence, and street violence.

courses.title: History by Hollywood
courses.description: Compares Hollywood films with traditional historiographic accounts to explore the cultural and political history of the 1950s, '60s and '70s, including the Montgomery Bus Boycott, civil rights, the Vietnam War, and political assassinations.

courses.title: Crime and Punishment in American History
courses.description: Historical development of crime and criminal justice in America with particular attention to the ways in which social, political and cultural forces have shaped legal institutions during the past four centuries.

courses.title: History of American Capitalism
courses.description: Political, economic and social contours of American capitalism from the late 18th century through the near present.

courses.title: The South to 1865
courses.description: Development of southern culture from the earliest settlements to the development of southern nationalism.

courses.title: The South Since 1860
courses.description: Impact of Civil War and Reconstruction; economic, political and social development of the new South.

courses.title: Origins of the US Constitution
courses.description: The colonial origins, drafting, and ratification of the US Constitution and its application through 1819. Examines the political, economic, and intellectual influences that helped shape the constitutional system designed by the framers.

courses.title: American Civil War and Reconstruction
courses.description: Analyzes the political, social, and economic transformation of the Union, highlighting the presidency of Lincoln, the evolution of federal policies of Unionist loyalty and slave emancipation, the development of Union military leadership, and the tragically unsuccessful post-war attempt to provide justice to the freed people.

courses.title: Civil Rights Movements
courses.description: Introduces the origins, development, and legacies of the African American civil rights and black movements in America, focusing primarily on the period between 1945 and 1980.

courses.title: Sport and American Culture
courses.description: Explores the place of sport in American society and culture from the time of European settlement to the present. Uses sport, in its institutional and recreational forms, to illuminate broader historical themes, urban and community life, economic development, social relationship, social mobility and popular and cultural processes.

courses.title: History Research Seminar: US
courses.description: Introduces the historiography of a specific topic and production of a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

courses.title: History of the Modern Middle East
courses.description: Surveys the history, politics and society of the Middle East from the early 19th century until the present day. Topics include transformation of Islamic empire to post-colonial states, development of collective identities, the formation of new social classes and changing gender relations.

courses.title: Modern Japan
courses.description: Surveys the social, political and economic transformation of modern Japanese society from 1800.

courses.title: Special Topics in Asian History
courses.description: Variable topics in the history and culture of Asia.

courses.title: History Research Seminar: Asia
courses.description: Variable topics seminar with two distinct goals: introduce the historiography of a specific topic and produce a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

courses.title: Western Civilization: From Early Times to the Middle Ages
courses.description: Introduces western civilization that studies the early cultures in Mesopotamia and Egypt, the Minoan-Mycenaean society, Greece, the Hellenistic period, and the Roman Empire to the Barbarian invasions.

courses.title: Western Civilization: From the Middle Ages to the Eighteenth Century
courses.description: Treats feudal, urban and religious institutions in Medieval society, Renaissance and Reformation, the Thirty Years' War, the Age of Louis XIV, and the Age of Reason.

courses.title: Western Civilization: From the Eighteenth Century to the Present
courses.description: Explores 18th-century revolutions, Napoleon, romanticism and reaction, national unifications and imperialism, competing ideologies, the world wars, and Europe in the postwar era.

courses.title: History of the Holocaust
courses.description: Origins of anti-Semitism in central Europe and the execution of the Holocaust by Nazi Germany. Examines the ideology of the Nazi leaders and the role of the SS, Army, Police, and ordinary citizens in perpetrating genocide.

courses.title: Nazi Germany
courses.description: Political and cultural analysis of the history of Nazi Germany examining Nazi ideology, the origins of the Nazi state, coercion and consent among ordinary Germans, persecution of the disabled and of Jews, resistance and non-resistance, and the course of World War II from the German perspective.

courses.title: Intellectual History of Europe, Renaissance to Modern
courses.description: Examines intellectual developments that have shaped modern views of human nature, society, the natural world, and God.

courses.title: The Early Middle Ages
courses.description: Studies the formation of the Medieval West from the dissolution of the Roman Empire to the year 1000 A.D. Emphasizes the ways in which Roman, Christian, and Germanic traditions fused to form a new civilization.

courses.title: The High Middle Ages
courses.description: Examines European civilization from the 11th to the 14th centuries. Contrasts the urban and rural, northern and southern forms of economic social, cultural, and political phenomena.

courses.title: Renaissance
courses.description: Interpretations of the Renaissance: Italy's political, literary and artistic developments. The northern Renaissance and Christian Humanism. (H and N) (WR)

courses.title: The Reformation
courses.description: Critical religious changes in Europe from the 15th to 17th centuries. Pays particular attention to the broad impact of religion on the social, cultural, and political developments of the period.

courses.title: Medieval Magic
courses.description: Assessment of the cultural, religious and political implications of the supernatural in late antique, medieval and early modern European society (400-1700 CE). Besides addressing the role of scapegoating in the persecution of marginalized groups, it suggests how belief in demonic magic co-existed with Christian belief in miracles.

courses.title: Medieval Archaeology
courses.description: Methods and theory of archaeology with particular emphasis on the Medieval period and the relation between the written and the archaeological evidence.

courses.title: Early Modern Europe, 1500-1700
courses.description: Development of Europe as it emerged from Middle Ages focusing on the growth of the modern state and the critical changes in politics, science, economics, and religion.

courses.title: Eighteenth-Century Europe
courses.description: Studies European politics, economics, society, ideas and institutions in the 18th century, including early modern forms of governance, the Enlightenment, and the Age of the Revolution.

courses.title: Nineteenth-Century Europe
courses.description: Studies European politics, society, ideas and institutions, including the French Revolution, emergence of modern politics, upheavals of 1848 and 1871, rise of nationalism, urbanization, and socialism.

courses.title: Twentieth-Century Europe
courses.description: Origins and outcomes of the two world wars, the varieties of European social and political ideologies, and the ever-changing pattern of national and trans-national identities.

courses.title: Holocaust in the Courtroom
courses.description: Examination of major Holocaust trials and the conflict between justice, national identities, and historical narrative in Germany, Israel, France, the Soviet Union, and the US.

courses.title: Authoritarian Interwar Europe
courses.description: A comparison of extremist political regimes in Europe from 1917 to 1945. Special attention to Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union.

courses.title: Byzantine History
courses.description: Surveys Byzantine history with emphasis on political, economic, and religious institutions, and the role of Byzantium in medieval Europe.

courses.title: Medieval Eastern Europe
courses.description: Eastern Europe from late Antiquity to the 15th century. Examines the major problems of medieval history, with special emphasis on the role of the region in the history of the continent.

courses.title: Late Modern Central and Eastern Europe
courses.description: Cultural, social, and political survey of the Hapsburg Monarchy, Poland, and the Balkans from 1700 to 1918. Topics include absolutism, revolutionary nationalism, modernization, cultural flowering, ethnic violence, socialism, and WWI.

courses.title: Pagans, Christians, Barbarians: the World of Late Antiquity
courses.description: Surveys the history of the Mediterranean region from the second to the 7th century with a particular focus on religious and cultural developments that marked the rise of a Christian Roman Empire.

courses.title: Early Medieval Italy
courses.description: Surveys economic, social and political developments in the Italian peninsula between 800 and 1100.

courses.title: Medieval France
courses.description: A chronological and topical introduction to the history of medieval France, from the abandonment of the Roman province of Gaul to the beginning of the Hundred Years War.

courses.title: The French Revolution
courses.description: Examines one of the most transformational events in European and world history. The French Revolution brought about the overthrow of a centuries-old monarchy, the rapid mutation of social relations, the abolition of slavery, and the end of the Christian calendar. Introduces the major events of the period and to the historiographical debates among historians who continue to debate its significance by examining the causes and the effects of the revolution.

courses.title: Medieval Germany
courses.description: Surveys economic, social and political developments in Central Europe during the Middle Ages (500-1350).

courses.title: Medieval England
courses.description: Creation of a national society and culture in the time of England's constitutional development (to the 16th century).

courses.title: Early Modern England
courses.description: Development of a revolutionary tradition and of a parliamentary monarch in the period of England's cultural flowering (16th to 18th centuries).

courses.title: Modern Britain
courses.description: Social, political, and economic developments in the19th and 20th centuries.

courses.title: Colonies to Commonwealth: the History of the British Empire
courses.description: History of the British Empire from its origins in Ireland to the decolonization movements of the 20th century. Examines not only the ways in which the British established and extended the empire through the political, military, economic, and cultural spheres, but also resistance to empire.

courses.title: Ireland in the British Empire
courses.description: Place of Ireland in the British Empire and the imperial experiences of the Irish people. Covers the main themes of Irish history from the Tudor conquest to the establishment of the Irish Republic, all the while being attuned to the broader imperial context.

courses.title: Central and Eastern Europe in the 20th Century
courses.description: Covers the collapse of Austro-Hungary, its successor states in the inter-war period, World War II, the Holocaust, and the rise and fall of Communism in Central and Eastern Europe.

courses.title: Imperial Russia, 1700-1914
courses.description: Major institutional, political, social, and economic issues confronting the Russian state, drawing on source materials and on Russian literature to illustrate these issues.

courses.title: Twentieth-Century Russia to 1953
courses.description: Internal political, economic, and social history of 20th-century Russia, including the impact of modernization, the rise of radical ideologies, the Bolshevik revolution, and the evolution of the Soviet Union.

courses.title: Jewish History from 711 to 1492
courses.description: Surveys major historical developments in medieval Jewish society under Islam and western Christendom. Examines the interaction of Jews with the majority culture, political structure and economy, as well as changing cultural trends.

courses.title: Jewish History from 1492-1750
courses.description: Surveys major trends in Jewish society from the f15th to the 18th century, focusing on community structures and interfaith relations.

courses.title: Modern European Jewish History
courses.description: Major events and themes of the Jews in Europe from 1650-1945.

courses.title: The History of Consumption
courses.description: Combines economic, social, and political history to study the rise of consumer culture from the 18th century to the present. Primarily focused on Europe but includes the United States in the 20th century.

courses.title: Special Topics in European History
courses.description: Selected variable topics in the history and culture of Europe.

courses.title: Holy War in the Middle Ages
courses.description: Examines the shifting terrain of historical and theological conceptions of war and holy war in the middle ages. Divided into four distinct sections: theological foundations, early medieval conceptions of war and community, the Crusades and changes in the high and late middle ages.

courses.title: The Viking Experience
courses.description: Scandinavian medieval history, including an examination of the profound changes brought by Christianization and the rise of the medieval states.

courses.title: History of the Second World War
courses.description: Analyzes World War II, covering the origins, politics, resistance movements, grand strategy and consequences. (H) (WR)

courses.title: History of Cold War Europe
courses.description: Cold War era in Europe, 1945-1991; emphasizes origins, social, economic and political aspects, and the historical consequences on Europe.

courses.title: History of Medieval Spain
courses.description: History of the Iberian Peninsula between Late Antiquity and the end of the Reconquista. Emphasizes Muslim Spain, the Christian kingdoms in the North, Christian-Muslim-Jewish interactions, cultural development and social differentiation.

courses.title: Jews of Medieval Spain
courses.description: Explores Jewish life and culture in the Iberian Peninsula from the early middle ages through the Expulsion of 1492. Analyzes interfaith relations and the role Jews played in shaping Spanish society and culture.

courses.title: Nineteenth-Century Germany
courses.description: Germany's political development toward nationhood in the 19th century, and the imperial policies of Bismarck and Wilhelm II. The social history of specific groups in German society. Germany's role in the outbreak of WW I. Offered alternate years.

courses.title: Medieval Russia
courses.description: Introduces the history of Eastern Europe from ca. 500 to 1584. Focuses on interconnected themes of state formation, trade, conversion to Christianity and the impact of the Mongol conquest.

courses.title: Society and the Sexes in Modern Europe, 18C to the Present
courses.description: Gendered analysis of great historical events, political movements and ideologies. Other topics of social and cultural history are discussed.

courses.title: Modern European Revolutions: 1789-1989
courses.description: History of key European revolutions that occurred between 1789 and 1989. Emphasizes the economic, cultural and political conditions that gave rise to and accompanied the development of these watershed events.

courses.title: Terrorism and Political Violence in Post-War Europe: 1945-2000
courses.description: Provides a multi-country historical survey of the role terrorism and violence have played in European affairs in the post-Second World War era from 1945 to 2000.

courses.title: History Orthodox Christianity
courses.description: A chronological and topical introduction to the history of the Orthodox Church, from the beginning to the present. Emphasis is on the political circumstances leading to the separation of various churches, and the main aspects of Orthodox Christian life throughout history.

courses.title: History Research Seminar: Europe
courses.description: Through rotating in content, this seminar has two distinct goals: introduce the historiography of a specific topic and produce a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

courses.title: Racial Theories in Europe and the US
courses.description: Introduces history of racial ideas and images from ancient to modern period.

courses.title: History of Science and Religion
courses.description: Surveys the interaction between the religious and scientific communities in the West from the time of the early church to the present.

courses.title: Introduction, History of Science: Origins to Newton
courses.description: Introduces the emergence of scientific thought from its mythopoeic beginnings to the time of Newton. Focuses on the interrelationships among science, philosophy, and religion in Greece, Islam, and the Latin West. Emphasizes Copernicus, Kepler, Galileo, Descartes, and Newton.

courses.title: Introduction, History of Science: Renaissance to the Present
courses.description: General survey of the major issues in physical and biological science from the time of Galileo to the present. Emphasizes the impact of scientific development on society, culture, and thought.

courses.title: The Scientific Revolution
courses.description: Emergence of modern science from Copernicus to Newton exploring the notions of empiricism, experiment, mechanism, materialism, and the historical concepts of continuity, change, revolution, and progress.

courses.title: The Nuclear Age
courses.description: History of the changing perception of the political and social significance of science since the discovery of nuclear fission.

courses.title: Evolution of Infectious Diseases
courses.description: Emergence of new infectious diseases in a historical and cultural context. Emphasizes the history of well-documented infectious diseases such as leprosy, bubonic plague, cholera, smallpox, yellow fever, tuberculosis, influenza, polio, venereal disease, and AIDS, as well as the more recent Ebola viral-type outbreaks.

courses.title: The History of Modern Biological Thought
courses.description: Selected areas of modern biological thought after 1800. Topics include Darwin, genetics, the Evolutionary Synthesis, molecular biology and sociobiology. (H) (WR)

courses.title: History and Public Policy
courses.description: Examines the role of historical analysis and argument in the policy-making process. Introduces the ways in which decision-makers use and misuse history, and considers what it means to take history into account in public policy. Uses specific contemporary policy problems to illustrate the challenges of using history effectively.

courses.title: Special Topics in History
courses.description: Special topics in history.

courses.title: History Practicum
courses.description: Learn the elements of the professional study of history: the critical reading of sources (primary and secondary); research skills; and a variety of historical methodologies.

courses.title: History of Evolutionary Thought from the Enlightenment to the Present
courses.description: Advanced history of science examines the history of evolutionary thought from the Enlightenment to the present. Emphasizes the specific development of Darwinian evolutionary theory and the lives of key theorists such as Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace. Considers sociopolitical and national contexts.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: Individual study in history. (WR)

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in History
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: History Research Seminar
courses.description: Through rotating in content, this seminar has two distinct goals: introduce the historiography of a specific topic and produce a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

courses.title: Internship in the Practice of History
courses.description: Gives history majors practical experience in history-related institutions and organizations, such as archives, historical societies, museums and university presses.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.description: Required for potential award of high or highest honors. Directed research leading to the submission of an interpretive and analytical, rather than merely narrative, essay of approximately 40 pages in length. The paper may be based on research into a particular topic for which there is accessible source materials or it may involve a thorough critical assessment of a significant historical controversy or historiographical issue. Topics must be approved by the department honors coordinator. Registration for two semesters' work is required in order to allow adequate attention to the project. (WR)

courses.title: History Honors Workshop
courses.description: Assists with all phases of the senior thesis, including project design, research, writing, and oral presentation. Students complete assignments that build toward a draft of a preliminary chapter or the introduction. The workshop provides a collaborative environment in which to pursue individual thesis projects.

courses.title: Perspectives on Science and Mathematics
courses.description: Explores the different ways that scientists and mathematicians since the 17th century have explained the workings of the natural world.

courses.title: Honors Seminar
courses.description: Special topics restricted to those in the university-wide Honors Program. (WR)

courses.title: Introduction to Latin American History
courses.description: Introduces Latin American civilization, from the Conquest to the present, emphasizing select topics in social, political and cultural history. (H and N)

courses.title: Emergence of Latin American Nations
courses.description: The last phase of the colonial regime, movement for independence, and problems of nation-building to the end of the 19th century.

courses.title: Colonial Latin America
courses.description: Surveys the formation of Spanish and Portuguese imperial systems and colonial societies in America in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries.

courses.title: Contemporary Latin America
courses.description: Contemporary challenges to traditional structures; revolution and evolution.

courses.title: Introduction to Caribbean History
courses.description: The main issues and debates in Caribbean history from the time of Columbus to the mid-20th century.

courses.title: Race, Religion, and Revolution in the Black Caribbean
courses.description: Explores the history of Jamaica, Haiti, the Dominican Republic and the Miskito Coast of Nicaragua. Explains the emergence of colonial and neo-colonial political systems, the concept of race in relationship to slavery and global capitalism as well as the role of religion in revolutionary actions.

courses.title: Revolution in the Americas
courses.description: Historical analysis of the armed and unarmed revolutionary movements of 20th century Latin America, from Mexico to Chile.

courses.title: Special Topics in Latin American History
courses.description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of Latin America.

courses.title: Modern Mexico
courses.description: Aftermath of independence and war with US, the Reform and Maximillian, Porfiriato, Mexican Revolution and contemporary trends.

courses.title: Caribbean History to 1800
courses.description: Social, economic and political history of the West Indies and the Circum-Caribbean region to 1800, with particular emphasis on slave society.

courses.title: The Caribbean, Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries
courses.description: Social history of the modern Caribbean: slave emancipation and decolonization; race relations and black consciousness; labor, culture, and economic change.

courses.title: France in the Caribbean
courses.description: Making of the modern Francophone Caribbean. Introduce a range of political, economic, and cultural phenomena from buccaneering and voodoo to tourism and transnational identity. Emphasizes slave plantation society, the Haitian Revolution, and the black consciousness movements of the 20th century.

courses.title: The Conquest of Amazonia
courses.description: Historical analysis of the Amazon. Need no previous knowledge of Latin American history; for those interested in the current issues confronting the region.

courses.title: Brazil after 1750
courses.description: Late and colonial reform; independence and origins and achievements of Brazilian monarchy; modernization and neo-colonialism; slavery, the military, and emergence of oligarchical republic; legacy of dictatorship and populism.

courses.title: Science and Technology in Latin American, 1492-Present
courses.description: Introduces the diffusion, acculturation and adaption of scientific ideas, practices and technology by exploring concepts within Latin America.

courses.title: History Research Seminar: Latin America
courses.description: Through rotating in content, this seminar has two distinct goals: introduce the historiography of a specific topic and produce a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

courses.title: Introduction to the Medieval World
courses.description: Chronological and topical introduction to history of the medieval millennium (400-1400).

courses.title: Special Topics in Medieval and Early Modern Studies
courses.description: Advanced study in medieval and early modern studies.

courses.title: The World in the Twentieth Century
courses.description: Surveys major developments in the history of the twentieth century, focusing on the increasing world interconnections and interdependency. Themes include imperialism, nationalism and decolonization, the two world wars and the interwar period, the Cold War, new social movements and globalization and the international economy.

courses.title: The World Since 1945
courses.description: Overview of the contemporary world while trying to promote an awareness of the striking diversity of views that characterize and shape that world. Covers major issues in the post 1945 world, the Cold War, colonialism, and decolonization.

courses.title: Africans in World History
courses.description: Critically examines the history of Africans outside Africa; emphasizes the Atlantic world and the Americas and to connections forged between peoples of African descent and broader movements in world history. Themes include slavery and anti-slavery, diaspora formation, the history of ideas, revolution, decolonization and civil rights struggles.

courses.title: History of Human Rights
courses.description: Explores the global history of human rights, looking at the bases of those rights, including traditions, practices and international declarations and their evolution over time. At the end of the semester, groups present case reports that apply human rights principles to a variety of historical moments.

courses.title: History of Christianity 1
courses.description: Surveys the history of Christianity, c. 100 to c. 1300, from its status as a persecuted minority religion of the Roman Empire to its position of dominance in the civilizations of medieval Europe and Byzantium.

courses.title: History of Christianity 2
courses.description: Developments in the history of Christianity from the 14th to the 18th centuries. Topics include the crises of the 14th century (impact of the Black Death, Avignon papacy and schism), conciliarism, the Reformation movements, expansion of Christianity abroad and the impact of the Enlightenment on faith.

courses.title: The Vietnam War
courses.description: Examination of the origins, course, and consequences of the conflict in Vietnam, from American and various Vietnamese perspectives, and including the roles of other participants, such as the French, Chinese, and Soviets.

courses.title: The United States and the Contemporary World
courses.description: Traces the historical development of issues in contemporary international politics. Case studies may include the international economy, terrorism, change, and conflict in the Middle East, the drug trade, nuclear and biological weapons, climate change, and globalization.

courses.title: Global History of Energy
courses.description: Examines the relationship of human society to energy. Global in size and scope, a large swath of human history on several continents is covered.

courses.title: Special Topics in World History
courses.description: Selected variable topics in world history.

courses.title: Modern Masculinities in Global Perspective
courses.description: Comparative, global and historical approach to the study of masculinity, drawing from a burgeoning interdisciplinary scholarship. Study ranges across the world and examines masculinities in the Americas, Asia and Europe with special attention to case studies such as Iran, the United Kingdom, Japan and the United States.

courses.title: Atlantic Exchanges from Columbus to NATO
courses.description: History of the Atlantic world, demonstrating that oceans have been connective forces that facilitate the exchange of commodities, capital, and culture across vast distances. Topics include the history of the central and northern Atlantic during the age of Imperialism.

courses.title: Empires, Nationalism, and Revolution 1945-1994
courses.description: Adopting a world history approach to post-World War II era, explores how decolonization intersected with the Cold War in Africa, Asia and Latin America.

courses.title: Nations and Nationalism
courses.description: Studies the modern genesis of the nation and the nation-state in the Americas, Europe, Asia, and Africa. Emphasizes the relationship between European Imperialism and colonial and postcolonial nationalisms around the globe.

courses.title: Empires and Imperialism
courses.description: Introduces the history of early modern and modern empires and imperialisms in Europe, Africa, the Americas, and Asia.

courses.title: History Research Seminar: World History
courses.description: Introduces the historiography of a specific topic; requires a substantial research paper based on primary source evidence.

courses.title: Agricultural Honors
courses.description: Various courses offered. (WR)

courses.title: Agricultural Ecology
courses.description: Introduces the study of ecology from an agricultural perspective. Emphasizes ecological principles with examples and applications from agriculture.

courses.title: Exotic Species and Biosecurity Issues
courses.description: Studies US policies and programs affecting agricultural biosecurity as applied to current agricultural and extension and regulatory programs. Emphasizes policies and procedures used to detect and report non-indigenous species. Develop the analytical capabilities to assess the consequences of agricultural biosecurity threats.

courses.title: Consequences of Biological Invasions
courses.description: Non-native species invasions and environmental effects of these invaders. Students will develop analytical capabilities to assess the consequences of biological invasions.

courses.title: Challenges in Plant Resource Protection
courses.description: Applied training in the regulatory aspects of plant protection, using real-world case studies, scenarios and issues.

courses.title: Bugs and People
courses.description: Introduction for lower-division students who want to learn popular information about insects and associated organisms.

courses.title: The Insects
courses.description: Introduces insect biology, insect-organism interaction, and insect association with humans. Features discussion of basic biological principles using insects as examples.

courses.title: Practical Beekeeping
courses.description: Establish colonies of European-derived honey bees and manage them to be healthy and productive. A hybrid approach combines online lectures and in-person field experiences.

courses.title: Insect Research CURE
courses.description: Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) which bridges the divide between the classroom and research laboratory. Become part of a collaborative research team and work with faculty mentors to collect publishable data that address pressing questions in the field of entomology. The specific research project changes each semester.

courses.title: Principles of Entomology
courses.description: Introduces basic principles of insect science, including insect diversity, evolution, morphology, physiology, behavior, and ecology, as well as applications of insect biology.

courses.title: Principles of Entomology Laboratory
courses.description: Provides practical laboratory experience working with insects, dissecting insects and preparing lab reports. Insect collection is required. (B)

courses.title: Life Science
courses.description: Introduces insects and their interactions with humans and the environment.

courses.title: Biology and Identification of Urban Pests
courses.description: Biology, behavior, ID and damage recognition of insect and vertebrate pests.

courses.title: Principles of Urban Pest Management
courses.description: Methods of controlling household, structural and occasional pests with emphasis placed on cockroaches, termites and fleas.

courses.title: Urban Vertebrate Pest Management
courses.description: The biology, ecology, health risks, exclusions and control of vertebrate pests in the urban environment.

courses.title: Insect Behavior
courses.description: Provides a theoretical and empirical overview of insect behavior, ranging from physiology underlying behavior to the evolution of behavioral diversity. Focuses on recent and current research on insect behavior, the diversity of approaches for studying it, and how this knowledge can be applied to solve human challenges.

courses.title: Turf and Ornamental Entomology
courses.description: Biology, identification, and management of arthropods that infect turfgrass and ornamental plants in urban landscape and in nurseries and greenhouses.

courses.title: Introduction to Tropical Entomology
courses.description: Natural history, ecology and behavior of tropical insects in natural and agroecosystems. Designed for students without previous experience in tropics.

courses.title: Tropical Entomology Field Laboratory
courses.description: A 10-day trip to a tropical country to study the insect faunas of natural and agroecosystems. Each student is assigned a field project.

courses.title: Spider Biology
courses.description: Introduces the biology of spiders and their relatives, with an emphasis on their ecology, behavior, and evolution. Learn to identify the members of approximately 20 common spider families as well as several common Florida species.

courses.title: Spider Biology Lab
courses.description: Provides practical experience working with spiders, including field collection techniques, identification and curation of spider specimens, and observing spider behavior. Requires spider collection.

courses.title: Insect Classification
courses.description: Classification of major families of adult insects with emphasis on their identification, habitat and niche. A properly curated collection is required. (B)

courses.title: Insect Ecology
courses.description: This course is an introduction to ecological concepts with emphasis on insects. The relationships of insects with their biotic and physical environments, along with the roles of insects in nature, will be emphasized. The basics of ecological research will be covered.

courses.title: Insect Ecology Lab
courses.description: Introduces ecological methods and analysis with an emphasis on insects. Emphasizes methods to explore relationships of insects with their biotic and physical environments, along with the roles of insects in nature. Also covers the basics of ecological research.

courses.title: Ecology of Vector-Borne Disease
courses.description: Introduces critical components of vector-borne disease systems and basic concepts inherent to disease ecology. Focuses on vector-borne diseases of humans and wildlife and how aspects of the environment and host/vector biology influence disease transmission. Topics include epidemiology, transmission models, and emerging diseases.

courses.title: Ecology and Conservation of Pollinators
courses.description: Examines interactions between animals and the plants that they pollinate, current threats to pollinator populations, and the conservation of pollinators worldwide; explore these topics through readings, discussion, and a field research project.

courses.title: Insects and Wildlife
courses.description: Introduces insects and other arthropods and their relationships with wild vertebrate animals.

courses.title: Termite Biology and Control
courses.description: Taxonomy, identification, behavior, ecology, and methods of control for the economically important termites in the New World.

courses.title: Pesticide Application
courses.description: Practical work experience in integrated pest management techniques, including identification, inspection, exclusion, proper application of pesticides, and IPM program evaluation in urban environments.

courses.title: Behavioral Ecology and Systematics
courses.description: Introduces behavioral ecology and systematics of insects. (B)

courses.title: Social Insects
courses.description: Overview of social insect biology in the context of comparative social evolution. Topics include the diversity of social behaviors in insects, evolutionary origins of sociality, kin recognition, caste systems, communication in social groups, and impacts of social insects.

courses.title: Honey Bee Biology
courses.description: Provides an in-depth look into the fascinating world of honey bee biology. Explore topics including honey bee sociality, taxonomy, biogeography, behavior, anatomy, physiology, reproduction, nutrition and genetics. Additionally, these topics will be discussed via the paradigm of the honey bee superorganism.

courses.title: Beekeeping I
courses.description: Examines the biology of honey bees and the craft of apiculture by exploring the life cycle of honey bees, biogeography, and evolution of beekeeping. Discusses equipment, techniques, management practices, pollination ecology, economic practices, and current issues within beekeeping.

courses.title: Beekeeping II
courses.description: Provide more depth on topics introduced in ENY 4573, including beekeeping styles, colony stressors, and yearly management. Also explores issues affecting the beekeeping industry including integrated pest management, pests/diseases, African bees, commercial pollination, queen production, bee removals, and pesticides.

courses.title: Mosquito Identification
courses.description: Intensive, hands-on training on morphological features and the identification of adult and larval mosquito species that occur in North America.

courses.title: Mosquito Biology
courses.description: This modular course covers six critical areas of mosquito biology; classification, natural history and ecology, physiology, population dynamics, mosquito-borne diseases and control of mosquitoes. Students will understand the fundamental processes governing mosquitoes and mosquito-borne diseases.

courses.title: Medical and Veterinary Entomology
courses.description: Presents the major insect, mite, and tick vectors of disease to humans and animals. Topics includes arthropod-transmitted diseases, the interaction between pathogens and the arthropod vector, and the mechanical damage that a parasite inflicts on its host.

courses.title: Medical and Veterinary Entomology Laboratory
courses.description: Identifying mosquitoes, ticks, lice, fleas and other disease vectors. Insect collection required. (B)

courses.title: Forensic Entomology
courses.description: Role of arthropods in decomposition, in criminal and civil investigations, and the increasing importance of science on society. Material and discussions deal with death and some may consider course images and concepts disturbing.

courses.title: Molecular Biology of Insects and Nematodes
courses.description: Provides foundation knowledge of molecular biology, with emphasis on scientific discoveries from insects and nematodes. Presents information on the current innovations and trends of molecular technologies (e.g. high throughput sequencing, different types of omics, genome editing by CRISPR).

courses.title: Supervised Extension Experience in Entomology and Nematology
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in entomology and nematology under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.title: Problems in Entomology
courses.description: Problems in any field of specialization in entomology and nematology.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Entomology
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in entomology under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Entomology
courses.description: Independent research in entomology leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Special Topics in Entomology and Nematology
courses.description: Special topics in Entomology and Nematology.

courses.title: Practical Work Experience in Entomology and Nematology
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic work experience in entomology or nematology under the supervision of a faculty member and workplace supervisor. Projects vary depending on program requirements.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Pest Management
courses.description: Fundamentals of Pest Management

courses.title: Insect Pest and Vector Management
courses.description: Covers the principles and practices used in pest and vector management, and also emphasizes the arthropod pests affecting crop and ornamental plants, humans and livestock.

courses.title: Landscape Integrated Pest Management: Ornamentals and Turf
courses.description: Landscape pest pressure is influenced by many factors. The development of sound integrated pest management plans for landscapes focuses on identification of abiotic factors, weeds, insects, mites, pathogens and nematodes that occur on Florida landscape ornamentals, turfgrass and palms.

courses.title: Principles of Nematology
courses.description: Introduces nematology, including studies of morphology, life histories, and control of the major nematode parasites of plants. Also includes studies of the bionomics of certain soil nematodes and nematode parasites of vertebrates and arthropods.

courses.title: Problems in Nematology
courses.description: Selected problems for study, research, or discussion in nematology.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Nematology
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in nematology under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Nematology
courses.description: Independent research in nematology leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Introduction to Communication Studies
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Introduces various theoretical perspectives for understanding human communication. (S)

courses.title: Organizational Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Explores the processes, practices, and difficulties of communication among large groups engaged principally in the work environment. Examines organizational structures, patterns of communication, task and social roles, extrinsic influences, and methods of producing intrinsic motivation and innovation.

courses.title: Global and Cultural Issues in Health Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Explores the complex associations among communication and the many contexts, issues, and relationships surrounding health and well-being in the world. Investigates cultural, historical, social, and ethical meanings of health and illness. Considers issues in global health, culture, and communication in health care initiatives.

courses.title: Biology of Human Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Focuses on the interaction between the body and communication behavior. Examines how physiology affects communication, and how communication affects physiology.

courses.title: Interpersonal Conflict Management
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Introduces fundamental communication skills, principles, theories and research relevant to effective conflict management in a variety of interpersonal contexts and relationships.

courses.title: Conflict Management and Negotiation in the Professions
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Introduces fundamental concepts and skills relevant to effective communication in business and professional conflicts. Topics include conflict management, ADR, and interpersonal, organizational, community and international negotiation. Emphasizes helping students to understand and improve the conflict management and negotiation skills required in their professional careers.

courses.title: Resilience & Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Focuses on the role of communication in human resilience, with emphasis given to social, interpersonal, and intrapersonal processes and outcomes relevant to the construction of resilience and resilience narratives.

courses.title: Internship in Comm Studies
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: A variable web-based course designed to complement a student's internship experience through guided reflection, critical analysis, synthesis, and discussion.

courses.title: Family Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Provides students with an understanding of how communication functions to develop, maintain, enrich, or limit family relationships.

courses.title: Health Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Surveys theory, research, and practice of communication in the contexts of healthcare and health promotion.

courses.title: Language & Social Interaction
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Explores the role of language in social interaction, covering theories and methods investigating language in social interaction, ways language is used to construct social identity, and issues concerning language and culture. Classroom activities and homework involve how (non)verbal conduct is enacted and understood in social situations.

courses.title: Language and Power
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Explores the role of language in articulating, maintaining, and subverting power relations in society. Drawing from Communication Studies and Applied Linguistics, the course provides the tools to uncover, describe, and critically analyze the various strategic biases in language that create and reinforce power asymmetries in society.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Communication Studies
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Communication Studies. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Communication Studies.

courses.title: Special Topics in Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Seminar study of theory and research in a specific area of communication.

courses.title: Introduction to Library and Internet Research
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Learn how to conduct solid and reliable library research. Critical thinking skills are used to find, evaluate and use relevant scholarly resources in a variety of disciplines. This dynamic, hands-on course emphasizes creative thinking and media production tools while exploring the social responsibilities of using digital age information.

courses.title: Introduction to Interpersonal Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: The study of how two people interact with one another and how factors such as listening skills, backgrounds, experiences, and perspectives influence that communication.

courses.title: Listening
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Theory and practice in responsible, participatory listening. Also includes principles of listening for literal comprehension and critical evaluation of ideas in response to various spoken and nonverbal messages.

courses.title: Intercollegiate Forensics
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Participation in intercollegiate debate and individual speaking.

courses.title: Introduction to Public Speaking
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Theory and practice presenting public speeches, determining communication purpose(s) and adapting to organization, evidence, language and other message characteristics for designated audiences.

courses.title: Nonverbal Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Surveys theory and research in nonverbal communication including eye behavior, facial expressions, gestures and vocal cues.

courses.title: Argumentation
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Implementation of principles and methods advocating factual claims and policy proposals. Also discusses propositional analysis, evidence as demonstration, effecting reasoning processes to become experimental for listeners and ethics in controversy.

courses.title: Advanced Public Speaking
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Studies principles and methods of selected forms of public speaking for various purposes, audiences and contexts.

courses.title: Advanced Interpersonal Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Analysis of interpersonal communication in various professional and social settings shown through case studies, role plays and discussion that all illustrate how emotions and social expectations shape communication.

courses.title: Small Group Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Communication in small groups with emphasis in practical applications, skill development and current research and theory.

courses.title: Patterns of Intercultural Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Explores practices and difficulties of communication between and among people of contrasting cultures. Includes investigation of theory and research by which intercultural communication problems can be mitigated. (N and S) (WR)

courses.title: Directed Individual Study in Communication Studies
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Directed individual study in communication studies designed for the advanced student who wants to pursue an in-depth area of study not provided in regularly offered courses. Directed individual study could involve independent readings or individual projects under faculty guidance.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Speech Communication
courses.department: William & Grace Dial Center for Speech and Communication Studies
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in speech communication. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application in speech communication.

courses.title: Business and You: Warrington Welcome
courses.description: Introduces students to the college of business by focusing on various resources and strategies for success, including personal and professional development opportunities that enhance career preparedness.

courses.title: Exploring Careers in Business
courses.description: Overview of the various career paths available through the business majors available at UF; focuses on exploration of the sub-sectors within business and will help students with career discernment.

courses.title: Career Accelerator
courses.description: Prepares students to secure internships and full-time jobs through emphasis on career readiness competencies. Covers assessing career goals, crafting effective resumes, excelling in interviews, and mastering networking. Learn to identify and put into practice various skills through group work with fellow classmates. Also emphasizes self-reflection, exploration, and teamwork, enabling students to make informed decisions about their future career paths.

courses.title: Special Projects
courses.description: Projects related to business as approved by the college.

courses.title: Leading Organizations
courses.description: Provides a Strategic Foundation for Leadership Practice in a Variety of Professions. Increases the Capacity to Lead With and Without Authority, Across Boundaries, and From Any Political or Organizational Position.

courses.title: Effective Career Management in Business
courses.description: Systematically designed course based on the cognitive information processing theory for career problem solving and decision-making. Delivered via modularized multimedia instructional materials. The course is designed to inform students about career planning and management interventions and to accommodate students at different levels of decidedness about their career aspirations.

courses.title: Professional Writing in Business
courses.description: Teaches business students fundamental written communication skills focusing on those areas central to professional writing in business. (C) (WR)

courses.title: Professional Speaking in Business
courses.description: Teaches fundamental oral communication skills necessary for succeeding in a business setting including presentations and speeches, interpersonal skills and interviewing.

courses.title: Writing and Speaking in Business
courses.description: Online content teaches business students the fundamentals of both written and spoken communication, enabling them to express their ideas effectively and efficiently and to prepare them for the demands of the business workspace. (C) (WR)

courses.title: International Business
courses.description: Exposes the business environments (culture, politics, laws and economics) encountered in other parts of the world; to the tools and skills necessary to analyze the potential of other countries as locations for production, distribution and marketing; to how managing and integrating international operations in many parts of the world differs from the domestic focus of many business courses; and to the broad perspective required of successful managers working in international business.

courses.title: Business Case Analysis
courses.description: Introduces case analysis and prepares students for national and international case competitions.

courses.title: Special Topics in Business Communication
courses.description: Through rotating special topics and content, this course has two distinct goals: to develop sophisticated, adaptable communication skills by tailoring communication to different audiences and to build and maintain strong professional relationships through communication.

courses.title: Business Externship: Micro-Consulting
courses.description: Students in this course apply relevant business skills and knowledge to help a company complete a specified and detailed project. Acting as consultants to the company, students are put in project or consulting teams and work together on the project while communicating with, and getting guidance by, a company contact. While applying information obtained in other business courses, students taking this course will focus on professional development skills and other important business skills.

courses.title: Leadership Launch
courses.description: Capstone course provides a foundation in effective leadership practice grounded in theory and research. Students build upon leadership knowledge and experiences, explore key attributes and behaviors, and develop competencies aligned with organizational and business success.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: Reading and/or research in business administration.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.description: Reading and research in business administration.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Business
courses.description: Provides an opportunity for firsthand, supervised research in business. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application in business.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Variable content provides an opportunity for in-depth study of topics not offered in other courses and topics of special current significance.

courses.title: Professional Development Module
courses.description: Presents techniques for outstanding presentation and public speaking skills. Includes a significant service learning component whereby students apply presentation techniques developed in the classroom via business-oriented instruction in the K-12 school system.

courses.title: Internship in Business Administration
courses.description: Applied work in business administration that requires several papers and reports.

courses.title: International Studies in Business
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.description: A thesis is required for the awarding of the magna cum laude or summa cum laude designation. To qualify for the thesis option, students will normally have completed 90 semester credits of coursework (exceptions may be made by the honors coordinator of the student's major department) and must have at least the 3.6 grade point average required for magna cum laude designation at the time they enroll. The thesis will be reviewed by at least one faculty member chosen by the honors coordinator from the student's major department.

courses.title: Human Physiology
courses.description: Functioning of human tissues, organs and organ systems, emphasizing the physical, chemical and mechanistic bases of normal physiology and the integrated function of the human body. Also introduces pathophysiological changes associated with human diseases.

courses.title: Issues and Concepts in Gerontology
courses.description: Multidisciplinary overview of the field of aging covers biomedical and health issues, psychosocial factors, applied aspects, and policy issues.

courses.title: US Health Care System
courses.description: Overview of organization, delivery, and financing of health services in the US. Topics include health professionals, health care facilities, financing of health services, managed care, and current health policy issues.

courses.title: Health Policy
courses.description: Engage in thinking critically about both the evolution of US Health Policy and the forces that influence current health policy. Develop strategies for conducting policy analyses and participation in the political process.

courses.title: Health Informatics & Emerging Healthcare Technologies
courses.description: Provides a fundamental understanding health informatics, healthcare information systems, and emerging healthcare technologies, starting with the core informatics competencies and the foundation of knowledge model.

courses.title: Healthcare Operations Management, Strategy, and Quality
courses.description: Provides a working knowledge of healthcare operations management, and with an understanding of the importance of effective and efficient delivery of healthcare services within the healthcare industry, and to society overall. Learn to develop, evaluate, and apply management systems, project management tools, supply chain management, operations performance metrics, and quality improvement strategies using both quantitative and qualitative skill.

courses.title: Health Economics
courses.description: Explores the economic forces that shape our health to reveal the unexpected consequences of everyday choices. Topics include healthcare demand and supply, health insurance, information economics, innovation, policy analysis, and behavioral economics. Through practical applications, students conduct vital economic analyses that can inform healthcare decision making, assess policies, and addressing inequities.

courses.title: Introduction to Health Professions
courses.description: Lecture, discussion and group assignments provide the opportunity to learn about different disciplines making up a health care team and their role in both the science and practice of health care.

courses.title: Research Methods and Issues in Health Science
courses.description: Emphasizes four aspects of research: understanding research principles, evaluating journal articles, applying research findings to clinical settings, and designing programmatic evaluation projects.

courses.title: Survey of Diseases and Disability
courses.description: Overview of medical and psychosocial aspects of chronic diseases and disability.

courses.title: Therapeutic Communication Skills with Patients, Families and the Health Care Team
