courses.description: Learn appropriate verbal and nonverbal behavior to be used with patients, families, and the health care team through lecture, discussion, and role play in large and small groups.

courses.title: Clinical Observation / Health Care Volunteer Work
courses.description: Learn about a specific health care field or gain knowledge about specific patient or client populations through direct observation and/or hands-on assistance.

courses.title: Professional Development for the Health Sciences
courses.description: Fosters the professional development needed to transition into the health and public health professions. Enrichment activities include diversity training, presentation skills training, career planning, and developing an online portfolio.

courses.title: Wearable Technology, Robotics, and Artificial Intelligence for Health
courses.description: Explore wearable technology, robotics, and Artificial Intelligence (AI) integration in health. Students will gain an in-depth understanding of how these technological advancements are revolutionizing health, improving patient care, and enabling health professionals to deliver more efficient and effective services. Students will learn through lectures, hands-on exercises, field trips, and discussions.

courses.title: Health Care Leadership: Skills and Styles
courses.description: Behavioral styles that contribute to leadership effectiveness. Studies specific styles for their contributions to motivating people and overall leadership effectiveness in health care.

courses.title: Disinformation and Misinformation in Healthcare
courses.description: Traces the interplay of misinformation and disinformation and the impact on personal and public health in the United States. Imparts understanding of the real world impact of misinformation on health outcomes and what can be done about it. Knowledge gained can be used to help understand how people are misinformed and lay the groundwork for being better informed future practitioners. Provides strategies to engage with people those influenced by misinformation or disinformation.

courses.title: Musculoskeletal Assessment in Rehabilitation
courses.description: This undergraduate course explores musculoskeletal assessment techniques and their application in rehabilitation. Designed to equip students with fundamental skills, knowledge, and practical experience, the course delves into the assessment of the skeletal system, muscular system, and their interplay in the context of physical therapy and occupational therapy. Through a combination of lectures, demonstrations, and case studies, students will learn to perform accurate musculoskeletal assessments.

courses.title: Medical Pharmacology in Clinical Care
courses.description: Overview of the fundamental principles of pharmacology, including drug classifications, mechanisms of action, and their impact on the human body. Explore the history of pharmacology, drug development, and the ethical considerations surrounding drug use and regulation.

courses.title: Survey of Diseases and Disabilities 2
courses.description: Overview of medical and psychosocial aspects of chronic diseases, including issues of disability management. This required course, combined with HSC 3502, covers all of the major disabling conditions.

courses.title: Psychiatric Disorders
courses.description: Study of major psychiatric syndromes and their management. The continuum of disorders from health to psychopathology.

courses.title: Clinical Diagnosis and Decision Making
courses.description: Facilitates the development of critical thinking and problem-solving skills in healthcare. A problem-based learning approach is used in which students are provided with carefully selected clinical, legislative, ethical, and professional problems and are provided guidance in problem solution.

courses.title: Ethical and Legal Issues in the Health Professions
courses.description: Overview of ethical and legal issues in the health professions, including contemporary ethical issues in disease management.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: Supervised program of study to investigate problems significant to health professions.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics in health science. Refer to the department for specific topic information. Can be repeated with change in content for up to 12 credits.

courses.title: Honors Seminar in the Health Professions
courses.description: Philosophy and implementation of scientific work, including an introduction to faculty research. Provides the opportunity to explore and discuss potential honors thesis topics.

courses.title: Public Health and Health Professions Senior Honors Thesis
courses.description: Special project leading to the distinction of magna or summa cum laude at graduation. The project can be any creative work that focuses on a specific topic or issue in the health professions. The student develops an outline of the special project prior to project initiation and produces a final paper at project completion. The paper must be approved by the program and dean's office for the student to graduate magna or summa cum laude.

courses.title: Pathophysiology
courses.description: Basic understanding of pathophysiology as a change from normal physiological functioning of the various systems of the human body.

courses.title: The Nervous System and Disorders
courses.description: Comprehensive foundation in neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, and neuropathology.

courses.title: Introduction to Public Health
courses.description: Overview of public health as a multifaceted field. Includes discussion of contemporary public health challenges with input from discipline experts.

courses.title: Critical Issues in Public Health
courses.description: Learn how to analyze, compare, and contrast the most current complex public health issues in society. Comprehend and discuss the influence of personal bias, scientific evidence, and societal trends on a variety of public health issues.

courses.title: Public Health Concepts
courses.description: Introduces the basic tenets, applications, and foci of public health, including integrating public health with other health professions.

courses.title: Special Topics in Public Health
courses.description: Exploration of a general or a specific area of public health.

courses.title: Service Learning Practicum
courses.description: Covers development of the role of a public health and human services provider in an agency setting.

courses.title: Rehabilitation Aspects of Substance Abuse
courses.description: Rehabilitation counseling implications of alcohol and drug use in society and the work place. Emphasis on detection, treatment, and follow-up services for individuals in the rehabilitation process.

courses.title: Honors Seminar in Pharmaceutical Research: In Search of Magic Bullets
courses.description: Overview of the issues associated with pharmaceutical research: drug discovery process, clinical research, drug tragedies, government laws and regulations, pharmaceutical care and drug efficacy versus risk. In addition, specific drug research by pharmacy faculty is presented and discussed. (WR)

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Pharmaceutical Outcomes and Policy
courses.description: Specific research projects in pharmacy are completed during a semester under the supervision of a pharmacy faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Pharmacodynamics
courses.description: Specific research projects in pharmacy are completed during a semester under the supervision of a pharmacy faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Pharmaceutics
courses.description: Specific research projects in pharmacy are completed during a semester under the supervision of a pharmacy faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Medicinal Chemistry
courses.description: Specific research projects in pharmacy are completed during a semester under the supervision of a pharmacy faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Pharmacotherapy and Translational Research
courses.description: Specific research projects in pharmacy are completed during a semester under the supervision of a pharmacy faculty member.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Pharmacy
courses.description: Undergraduates work on a project or complete a term paper under the supervision of a pharmacy faculty member.

courses.title: Medications and Health
courses.description: Provides a general overview of various pharmacy topics and concepts, including the use of medications, prescription, non-prescription, vitamins, and dietary supplements, in treating selected diseases and conditions. Also included is a history of pharmacy, health and wellness, and current and emerging fields within pharmacy. In addition, the role of pharmacists along with other health care team members to ensure proper use of medications, will be emphasized.

courses.title: Fostering Innovation through Leadership
courses.description: By studying key leadership theories and models students will develop the basic skills and knowledge necessary to move an innovation from creation to implementation. Using specifically designed experiences, students will be able to think critically about leadership's direct application to innovation and change.

courses.title: Artificial Intelligence Fundamentals
courses.description: Overview of Artificial Intelligence (AI), approaching the concept from its origins to expectations for the future; focuses on various AI technologies, how to build Machine Learning models, and how to apply AI tools to solve real world problems. Some concepts are types of AI and Machine Learning, Hacking and the IoT, AI today and its outlook for the future.

courses.title: Engineering Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Engineering Entrepreneurship introduces engineering students to the concepts and practices of technological entrepreneurial thinking and entrepreneurship. Using lectures, case studies, business plans and student presentations, the course teaches life skills in entrepreneurial thought and action that students can utilize when starting technology companies or executing research and development projects in large companies.

courses.title: Principles of Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Practical, hands-on understanding of the stages of entrepreneurial process. Focus on the decision-making process within a start-up company.

courses.title: The Venture Accelerator
courses.description: A team-based, experiential program focused on the start-up process; includes lectures, readings, discussions, workshops, and a team-based project. As deliverables, each team must deliver weekly lessons-learned presentations, complete business canvas updates, and prepare a final presentation.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Experiential learning in a variety of work locations. Permission of program director required. Supervision by a faculty member or delegated authority, daily journal and a post-internship report are required.

courses.title: Innovation Mindset
courses.description: Provides incoming Innovation Academy students strategies for success as 21st century college students and innovators and equips students with the tools to become independent thinkers and learners.

courses.title: Innovation in Action
courses.description: Focuses on execution of creative problem-solving strategies through completion of a design sprint, resulting in an innovative project. Students refine design thinking skills developed in IDS 1940, research and prototype a concept, test and refine the prototype, and complete and present the final project at the “Catalyst” showcase.

courses.title: Creativity & Design Thinking for Innovation
courses.description: Focuses on building creative confidence through the design thinking process. Students explore and develop their own creative processes, experience collaborative creative problem solving in multidisciplinary teams, and practice prototyping innovative solutions to problems through sustainable prototyping, laser cutting, 3-D modeling/printing, and Arduino.

courses.title: Innovation Academy Internship
courses.description: Experiential learning enables participation in an innovative internship that supplements the degree program. Supervised by a faculty member or designated authority, seven online assignments are required for successful completion.

courses.title: Innovation Academy Senior Project
courses.description: Using lectures, labs and a multidisciplinary team-based project approach, build life skills in creativity and innovation, entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial thinking. Synthesize and demonstrate leadership and ethics through design and development of a team project.

courses.title: Ethics, Data, and Technology
courses.description: Addresses ethical issues related to data science, algorithmic decision-making, and artificial intelligence. Pairs theoretical discussions of ethics, economics, and policy-making with concrete issues in emerging technologies.

courses.title: Ethics and Innovation
courses.description: Grounding in ethical theory and moral reasoning with a focus on changes at both organizational and societal levels, including, for instance, technological innovations, new business practices and legal changes. Examines the rights and responsibilities of those making such changes as well as the conditions that facilitate responsible decision making. (H, WR4)

courses.title: Beginning Turkish 1
courses.description: This course and its sequel, TUR 1131, constitute the introductory sequence in Turkish.

courses.title: Beginning Turkish 2
courses.description: Second semester of the introductory sequence in Turkish.

courses.title: Intensive Beginning Turkish
courses.description: An intensive introduction to Turkish, using the proficiency method. This course is equivalent to, and substitute for, the UF's first-year Turkish sequence (TUR 1130 / TUR 1131).

courses.title: Intermediate Turkish 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of speaking, reading, writing and listening comprehension skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Turkish 2
courses.description: Improves speaking, reading, writing and listening skills by building upon language principles introduced in TUR 2220.

courses.title: Intensive Intermediate Turkish
courses.description: Immersive intermediate study of Turkish. Equivalent to, and substitute for, the second-year sequence of TUR 2220 / TUR 2221. Classes meet daily; see the weekly schedule of topics.

courses.title: Life in the Universe
courses.description: The origin of life on Earth and the possibility of life elsewhere. A multidisciplinary approach is followed. Conditions for life to form and the likelihood that such conditions may exist elsewhere in the universe are discussed. Also considered are schemes proposed for the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI). (P)

courses.title: Theory and Practice in the Biological Sciences
courses.description: Presents the scientific method in its many formulations from historical, philosophical, and sociological perspectives. Explores generation and presentation of data, formulation of hypotheses, and theories and dissemination of results. Also examines the ethical implication of biological research.

courses.title: Paleontology
courses.description: Investigation of the history of life on earth, including aspects of invertebrate and vertebrate paleontology, micropaleontology and paleobotany.

courses.title: Genetics
courses.description: Fundamental properties of inheritance in eukaryotic organisms emphasizing examples in humans. Develops basic concepts for the nature, organization, transmission, expression, recombination, and function of genetic materials, and principles derived for genetically characterizing populations.

courses.title: Cellular and Systems Physiology
courses.description: How cells, organs, and higher level systems are integrated and coordinated in the functions of humans and other animals. Emphasizes the use of model organisms, mathematical models, and the physical sciences to understand the mechanistic basis of normal physiology and dysfunction.

courses.title: General Ecology
courses.description: Ecological processes and organization in terrestrial and aquatic habitats. Laboratory and field exercises emphasize techniques of ecological analysis.

courses.title: Evolution
courses.description: Processes and mechanisms of evolution, including population genetics, speciation, patterns of evolution and molecular evolution.

courses.title: Comparative Biomechanics
courses.description: Reviews physical principles governing the form and function of organisms.

courses.title: Physiology and Molecular Biology of Animals
courses.description: Processes and mechanisms of maintenance, activity, and integration in animals with emphasis on vertebrates. Laboratory experience in quantitative methods and techniques of physiological investigation.

courses.title: Animal Behavior
courses.description: The causes, origins and evolution of animal behavior emphasizing field observations and experiments on the behavior of a variety of animal groups.

courses.title: Evolutionary Developmental Biology
courses.description: Analysis of embryonic development, underlying genetic mechanisms and how these processes have driven the evolutionary diversification of animal body plans.

courses.title: Functional Vertebrate Anatomy
courses.description: The form and function of chordates accompanied by laboratory work dealing with a selected series of chordates.

courses.title: Invertebrate Biodiversity
courses.description: Comparative biology of invertebrates, emphasizing morphology, evolution, ecology and life history.

courses.title: Vertebrate Biodiversity
courses.description: Comparative biology of vertebrates, emphasizing morphology, evolution, ecology and behavior.

courses.title: Marine Biology
courses.description: Survey of major marine taxa, systematics of local marine fauna and flora, with familiarization of the marine environment. Laboratory emphasizes field work and independent projects.

courses.title: Avian Biology
courses.description: The basic biological characteristics of birds, which, as exceptionally unique flying vertebrates, are confronted with a spectrum of problems in terms of anatomy, physiology, behavior, migration and population ecology.

courses.title: Individual Studies in Zoology
courses.description: Qualified students and the instructor concerned may choose a particular topic or problem for study.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Zoology
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Special Topics in Zoology
courses.description: Lectures, conferences or laboratory sessions covering selected topics of current interest in zoology.

courses.title: Practical Experience in Teaching Zoology
courses.description: Participation in teaching approved Zoology courses with practical experience in instructional procedures, testing and grading, course and laboratory preparation, and laboratory assistance. Cannot be used to satisfy the minimum credit requirement for Zoology majors.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
courses.description: In this course, students will learn the foundations of macroeconomics as the branch of economics concerned with how decision-making, in an environment of scarcity, maps onto the aggregate economy. Students will examine theories and evidence related to the following core set of topics: national income determination, money, monetary and fiscal policy, macroeconomic conditions, international trade and the balance of payments, and economic growth and development.

courses.title: Principles of Microeconomics
courses.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. (S)

courses.title: Economics of Sustainability
courses.description: Examines issues of environmental sustainability from an economic perspective. Discusses economic treatment of renewable and nonrenewable resources, land constraints, and global climate change. Identifies potential policy solutions grounded in economic theory.

courses.title: Intermediate Microeconomics
courses.description: Nature, scope, and purpose of economic analysis. Examines the theory of consumer behavior, production, costs, firm behavior, and the allocation of resources.

courses.title: Intermediate Macroeconomics
courses.description: Theoretical determinants of aggregate employment, income, expenditures and the price level. Keynesian and neoclassical models are analyzed.

courses.title: Economic Analysis of Data
courses.description: Introduces prominent big economic datasets. Presents common practices for identifying inconsistencies and cleaning data. Describes several data basic visualization tools within various software packages. Incorporates hand-on experience with economic data analysis.

courses.title: Public Choice
courses.description: Role of voters, special interests, legislators and the bureaucracy in determining government expenditure, taxation and other economic policies. Economic models of voting and the structure of governments.

courses.title: International Trade
courses.description: Theory of international trade and commercial policy. Current issues in international trade, comparative advantage, scale economics, the economics of tariff and non-tariff barriers. International factor movements and multinational firms. Political economy of trade restrictions, strategic trade policy and trade negotiations.

courses.title: International Macroeconomics
courses.description: Macroeconomic theory of an open economy. Current monetary issues of the world economy. The international monetary system, exchange rate determination, balance of payments adjustment mechanism, international financial institutions and their policies. Macroeconomic policies and national income determination in an open economy.

courses.title: Economics of Competitive Strategy
courses.description: Focuses on identification and analysis of competitive strategies in expanding markets. Draws on strategic management, the economics of technological change and RD investments, and dynamic game theory, to address challenges faced by firms. Examines demand-based network externalities, the dynamics of pricing rivalry, industry evolution, RD strategies entry and exit decisions.

courses.title: Monetary Economics
courses.description: An integrated examination of how banks impact the money supply, monetary policy and financial markets. Topics include: the historical features of money; banking and money supply; goals and tools of monetary policy; and banks as financial intermediaries.

courses.title: Economic Growth
courses.description: Examines global history of economic growth and development. Introduces classical and modern theories of economic growth. Develops mainstream models of exogenous and endogenous growth. Compares insights from these models to real-world data.

courses.title: Game Theory and Applications
courses.description: Introduces modern game theory, including the formal theory of Nash equilibrium and solutions techniques. Applications include strategic barriers of entry; cooperative behavior in oligopoly, auctions and bidding strategies; and durable goods sales.

courses.title: Mathematical Economics
courses.description: Introduces fundamental mathematical tools employed in economic analysis. Covers comparative static analysis, introduces linear algebra, constrained and unconstrained optimization, and dynamic analysis using differential and difference equations. Examines applications from a wide range of subfields in economics, including consumer theory, macroeconomics, economic growth, and environmental economics.

courses.title: Econometrics
courses.description: Introduces concepts and methods used in empirical economic research. Emphasizes practical use of basic econometric techniques to estimate economic relationships and evaluate policy. Covers topics needed to plan and implement empirical projects, and understand potential problems with the empirical analyses of others.

courses.title: Econometrics 2
courses.description: Introduces advanced concepts and methods employed in empirical economic analysis. Focuses on identification of causality using regression techniques. Examines regression discontinuity and difference-in-differences identification strategies.

courses.title: Public Economics
courses.description: Market failures and the role of the government in providing goods and services, like education and infrastructure, in a market economy. The role of the government in the provision of various types of social insurance like health insurance, social security and welfare. The effects of taxes on economic behavior.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: For advanced undergraduate students who need to supplement regular coursework by individual studies under guidance. Counted as a free elective credit only.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Variable content providing an opportunity for the study in-depth of topics not offered in other courses.

courses.title: Empirical Research in Economics Seminar
courses.description: After getting some background in economic empirical methodology, statistics, and statistical software and discussing some representative empirical papers, each economics student develops an empirical model and subjects it to statistical testing, helped by several class presentations.

courses.title: Internship in Economics
courses.description: Applied work in economics. Requires several papers and reports. Counted as a free-elective credit only.

courses.title: International Studies in Economics
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.description: A thesis is required for the awarding of the magna cum laude or summa cum laude designations. To qualify, students will normally have completed 90 semester credits of coursework (exceptions may be made by the honors coordinator of the student's major department) and must have at least the grade point average (3.6) required for the magna cum laude designation at the time they enroll. The thesis will be reviewed by at least one faculty member chosen by the honors coordinator for the student's major department. Counted as a free-elective credit only.

courses.title: Economics of Sports
courses.description: Examines the business of sports using economic theory as a framework for analysis. Topics covered include the economics of sports leagues, labor negotiations and arbitration, pricing decisions, discrimination, corruption in sports, gambling, sports memorabilia and antitrust policy.

courses.title: Labor Economics
courses.description: Determinants of demand for labor and labor supply. Labor market equilibrium and changes in the equilibrium due to changes in unionization, public policies, technology and trade. Study of the effects of skill, job amenities and discrimination on wage differentials.

courses.title: Environmental Economics and Resource Policy
courses.description: Relations between environmental quality, resource utilization, and economic institutions and policy. Examines alternative strategies and policies in solving the problems of environmental quality and resource scarcity.

courses.title: Industrial Organization
courses.description: Examines the structure of markets and the behavior of firms operating in imperfectly competitive markets. Develops models of imperfectly competitive markets and compares the insights and predictions from each. Investigates firms' strategic profit-maximizing decisions regarding prices, product differentiation, market entry and exit, and product promotion.

courses.title: Economics of Education
courses.description: Uses economic concepts to analyze the education system and education policy options. Topics covered include class size, No Child Left Behind legislation, public vs. private schools, and vouchers.

courses.title: Health Care Economics
courses.description: Analysis of health care markets, employing efficiency and equity criteria. Evaluation of current health care policies and their effects on cost, access and quality. Topics covered include the production of and demand for health and medical care; information asymmetrics between patients, doctors, and payers; health insurance coverage; the effects of managed care (including HMOs) on competition, efficiency, and quality; training and practice of physicians; hospitals; prescription drug pricing; government regulations; Medicare and Medicaid; health care reform.

courses.title: Managerial Economics
courses.description: Analysis of the firm's decisions regarding prices, outputs and inputs, advertising, etc. under various market conditions. Reliance is placed upon both theories and applications.

courses.title: Government Regulation of Business
courses.description: The evolution, statutory foundation and methods of governmental regulation. Antitrust regulation of competitive practices.

courses.title: Law and Economics
courses.description: Analyzes the interaction between law and economics, and evolution of legal rules; efficiency of alternative rules on pollution and public goods, enforcement of contracts, deterrence of crime, and protection of consumers; and efficiency versus fairness.

courses.title: Economic Development of Latin America
courses.description: A critical assessment of Latin American political economy and economic development. Topics covered include economic history from the colonial period forward; commodity price cycles and balance of payment fluctuations; import substitution industrialization; international indebtedness; trade liberalization; inflation stabilization policies; poverty eradication difficulties.

courses.title: Economic Development
courses.description: Examines different theories of economic growth and development of low-income and middle-income countries. Covers microeconomic and macroeconomic models relevant to understanding development and analyzing various policy proposals. Analyzes history and empirical evidence of global economic growth and development.

courses.title: Africa in the Global Economy
courses.description: Examines the African continent position globally, looking both at the challenges as well as at the options available to African nations to get a fair and better deal in the global economy. Main topics: international trade and global value chairs; WTO rules and negotiations especially with regard to agriculture; aid to Africa; economic reforms, the World Bank and IMF; the debt crisis; migration and African Diaspora.

courses.title: African Economic Development
courses.description: Deals with the most pressing issues facing Sub-Saharan African countries in their quest for socioeconomic development. Although the focus is on contemporary issues and forthcoming challenges, more or less recent historical facts will be reviewed whenever necessary to shed light on the present. Main topics include economic growth, politics and institutions, international trade, agricultural and industrial development, poverty and inequality, access to basic social services, the environment, and gender issues.

courses.title: Introduction to Biological Engineering
courses.description: Introduces the process of design along with approaches to solving engineering problems, manipulations and presentations of engineering data and applied engineering concepts. (WR)

courses.title: Biology for Engineers
courses.description: Principles and engineering applications of biology. Principles and applications of biochemistry, genetics, microbial systems, animal systems, ecological systems and global systems. (B) (WR)

courses.title: Applications in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Overview of the research and applications of biological engineering, such as bioprocessing, biotechnology, transport processes, biosensors, bioremediation, biological materials and biomedicine.

courses.title: Land and Water Resources Engineering
courses.description: Introduces hydrology, flow through porous media, flood routing, grade control structures and erosion control.

courses.title: Heat and Mass Transfer in Biological Systems
courses.description: Transport phenomena, steady and unsteady-state heat conduction, radiation, free and forced convection, mass transfer, psychometrics and thermodynamics of biological processes.

courses.title: Physical and Rheological Properties of Biological Materials
courses.description: Theory and use of physical and rheological properties of biological materials in agricultural engineering applications.

courses.title: Control Methods in SmartAg Systems
courses.description: Design, analysis, simulation, and programming modern control methods for applications in production agriculture, biological and food engineering, land and water resources. Learn theoretical concepts, application programming, and simulation techniques using classical and modern control approaches, fuzzy logic, neural networks, and other intelligent learning algorithms.

courses.title: Fundamentals and Applications of Biosensors
courses.description: Provides a broad introduction to the field of biosensors, as well as an in-depth and quantitative view of biosensor design and performance analysis. Fundamental application of biosensor theory will be demonstrated, including: recognition, transduction, signal acquisition, and post processing/data analysis.

courses.title: Remote Sensing in Engineering: Science, Sensors and Applications
courses.description: Develop an understanding of remote sensing theory, systems and applications using information obtained from the visible/near infrared, thermal infrared and microwave regions of the EM spectrum.

courses.title: Biological Engineering Design 1
courses.description: Design of engineered agricultural and biological systems and devices. Problem definition analysis, synthesis, project management, economic, environmental, and social impacts. Individual and team projects.

courses.title: Biological Engineering Design 2
courses.description: Senior capstone design project.

courses.title: Power and Machines for Biological Systems
courses.description: Design and specification of power and machine elements applied to agricultural, biological and land and water resources or food engineering; fundamentals of power units, design of machine elements and power transmission.

courses.title: Irrigation and Drainage Engineering
courses.description: Irrigation and drainage systems design, including pump sizing and specification, water distribution systems, plant water requirement, drainage systems and flood control.

courses.title: Controlled Environment Agriculture Systems Design
courses.description: Introduces the engineering design of controlled-environment agriculture systems, including glazing materials selection, fan-sizing for mechanical ventilation, lighting distribution, cooling system design with fan-and-pad evaporative cooling, and heating system design with hot water floor heating.

courses.title: Post-Harvest Operations Engineering
courses.description: Engineering principles and practices of post-harvest operations for the maintenance of quality of agricultural products. Design of systems and facilities.

courses.title: Modeling Coupled Natural-Human Systems
courses.description: Explore approaches to modeling coupled natural-human systems, drawing from both natural and social sciences. Topics include regime shift from dynamical systems and basic concepts from game theory and social-ecological system literature. These are combined in models that operationalize a conceptual framework. With guidance, develop models for final projects.

courses.title: Bio-Based Products from Renewable Resources
courses.description: Provides the knowledge for the production of fuels, chemicals, and materials from renewable resources; includes the fundamental principles and practical applications of bio-based products: biorefinery and biobased products overview, fundamental concepts in understanding biorefinery and biobased products; materials, chemical platforms, and fuels from biomass.

courses.title: Quantification of Biological Processes
courses.description: Quantitative description and analysis of biological processes pertaining to microbes, plants, animals and ecosystems. Biological transport phenomena, bioenergetics, enzyme kinetics, metabolism, bioregulation, circulatory and muscle systems, agroecosystems. Analytical and experimental laboratory for development of quantitative skills.

courses.title: Food and Bioprocess Engineering Unit Operations
courses.description: Analysis of thermal freezing, evaporation, dehydration, contact equilibrium and mechanical separation processes as governed by the reaction kinetics and rheology of processed foods.

courses.title: Individual Study in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Selected problems of projects in the student's major field of engineering study.

courses.title: Integrated Product and Processing Design 1 in Biological Engineering
courses.description: First part of a two-course sequence in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic products and processes on time and within budget.

courses.title: Integrated Product and Process Design 2 in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Second part of a two-course sequence in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic products and processes on time and within budget.

courses.title: Professional Issues in Agricultural and Biological Engineering
courses.description: Current developments in agricultural and biological engineering, principles of agricultural and biological engineering practice, and professional standards and ethics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Variable subjects provide content for the study of agricultural engineering topics not offered in other courses.

courses.title: Writing Grant Proposals for Scholarships and Fellowships
courses.description: Introduces seniors in the Agricultural and Biological Engineering department to opportunities for obtaining scholarships, fellowships, internships, and teaching/research assistantships from federal funding agencies; includes funding sources and opportunities, provide guidelines for proposal writing. Requires preparing a proposal.

courses.title: Work Experience in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Work experience in the biological engineering industry with advisor approval.

courses.title: Engineering Directed Independent Research
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: The African Experience: An Introduction to African Studies
courses.description: Introductory study of African society and culture that examines the richness, diversity, and time-depth of African civilizations.

courses.title: Poverty and Development in Africa
courses.description: Contemporary study of development issues in Africa, their challenges and possible solutions; theme based and includes economic development, agriculture and the environment, social issues and gender equality, and democracy and political development.

courses.title: Culture, Health and Arts in Sub-Saharan Africa
courses.description: Explores Sub-Saharan African cultures, health issues and belief systems related to health and the arts. Also provides a framework to better understand health and health care systems in other cultures.

courses.title: Childhood in African Literature and Cinema
courses.description: Explores African conceptions of childhood through the mediums of literature and film; examines how childhood is represented in diverse African cultures.

courses.title: Special Topics in African Studies
courses.description: Selected variable topics in African Studies.

courses.title: The African Family
courses.description: Understanding African societies south of the Sahara through the study of the functions, roles and meanings of households and families. Emphasizes diversity within and commonalities among the myriad forms of African families.

courses.title: Critical Issues in Contemporary Africa
courses.description: Upper-division seminar that discusses perspectives on conflict resolution, corruption, economic development, environmental management, food security, governance, international assistance, and public health in contemporary Africa. In addition, enhances skills in analysis, discussion, and debate.

courses.title: Women and Politics in Africa
courses.description: Introduces historical and contemporary roles of women in African political systems, from local to national governance.

courses.title: Community Conservation and Rural Development in Africa
courses.description: Examines the practicalities and theoretical foundations of community conservation in Africa, with particular attention on the relationship between conservation and rural development issues. Main themes include property rights, governance, and local-global relations.

courses.title: Political Economy of Conservation in Africa
courses.description: Analyzes effectiveness of diverse approaches to natural resource preservation and uses. Case studies are primarily from southern and eastern Africa, and readings focus on political and economic aspects of conservation strategies.

courses.title: Urban Africa Today
courses.description: Interdisciplinary seminar incorporates scholarship from anthropology, geography, history, political science, sociology, and urban planning to understand African cities, their rapid growth, and their future development.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: Individual study and research for topics not covered in other courses.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in African Studies
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: African Studies Interdisciplinary Seminar
courses.description: Seminar on a selected interdisciplinary theme.

courses.title: African Studies Internship
courses.description: Complements an Africa-related internship experience through guided reflection, critical analysis, synthesis, and discussion.

courses.title: Beginning Chinese 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Materials are designed for learners with no prior exposure to the language. Those with native background or education for four years or more in a Chinese speaking country must take a placement test before enrolling in any Chinese language class.

courses.title: Beginning Chinese 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Chinese 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Chinese 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Chinese for Heritage Learners 1
courses.description: For those with significant bilingual speaking and listening backgrounds. Emphasis is on recognition of the characters and writing, and pronunciation and speaking.

courses.title: Chinese for Heritage Learners 2
courses.description: To consolidate the foundation built in Chinese for Heritage Learners 1, to expand vocabulary and to introduce more complex grammatical structures. Emphasis is on reading and writing. Those who successfully complete CHI 2341 are eligible for CHI 3410.

courses.title: Chinese Calligraphy
courses.description: Introductory study of the origin, composition, development, variations and aesthetic styles of Chinese characters with laboratory sessions for appreciating and practicing calligraphic skills. (H and N)

courses.title: Advanced Chinese 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures. (S and N)

courses.title: Advanced Chinese 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Business Chinese
courses.description: Development of language skills and protocol issues used in Chinese business environments. Acquire vocabulary, phrases, and sentence patterns essential for business transactions and develop oral presentations, business cards, and resumes.

courses.title: Fourth Year Chinese 1
courses.description: Introduces and analyzes the documentary prose style used in Chinese newspapers and media. By studying a variety of short texts students develop skill in listening, speaking, reading and writing about issues commonly encountered in Chinese newspaper editorials and in television news programs, debate roundtables, or TV documentaries.

courses.title: Fourth Year Chinese 2
courses.description: Solidifies and improves students' knowledge of advanced Chinese through literature as a continuation of CHI 4050. Emphasizes formulating strategies to learn the difference between written language and spoken language and approaches meaningful writing with an eye toward careful examination of authentic writing samples.

courses.title: Structure of Chinese
courses.description: Introduction to phonological, grammatical and discourse structures of Mandarin Chinese, with an emphasis on its contrastive aspects with the English language. (S and N)

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Includes all individual study courses offered by the Chinese section.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Language or Linguistics
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Language or Linguistics. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Language or Linguistics.

courses.title: Special Topics in Chinese Studies
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Chinese studies.

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.description: Select a Chinese faculty member to act as director for an independent research project that culminates in the preparation of an honors thesis.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Gain practical experience that enhances classroom learning.

courses.title: Translation Method: Chinese to English
courses.description: Hands-on introduction to the processes, procedures, and cultural and linguistic challenges relevant to translation from Chinese to English. Development of basic translation skills including strategies on word level, sentence level, and text level. Acquisition of lexicon, structure, and style used in various fields (legal, business, medical) and hands-on experience in translating real-life documents.

courses.title: Chinese Literary Heritage
courses.description: Introduces pre-modern Chinese literature in translation. Topics chosen from classical poetry, short stories, novels, and drama. Emphasizes the interplay between orthodox values and the folk tradition. All readings are in English.

courses.title: Pre-Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation
courses.description: Pre-modern Chinese narrative from its philosophical and historical origins to the fiction at the turn of the 20th century. Emphasizes the 16th and 17th centuries when Chinese vernacular fiction flourished.

courses.title: Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation
courses.description: Surveys modern Chinese fiction in translation. Samples are from the early 20th century through the contemporary era and include writers of the early Republic, the P.R.C., and Taiwan. Focuses on fiction as a vehicle for social change. All readings are in English.

courses.title: Tales of the Strange in Medieval Chinese Literature
courses.description: Introduces traditional Chinese tales of the strange and primary sources that contributed to their development. Also covers cross-cultural literary theories of the fantastic and uncanny; interdisciplinary literary, discourse, and narrative theories; and three common medieval Chinese worldviews.

courses.title: Chinese Film and Media
courses.description: Examination of Chinese cinema and other forms of media, such as television, music, and print culture in a broad sociopolitical and historical context. An interdisciplinary approach with a diversity of readings and multimedia tools incorporated into discussions.

courses.title: Chinese Culture
courses.description: Introduction to Chinese culture with emphasis on its philosophy, language, society, art, and people as a whole. All readings are in English.

courses.title: Chinese Martial Arts Fiction
courses.description: Overview of Chinese martial arts fiction from earliest times to the present day. Discusses the literary pleasure of watching violence, the relationship between violence and the law, gender ambiguity of woman warriors, the imperial and (trans)national order of martial arts narrative, and the moral and physical economy of vengeance.

courses.title: Taoism and Chinese Culture
courses.description: Introduction to the general history and culture of Taoism in ancient and modern China: its thoughts, belief systems, cultural influences, practices, and rituals.

courses.title: Hong Kong, Taiwan, and the New Global Cinema
courses.description: Overview of Sinophone film in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and the broader sphere of Chinese diaspora. Addresses film history, culture, and aesthetics.

courses.title: Dream of the Red Chamber
courses.description: Explores the intellectual and social life of traditional China through the 18th century epic novel, Story of the Stone. Also studies interpretive theories of the novel, both Chinese and Western. All readings are in English.

courses.title: Journey to the West
courses.description: Exploration of traditional Chinese religious culture, cultural history and literacy expression through a 100 chapter novel known as Journey to the West, or Monkey.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in English Translation
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in English Translation. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in English Translation.

courses.title: Classical Chinese 1
courses.description: Introduction to classical Chinese prose with texts drawn mainly from early histories and philosophical writings (500 BC - AD 100). Emphasis on reading comprehension, grammar analysis and translation.

courses.title: Classical Chinese 2
courses.description: Continuation of CHW 4120 focusing on classical Chinese prose with texts drawn from early historical and philosophical texts to belles-lettres of the medieval era and later periods. Emphasis on reading comprehension, grammar analysis, and translation.

courses.title: Readings in Chinese Literature
courses.description: Introduces advanced language students to a sampling of Chinese writers. Materials chosen from classic or modern/contemporary Chinese literature rotated across semesters. All readings in Chinese.

courses.title: Newspaper Chinese
courses.description: Development of ability to understand and translate the documentary prose style used in Chinese newspapers and academic journals. Introduces literary function words and grammar structures, with comparison to the vernacular. Most readings in the simplified character form used in the PRC; all readings in Chinese. Applications for research on modern China.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Target Language
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Quantification of Biological Processes
courses.description: Quantitative description and analysis of biological processes pertaining to microbes, plants, animals and ecosystems. Biological transport phenomena, bioenergetics, enzyme kinetics, metabolism, bioregulation, circulatory and muscle systems, agroecosystems. Analytical and experimental laboratory for development of quantitative skills.

courses.title: Advertising Strategy
courses.description: Overview of the strategic planning process required to develop a successful strategic, persuasive communication plan such as an advertising, integrated marketing communications, or social marketing campaign. Case studies and projects teach the skills needed to address a variety of communications management issues and engage audiences in diverse marketplaces.

courses.title: Digital Insights
courses.description: Acquiring, evaluating, and analyzing information for advertising decisions. Emphasizes understanding the scientific method, developing explicit and measurable research objectives, selecting appropriate methodologies, and analyzing data.

courses.title: Media Planning
courses.description: Provides an in-depth overview of the media planning process. Emphasizes the value of various media channels and evaluation methods to design innovative and integrated media strategies to reach and engage diverse audiences.

courses.title: AI in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Artificial intelligence (AI) is used to solve problems in research and industry. This course provides students with understanding of and practical hands-on experience building and using AI systems. Students will obtain the skills and knowledge they need to use AI to solve real-world problems in agricultural and life sciences.

courses.title: Building Energy Modeling
courses.description: As energy becomes a more precious commodity, it is crucial to design and operate high performance buildings. A solid foundation of energy engineering and sustainability principles is essential to achieving these higher performance standards.

courses.title: AI in Biology
courses.description: Examines how AI has rapidly become ubiquitous in daily life and been applied to diverse areas of Biology. Focuses on machine learning approaches as well as deep learning methods, including transformers. Covers machine learning methods for tabular data, computer vision, transfer learning, natural language processing, and transformer-based architectures. Classes typically applied coding with Jupyter Notebooks on HiPerGator. Prior Python coding experience required.

courses.title: Natural Language Processing
courses.description: Introduction to the essential concepts, principles, and techniques of Natural Language Processing (NLP). Practical application and theoretical concepts are examined. Topics include information extraction, language construction, grammars, disambiguation, as well as system modeling, classification, and evaluation.

courses.title: AI in the Built Environment
courses.description: Introduces Artificial Intelligence (AI) and its applications to real world problems in planning, design, and construction of the built environment. Includes application in professional practice in architecture, construction management, interior design, landscape architecture, and urban and regional planning.

courses.title: Econometrics
courses.description: Introduces concepts and methods used in empirical economic research. Emphasizes practical use of basic econometric techniques to estimate economic relationships and evaluate policy. Covers topics needed to plan and implement empirical projects, and understand potential problems with the empirical analyses of others.

courses.title: Econometrics 2
courses.description: Introduces advanced concepts and methods employed in empirical economic analysis. Focuses on identification of causality using regression techniques. Examines regression discontinuity and difference-in-differences identification strategies.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Machine Learning
courses.description: Overview of machine intelligence and the role of machine learning in a variety of real-world problems. Probability and statistics to handle uncertain data. Topics covered include: learning models from data in both a supervised and unsupervised fashion, linear models and non- linear models for classification, and linear dimensionality reduction.

courses.title: Artificial Intelligence Fundamentals
courses.description: Overview of Artificial Intelligence (AI), approaching the concept from its origins to expectations for the future; focuses on various AI technologies, how to build Machine Learning models, and how to apply AI tools to solve real world problems. Some concepts are types of AI and Machine Learning, Hacking and the IoT, AI today and its outlook for the future.

courses.title: Introduction to Data Analytics
courses.description: Provides a basic understanding of the skills necessary for managing and analyzing data. The concepts covered include exploratory data analysis, data manipulation, data cleaning, data wrangling, and machine learning models. A basic understanding of data management with SQL is also provided. All the technical skills will be motivated by different examples involving data. Python is the programming language used.

courses.title: Laboratory in Sensory Processes
courses.description: Collect, analyze, and evaluate data on specific problems related to sensory and perceptual abilities.

courses.title: Business Finance
courses.description: The acquisition and management of funds by business. A minimum grade of B is required in FIN 3403 to register for required finance major courses.

courses.title: Geographical Sciences and Sustainability
courses.description: Examines the most critical environmental issues facing the world today; emphasizes the sustainability of both human and physical systems in the 21st century utilizing cutting-edge geographic technologies: spatial analysis, GIS, and satellite imagery.

courses.title: Intermediate Quantitative Analysis for Geographers
courses.description: Surveys various multivariate techniques commonly used to analyze geographic data. Emphasis on hypothesis testing, inference, multiple regression, analysis of variance and cluster analysis. Introduces time-series regression and grouped estimation procedures, factor analysis, probit/logit modeling and trend-surface interpolation. (WR)

courses.title: The Digital Earth
courses.description: Focuses on how the Earth's surface is visualized, explored, and analyzed in digital formats (e.g. maps, satellite images, aerial photos). Provides an introduction to fundamental concepts of digital geographic data to understand the Earth environment and human society based on the vast quantities of geographic information in our ever-changing world.

courses.title: Foundations of Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) as the technology for creation, modification, display, and analysis of spatial information. Develops knowledge of GIS, competence in geographic databases, and familiarity with computer software and hardware.

courses.title: Digital Image Processing
courses.description: Introduces the theory and application of digital imagery data in geographical research with a hands-on, lab-based approach.

courses.title: GIS Programming
courses.description: Introduces basic programming concepts; instruction in popular programming languages for geospatial processing, applications, and modeling in ArcGIS environment.

courses.title: Introduction to Spatial Networks
courses.description: Many phenomena of interest in physical, social and cyber environments can be thought of as networks within geographic context. Teaches methods for analyzing these spatial networks, and introduces their applications in geography, transportation, hydrology, epidemiology, social science, etc.

courses.title: Artificial Intelligence Revolutions and Applications in Tourism, Hospitality, and Events
courses.description: A foundational examination of the implications of the artificial intelligence revolution (AI) in the tourism, hospitality, and event industry. Content includes analyses of AI applications in booking, transportation, theme parks, destination and attraction marketing, economic, social, cultural, and environmental impacts, as well as motivators to travel.

courses.title: Nutrition and Disease: Part 2
courses.description: Part two of the sequence that focuses on the biochemical and pathophysiological bases of disease/conditions that require specialized nutrition support/medical nutrition therapy.

courses.title: Laboratory Techniques in Molecular Nutrition
courses.description: Laboratory techniques relevant to the study of nutrition, ranging from biochemistry, molecular biology, genomics and bioinformatics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Introduces selected interdisciplinary topics. Content varies from term to term.

courses.title: Computing in the Business Environment
courses.description: Presents fundamental concepts from two perspectives: the individual business computer user and the corporate business computing environment. Introduces common business computing applications; this is not a  hands on  applications training course. Students use their existing computer skills to complete assignments.

courses.title: Introduction to Information Systems
courses.description: Introduces the role of information systems and technology in an organization with a focus on the use of Access and Excel to solve business problems. Receive the knowledge necessary to earn Microsoft certifications in Access and Excel.

courses.title: Artificial Intelligence in Media and Society
courses.description: Gain an understanding of artificial intelligence as it applies to the media professions, including journalists reporting on AI. Explore developments in AI technologies as covered by the mass media. Learn to detect exaggeration in descriptions of AI’s promise and potential risks and dangers.

courses.title: Site Analysis
courses.description: Inventory, analysis and evaluation of site development procedures; emphasis on landscape ecology.

courses.title: Operations and Supply Chain Management
courses.description: Managerial concepts and quantitative tools required in the design, operation, and control of production systems and their relationship to business functions.

courses.title: Radar and Satellite Meteorology
courses.description: Overview of radar and satellite remote sensing as used in the atmospheric sciences, including the principles of atmospheric radiative transfer, the retrieval of atmospheric variables, and emphasis on geospatial interpretation of imagery for different weather systems.

courses.title: Consumer and Audience Analytics
courses.description: Provides practical analytical skill-sets, benefiting those who plan careers in analytics/research, social media, media business, advertising/marketing, and public relations.

courses.title: Biological Invaders
courses.description: Introduces plants and animals that are invading Florida and the US. Why biological invaders are second only to habitat destruction as threats to natural ecosystems, what makes some species invasive, how to control or prevent invasions, where international commerce may be regulated, and who is affected by such issues.

courses.title: Higher Thinking for Healthy Humans: AI in Healthcare and Public Health
courses.description: Covers history, foundational concepts and methods on artificial intelligence (AI), focusing on public health and healthcare applications, including hands-on practice on graphical/highlevel AI software. The course neither provides advanced statistical/machine learning training nor programming.

courses.title: Ethics, Data, and Technology
courses.description: Addresses ethical issues related to data science, algorithmic decision-making, and artificial intelligence. Pairs theoretical discussions of ethics, economics, and policy-making with concrete issues in emerging technologies.

courses.title: Plant Propagation
courses.description: Principles, practices and physiological aspects of the propagation of horticultural and agronomic crops by cuttage, graftage, seedage, micropropagation and other methods.

courses.title: Plant Propagation Laboratory
courses.description: Methods of propagating by seeds, bulbs, divisions, layering, cuttings, budding, grafting and micropropagation in a hands-on environment.

courses.title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.description: The biological foundations of human cognition.

courses.title: Statistics for Business Decisions
courses.description: Correlation and linear regression, model building, multiple regression, analysis of variance, time series analysis and decision analysis. Regression modeling with computer applications for business problems.

courses.title: Foundations of Business Analytics & Artificial Intelligence (AI)
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the basics of data analytics and machine learning using the powerful programming language Python. Students will learn Python basics, as well as how to write programs and use Python to solve real world problems.

courses.title: Managerial Operations Analysis 1
courses.description: Introduces the concepts and applications of management science; become more confident in understanding and using deterministic analytic models.

courses.title: Managerial Operations Analysis 2
courses.description: Overview of stochastic applications of management science; learn stochastic modeling techniques and introductory visual basic.

courses.title: Media Law and Policy
courses.description: Introduction to the laws and regulations affecting the past, present, and future of communication technology, emphasizing free expression, privacy, defamation and intellectual property.

courses.title: Wildlife Behavior and Conservation
courses.description: Concise, current, and thorough grounding to the field (theory, practice, and relevance) of animal behavior, with a strong focus on applications of wildlife behavior to achieve successful wildlife conservation gains.

courses.title: Data Feminisms
courses.description: Draws from critical data and algorithm studies and feminist science and technology studies to develop critical tools of inquiry needed to approach data within a context of racialized, gendered, colonial, and classed systems of power. Combines practical data workshops with critical readings to analyze data across key uses in domains such as healthcare, security apparatuses, carceral systems, and digital infrastructures.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Topics vary.

courses.title: Human Growth and Development
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Life-span survey of human growth and development beginning at conception and ending with death. Provides the opportunity to apply general principles in appropriate educational settings.

courses.title: Development in Education
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: This course will introduce students to the significant changes in biological, cognitive, social, and emotional development that occur during childhood and adolescence. This course will acquaint students with relevant theoretical perspectives and research on child and adolescent development within the context of learning and education. Although the course is not a teacher preparation course it does include content that focuses on educating students from early childhood through adolescence.

courses.title: Child Development for Inclusive Education
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Examines psychological theories and research on typical and atypical development and their application in general education classrooms that include children with sensory, mental, emotional, and learning disabilities, as well as gifted and talented children.

courses.title: The Young Adolescent
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Introduces application of developmental and educational psychology to contexts of young adolescents between the ages of ten and fifteen. Service-learning component in a 6th-12th grade educational setting is required in order to apply course content.

courses.title: The Adolescent
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: The special role that the adolescent plays in total development. Emphasis is on the psychological development of the adolescent in the school.

courses.title: Educational Psychology
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Introduces the application of psychology to the problems of education in a variety of educational settings. Also examines the theoretical and applied aspects of learning, motivation, human development, personality, and measurement and evaluation.

courses.title: Educational Research Design
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Addresses the basic tenets of educational research design, including quantitative, qualitative, and mixed-method approaches to investigating educational phenomena; Learn the information needed to understand the educational research process.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Topics vary.

courses.title: Cognition in Education
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Examines cognitive science that explains learning in educational contexts. Specifically, reviewing memory, attention, thinking, and problem solving in classroom or applied settings. Pays special attention to the connections between research and everyday phenomena; designed to help students apply course material to enhance their lives.

courses.title: Measurement and Evaluation in Education
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Basic principles and methods of measurement, evaluation, and test construction.

courses.title: Program Evaluation in Educational Settings
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Overview to the skills and methods required to assess the effectiveness and impact of educational programs and institutions. First presents program evaluation in the broader setting of the social sciences, followed by evaluation readings and activities tailored specifically to educational settings.

courses.title: Survey Research Methods in Education
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Overview of the theory and application of survey research methods, with special emphasis on conducting survey research in educational settings. Presents the full process of survey research, including design, implementation, analysis, and data management.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Explore areas of inquiry under faculty guidance in psychological, social, philosophical foundations of education, research, or measurement.

courses.title: Education Undergraduate Research
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Supports mentored scholarship work that enables engaging in the research process of posing questions, collecting and analyzing data, drawing evidence-based conclusions, and communicating the results to others. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application, depending on the topic.

courses.title: Introduction to Education Policy
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Introduces education policy and analysis that explores the history and purpose of education policy, key federal and state policies impacting K12 and higher education, and theoretical and conceptual approaches to policy analysis.

courses.title: Cognitive and Educational Science in AI
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Examines cognitive and education science concepts that underpin the field of Artificial Intelligence and explores how AI integrates into educational contexts. Enhance conceptual understanding of what makes AI tools work and increase the ability to use those tools in an increasingly AI-rich educational environment. This non-programming course does not require advanced AI or computer science knowledge.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Topics vary.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Topics vary.

courses.title: What if there was no Stigma in Mental Health?
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Explores stigma related to mental health from a social-cultural lens. Portrayals of mental health in art, media, and social science disciplines are deconstructed and regenerated through class activities. Students create a wellness plan, evaluate wellness, learn skills to optimal mental health, and challenging perceptions to create societal and personal change.

courses.title: Career and Life Span Planning
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Covers presentations, discussions, and experiential activities for making effective life plans and adjustments.

courses.title: Family and Community Involvement in Education
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Examines existing models and practices for enhancing family-school-community interaction with emphasis on communication, conflict resolution, and climate-building skill development.

courses.title: Introduction to Trauma and Crisis
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Develop knowledge about trauma and crisis and increase awareness of the effects of trauma on individuals, families, groups, and communities, and the process of recovery. Also develop knowledge about careers affiliated with assisting survivors of trauma and crisis through their recovery. Students will disclose personal reflections related to the information covered in the course on trauma and crisis.

courses.title: Student Development in a University Setting
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Examines factors affecting student growth and development in the university setting, current problems facing students, and the use of group processes and leadership training in solving problems and facilitating growth.

courses.title: Alcohol and Drug Abuse
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: General information of effects and problems associated with alcohol and other drug abuse.

courses.title: Stress and Anxiety Management
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Overview of theories and methods of stress and anxiety control and reduction.

courses.title: Interpersonal Communication Skills
courses.department: Education | School of Human Development and Organizational Studies
courses.description: Application of basic principles of interpersonal communication with emphasis on the affective dimensions. Gives attention to using basic counseling strategies and psychological techniques as an aid to effective communication.

courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Science
courses.description: This course is a survey of basic chemical, biological, and physical principles of environmental science and their applications to environmental issues. This course is appropriate for students in a wide range of disciplines or programs.

courses.title: First Year Environmental Science
courses.description: Onboarding course for first year freshmen and HSAA students pursuing a BS or BA in Environmental Science. Sets up students for success in the Environmental Science major by guiding students through degree requirements, exploring departmental, college, and university resources, and discussing a variety of current environmental issues.

courses.title: Environmental Science 1
courses.description: Assess environmental issues arising from human-nature interactions, including biodiversity loss, overpopulation, degradation of ecosystems, and concerns associated with energy and water use. This interdisciplinary approach integrates natural and social science perspectives to explore causes, impacts, and solutions to these issues.

courses.title: Environmental Science Laboratory
courses.description: Hands-on experience in data collection and analysis for environmental science and management.

courses.title: Environmental Science 2
courses.description: Advanced environmental science topics with a focus on methods and applications to develop reasoned solutions to the complex social-ecological issues impacting society.

courses.title: Critical Thinking in Environmental Science
courses.description: Develops critical thinking and communication skills in the practicing environmental scientist. Students analyze the strengths, limitations and strategies of arguments regarding environmental science, policy and management, and craft arguments consistent with the scientific method.

courses.title: Supervised Extension Experience in Natural Resources and Environment
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic experiences in natural resources and environment under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Environmental Science
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in environmental science under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Environmental Science
