Participate in class lectures and hands-on laboratory activities to build full-scale projects involving framing, plumbing, electrical, windows, etc. Combines building codes and building science to introduce the changing world of construction.

courses.title: Pesticide Application Techniques
courses.description: Equipment and methods used to apply pesticides in agriculture. Emphasizes techniques used to avoid misapplication, a common cause of pesticide failures.

courses.title: Irrigation Principles and Practices in Florida
courses.description: Irrigation practice related to Florida agriculture. The course deals with irrigation system characteristics, management, maintenance and economics.

courses.title: Agri-food Systems Innovation
courses.description: Explore the role of innovation in food systems from a reverse chain perspective. Gain knowledge of the food system framework from a multilevel (i.e., individual, organizational, etc.) perspective, identify current, innovative business and technological practices, as well as present and think critically about future trends in food.

courses.title: Principles of Food Engineering
courses.description: The functional requirements and principles of operation of systems for handling and processing food and agricultural products.

courses.title: Power and Machinery Management
courses.description: Functional requirements, operating principles, performance, safety, and economic application of agricultural power units and field machines for citrus, vegetable and field crop production.

courses.title: Precision Agriculture
courses.description: Principles and applications of technologies supporting precision farming and planning for natural resource data management. Global positioning systems (GPS), geographic information systems (GIS), variable rate technologies (VRT), data layering of independent variables, automated guidance, Internet, information access and computer software for management.

courses.title: Electrical Power and Instrumentation for Agricultural Operations Management
courses.description: Fundamental concepts of electricity, power, instrumentation, computer control operations, and selected transducers. Foundation to aid in management of agricultural processing operations.

courses.title: Agricultural Operations and Systems
courses.description: Quantitative and managerial techniques for management and planning of technical resources in agriculture. Applications of queuing theory, project scheduling, optimization, and expert decision systems.

courses.title: Sustainable Agricultural Systems
courses.description: Minimizing energy and costs in agricultural and natural resource systems and industries. Explore ways to enhance sustainable systems by improving efficiency. Topics include agricultural machinery, pumps, motors, fans, refrigeration, lights, and construction methods.

courses.title: Instrumentation and Climate Management in Controlled Environment Agriculture
courses.description: Sensors and instruments for monitoring growing environment in controlled environment agriculture will be introduced. Learn how to evaluate production systems, monitor environmental variables, control growing conditions, and design experiments.

courses.title: Introduction to Biofuels
courses.description: An overview of biofuel production related to technologies and feedstocks, economics of producing biofuels and impact on the environment and the local economy. Dealing specifically with liquid and gaseous biofuels and bioenergy produced from renewable resources, it provides a summary of the past, present and future production technologies and applications.

courses.title: Environmental Systems for Agricultural Structures
courses.description: Effects of the environment on plant and animal production, processing operations and quality of stored produce. Selection of building materials and sizing of components of environmental systems in agricultural structures to enhance more efficient agricultural production, processing and storage.

courses.title: Environmental Hydrology: Principles and Issues
courses.description: The basics of environmental hydrology, intended for agricultural and natural resource managers. The first half covers scientific principles of the hydrologic cycle while the second half investigates case studies of current water quality and water management issues.

courses.title: Supervised Extension Experience in Agricultural Operations Management
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural operations management under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.title: Special Problems in Agricultural Operations Management
courses.description: Selected problems or projects in the student's major field of mechanized study.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Agricultural Education and Communication
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in Agricultural Education and Communication under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Agricultural Operations Management
courses.description: Independent research in agricultural operations management leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Special Topics in Agricultural Operations Management
courses.description: Variable topics provide content for the study of mechanized agriculture topics not offered in other courses.

courses.title: Professional Practices in Agricultural Operations Management
courses.description: Professionalism and interfacing of technical skills. Topics include ethics, continuing education, placement skills and professional development in agricultural operations management.

courses.title: Full-Time Practical Work Experience in Agricultural Operations Management
courses.description: Full-Time Practical Work Experience in Agricultural Operations Management

courses.title: Growing Fruit for Fun and Profit
courses.description: Especially for non-majors who desire a concise mini-course in fruit growing and marketing. Fruit crops include citrus, pecan, blueberry, strawberry, peach, grape, apple, mango and avocado.

courses.title: Introduction to Citrus Culture and Production
courses.description: Citrus botany, scion and rootstock selection, site selection, fruit quality grove design, and production practices.

courses.title: Tropical and Subtropical Fruits
courses.description: Culture and management of important tropical and subtropical fruit, including avocado, banana, mango, papaya, loquat, persimmon, pineapple, coffee, and others.

courses.title: Tree and Small Fruit Production
courses.description: Current principles and cultural practices in deciduous tree, bush, and vine crops. Emphasizes practical aspects of production.

courses.title: Viticulture for Table Grapes and Wine
courses.description: Teaches current practices for establishing a vineyard and maintaining its health and productivity into the final quality of the grape. Topics covered include grape varietal selection, site selection and preparation, vine growth, training and trellis systems, and equipment used in vineyard and wine production.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Special Problems

courses.title: Vegetable Gardening
courses.description: Primarily for non-majors who desire to learn the basic principles of vegetable gardening. A garden is required of each student.

courses.title: Fighting Food Waste and Loss
courses.description: For those interested in learning and reflecting upon the major future challenges of food and agriculture. Learn about postharvest biology, environmental and food sciences, and communication technology in reducing food waste.

courses.title: Principles of Horticultural Crop Production
courses.description: Introduces concepts and practices used to produce fruit and vegetable crops in Florida, the U.S., and globally. Topics covered include production regions, crop biology, crop nutrition, types of fruits and vegetables, disease and pest management, and marketing. Includes a hands-on practicum.

courses.title: Greenhouse and Protected Agriculture
courses.description: Principles and practices of crop production in protected structures. Emphasizes structure type, media, fertilization, and pest control practices.

courses.title: Organic and Sustainable Crop Production
courses.description: Concepts and techniques of organic and sustainable production of horticultural crops, including soil/water management, pest control, harvest, handling, and marketing.

courses.title: The Organic Debate: Organic Agriculture Development & Regulations
courses.description: Organic farming is a rapidly developing production system. This introductory course provides a critical analysis of organic agriculture growth, consumer perceptions, and regulations at the national and international level. This course also focuses on organic agriculture transdisciplinary innovations and challenges in advancing environmental, economic, and social sustainability of food production.

courses.title: Introduction to Plant Molecular Biology
courses.description: Introduces plant molecular biology and genetic engineering, emphasizing plant genes and genomes, transformation of plants and basic molecular biology.

courses.title: Nutrition of Horticultural Crops
courses.description: Study and discussion of physiological, biochemical, and environmental factors influencing nutritional status and productivity of horticultural crops.

courses.title: Breeding and Production of Medicinal Plants and Herbs
courses.description: Focuses on current and emerging breeding and cultivation practices used to produce high–value medicinal plants and herbs. Additionally, provides a critical analysis of health effects and therapeutic claims of plant-derived physiologically-active products.

courses.title: Genetics and Breeding of Vegetable Crops
courses.description: Traditional and molecular breeding methods for vegetable crops and the influence of scientific research, government policies, industry needs, and consumer preferences on vegetable crop improvement.

courses.title: Advanced Organic and Sustainable Crop Production
courses.description: Intensive examination of the methods and techniques necessary for organic and sustainable production and marketing of horticultural products.

courses.title: Horticultural Physiology
courses.description: Basic concepts and processes of physiology as they relate to plant growth and development.

courses.title: Laboratory Methods in Plant Molecular Biology
courses.description: Hands-on laboratory experience in plant molecular biology. Utilizing current techniques for isolation, purification and cloning of plant DNA, students learn many basic techniques in plant biotechnology.

courses.title: Principles of Postharvest Horticulture
courses.description: Biological principles involved in harvesting, grading, packaging, transportation, and marketing horticultural crops, and their effects on quality maintenance. Commercial postharvest practices explained in relation to general procedures and technologies as well as the recommended postharvest best handling practices and optimum postharvest conditions for different types of horticultural crops.

courses.title: Advanced Horticultural Physiology
courses.description: Environmental effects (light, temperature and water) on physiology, growth and development of plants.

courses.title: Supervised Extension Experience in Horticultural Sciences
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.title: Independent Study in Horticultural Science
courses.description: Selected research topics in molecular biology, physiology, and/or genetics of horticultural crops.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Horticultural Sciences
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in horticultural sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Horticultural Sciences
courses.description: Independent research in horticultural sciences leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Capstone Planning in Horticultural Sciences
courses.description: Focuses on planning service learning, scientific research, cooperative extension, or industry liaison projects for the Horticultural Sciences capstone. Also fosters reflection of academic and professional development in the major.

courses.title: Horticultural Sciences Capstone
courses.description: Focuses on executing service learning, scientific research, cooperative extension, or industry liaison projects designed during capstone planning. Perfect professional portfolios and present the outcomes of the capstone project.

courses.title: Special Topics in Horticultural Sciences
courses.description: Critical review of selected topics in specific areas not covered in other horticultural sciences courses.

courses.title: Professional Development in Horticulture
courses.description: Professional skills development, including job searching, resume writing, interview skills, professional etiquette, communications, and salary negotiations.

courses.title: Practical Work Experience in Horticultural Sciences
courses.description: Practical work that must be a new experience and related to the field of study.

courses.title: Hydroponic Systems
courses.description: This course offers students foundational information and hands-on experience on hydroponic and soilless cultivation of horticultural crops. Production practices, growing systems, new technologies and current challenges are discussed.

courses.title: Vegetable Production
courses.description: Principles and practices of successful commercial vegetable production, including crop requirements, growth patterns, and production techniques along with consumption/marketing patterns and US/Florida production areas.

courses.title: Organic Weed Management
courses.description: Apply ecological principles in agroecosystems to manage weeds sustainably. Emphasizes alternative weed management approaches that are less dependent on herbicides and utilize ecological processes detrimental to weeds and their propagules. Learn actively by critically analyzing pertinent literature and participating in discussions of supplemental reading.

courses.title: World Herbs and Vegetables
courses.description: Introduces a variety of vegetables and culinary herbs. Emphasizes genetic, phytochemical and botanical diversity and importance of food phytochemicals and role of vegetables in nutrition. (B)

courses.title: Site Analysis
courses.description: Inventory, analysis and evaluation of site development procedures; emphasis on landscape ecology.

courses.title: Landscape Management
courses.description: Explores the relationship between planning and design decision-making and landscape management practices which are, in turn, based on the fundamental principles of ecology and landscape ecology.

courses.title: Introduction to Landscape Architecture
courses.description: Introduces landscape architecture, a profession defined as an art and science of planning or designing on the land-arranging and creating spaces and objects in a landscape for human use. Open to all students.

courses.title: Principles of Landscape Architecture
courses.description: Builds upon the fundamental principles of design covered in previous studios to explore a range of landscape architectural issues. Site design problems incorporating a mixture of cultural, environmental, and historical topics provide a framework for students to develop their analytical skills, communication techniques, and general understanding of design.

courses.title: Planting Design Studio
courses.description: The planting design studio introduces the planting design process, its relationship to the site planning, existing site conditions, project locale and client needs.

courses.title: Design Communications 1
courses.description: Introduces visualization techniques via a project based studio in landscape architectural design and planning. Covers traditional drawing conventions, alternative methods of exploratory visualization and the techniques and processes used to produce these methods of communication.

courses.title: Design Communications 2
courses.description: Advances the design communication strategies introduced in Design Communications I by further developing skills in digital visualization and communication techniques. Additionally, expanding their skill set to include advanced applications in to include landform and three dimensional space and object modeling and to be introduced to digital fabrication and three dimensional output.

courses.title: History of Landscape Architecture
courses.description: Landscape architecture is the art and science of arranging functions and spaces within the ecology of the land and the culture of the humans who inhabit it. Surveys the history of humans as it is expressed in such diverse areas as urban form, community planning, gardens, parks and recreational areas, agricultural patterns and land management. Open to all students. (H and N)

courses.title: Theories of Landscape Architecture
courses.description: Explores the theories pertinent to the practice and study of landscape architecture. Addresses primarily aesthetic and cultural principles and values with related ecological aspects.

courses.title: Site Design and Planning Studio
courses.description: Application of basic site design principles on small-scale projects.

courses.title: Urban Design Studio
courses.description: Design studio emphasizes the physical, social-behavioral, and civil factors involved with the design and planning of towns, cities and the public space found therein. Projects range in scale and complexity including the design of a new urban environment and/or existing urban development.

courses.title: Advanced Design Communication
courses.description: Develop skills in digital visualization and communication techniques, exploring digital media as a landscape architecture tool for design and fabrication; produce high quality perspective drawings and design diagrams using Rhino and Adobe CC, and digital fabrication techniques using UF's Fab Lab.

courses.title: Landscape Construction 1
courses.description: Characteristics of land form and the effects of grading on drainage, soils and location of landscape architectural elements; pavings, low retaining walls; quantification skills.

courses.title: Landscape Construction 2
courses.description: Design and construction drawings for public and private landscape structures, landscape utilities, and irrigation system layouts; specifications, takeoffs and estimating.

courses.title: Landscape Architecture Professional Practice
courses.description: Preparation for professional practice and the understanding of the business of landscape architecture in private and public arenas.

courses.title: Senior Independent Project Seminar
courses.description: Focuses on proposal writing and information gathering to support the senior independent project.

courses.title: Senior Independent Project
courses.description: This final semester-long project expands personal interests and talents, hones decision-making abilities, and sharpens professional skills through well-rounded, comprehensive completion of individual projects. Project must be approved by the faculty.

courses.title: Design Communications for Landscape Architects
courses.description: Immersive experience in visualization techniques in landscape architectural design and planning. Covers traditional drawing conventions (plan, section/elevation and perspective) and builds skills in digital communication and visualization methods.

courses.title: Landscape Architecture Design Implementation
courses.description: Integration of the principles of construction with design. A combination of lecture and studio complements instruction in the design studio class. Students complete a full set of construction documents to support their design concept prepared in the beginning of the course.

courses.title: Special Studies in Landscape Architecture
courses.description: Studio investigations of topics in landscape architecture adjusted to individual needs of advanced undergraduate and graduate students.

courses.title: Gardens of the World
courses.description: Assessment and discussion of works of landscape architecture with emphasis on user evaluation, design trends, and research directions. Open to all majors.

courses.title: Landscape Architecture Internship
courses.description: Internship in a private/public sector office under the direction of a registered landscape architect; required for graduation.

courses.title: Extended Internship with Landscape Architect
courses.description: Internship in a private/public sector office under the direction of a registered landscape architect.

courses.title: Civil Engineering Estimating
courses.description: Design of systems for estimating and cost control of human-machine productivity for civil engineering projects. Analysis of cost factors required for optimization of engineering-investment efficiency.

courses.title: Construction Equipment, Methods and Management
courses.description: Theory and practice of construction operations, equipment utilization and construction methods. Analysis of costs. Optimizing crew and equipment. Heavy equipment costs. New emphasis on planning and executing a construction project.

courses.title: Construction Engineering Design
courses.description: Simulation of comprehensive construction project involving all phases of planning, scheduling and control from start to finish, which involves making major decisions. Oral presentation required at the end of course.

courses.title: Soil Mechanics
courses.description: Physical properties of soils, compaction, flow of water through soil, distribution of stress within soil and consolidation. Laboratory.

courses.title: Geotechnical Engineering
courses.description: Subsurface exploration settlements analysis, slope stability, earth pressure and an introduction to foundation design.

courses.title: Retaining Wall and Embankment Design
courses.description: The application of soil mechanics to the design and analysis of various types of retaining structures and earthen embankments.

courses.title: Foundation Engineering Design
courses.description: Comprehensive design of geotechnical system, focusing on design of complete project and utilizing CAD programs. Designs, drawings and oral presentations through group effort.

courses.title: Mechanics of Engineering Structures
courses.description: Introduces structural load, equilibrium, shear and bending moment diagrams, structural analysis software, classical methods for displacement determination, method of consistent deformations, slope deflection method, moment distribution method.

courses.title: Analysis and Design in Steel
courses.description: Elastic and plastic theories of design, design of members subjected to tension, compression, flexure and torsion. Design of connections and rigid frames.

courses.title: Analysis and Design in Reinforced Concrete
courses.description: Ultimate strength analysis and design of reinforced beams and columns, working stress design for flexure, design of footings and retaining walls.

courses.title: Introduction to Civil Engineering
courses.description: Introduces the broad field of civil engineering.

courses.title: Computer Methods in Civil Engineering
courses.description: Review of computer programming. Numerical methods as applied to civil engineering problems and civil engineering software.

courses.title: Civil Engineering Materials
courses.description: Studies the principal materials used for engineering purposes with special attention to mechanical properties and their importance to the engineer. Hands-on experience in testing of civil engineering materials.

courses.title: Introduction to Sustainable Engineering
courses.description: Overview of the principles of sustainability as they relate to civil and environmental engineering issues. Discussions and projects facilitate a basic understanding of the production-consumption model and life cycle assessment.

courses.title: Experimentation and Instrumentation in Civil Engineering
courses.description: Fundamentals and applications of measuring systems commonly used in civil engineering. Topics include recording techniques, strain, force, displacement, flow, temperature, humidity and PH measurements.

courses.title: Civil Engineering Cost Analysis
courses.description: Analysis of civil engineering proposals, utilizing time-value and related factors. Feasibility and optimum life comparisons. Utility rate derivation, utility/cost method.

courses.title: Civil Engineering Practice
courses.description: Fundamentals of civil engineering professional practice: project management, construction delivery processes, business concepts, public policy, administration, diversity and equity issues in civil engineering, and leadership.

courses.title: Machine Learning Applications in Civil Engineering
courses.description: Leverage machine learning state-of-the-art techniques and tools to solve Civil Engineering problems. Apply fundamentals of data analytics and machine learning techniques to real-world tasks and gain essential knowledge and programming skills (using R) in data preprocessing, feature selection, model comparison, hyperparameter tuning, and machine-learning interpretation. Includes case studies and applications for hands-on experience.

courses.title: Applied Data Science in Civil and Environmental Engineering
courses.description: Introduces the workflows of data science applications, covering the state-of-art techniques in data acquisition, data processing and management, analytics and modeling, and visualization. Critical application of data science concepts and techniques in complex socioeconomic and environmental contexts. Basics of problem formulation and major ethical considerations of applying data science in practice.

courses.title: Pavement Design
courses.description: Function and material requirements of different elements of flexible and rigid pavement systems; characterization of soils, materials, traffic loads, and environment for design; flexible and rigid pavement design; new developments.

courses.title: Public Works Engineering and Management Practices
courses.description: Public works profession, organization, administration, and management of operating divisions with emphasis on role of engineer.

courses.title: Transportation-Water-Materials Design
courses.description: Simulation of a design project experience through the completion and presentation of a comprehensive roadway project design. Students work in multi-disciplinary groups to complete a system design that includes traffic, materials, hydrologic and geotechnical considerations.

courses.title: Special Problems in Civil Engineering
courses.description: Selected problems or projects in the student's major field of engineering study.

courses.title: Structures-Geotechnical-Construction Comprehensive System Design
courses.description: Simulation of a design office experience through the completion and presentation of a comprehensive building design. Students work in multi-disciplinary groups to complete a system design that includes structural, geotechnical and construction management considerations.

courses.title: Co-op Work Experience
courses.description: Co-op work experience in a related field.

courses.title: Hydrodynamics
courses.description: Classification and properties of fluids, hydrostatics, and conservation of mass, momentum and energy in fluid flow. Potential flow, similitude and physical modeling. Laminar and turbulent pipe flow. Introduces turbomachines.

courses.title: Hydraulics
courses.description: Fundamental equations for pipe and open conduit flow. Development of design oriented formulas for pipes and open channels. Introduces hydrology.

courses.title: Urban Stormwater Systems Design
courses.description: Surface-water system design including: time of concentration, peak runoff rate, open-channel flow, gravity storm sewer, culvert, stormwater pumping, filtration systems, hydrograph generation, flood routing, site layout, site grading and permitting.

courses.title: Water Resources Engineering
courses.description: Study of water resources engineering applications including hydrology and statistics, groundwater, hydraulic machinery, dams and reservoirs, water quality, water quality modeling, water and waste-water treatment and water law and institutions.

courses.title: Engineering Directed Independent Research
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Water and Wastewater Treatment
courses.description: Design of water and wastewater treatment units.

courses.title: Transportation Engineering
courses.description: Overview of the significance of highway transportation to the social and economic underpinnings of society. Introduces road vehicle performance, geometric design of highways, traffic flow and queuing theory, highway capacity and level of service analysis, traffic control and analysis at signalized intersections, and travel demand and traffic forecasting.

courses.title: Urban Transportation Planning
courses.description: Overview of the four-step urban transportation planning process; includes analytical techniques for estimating future travel demand and state-of-the-art approaches.

courses.title: Traffic Engineering
courses.description: General review of the fundamentals of traffic engineering with emphasis on field studies and data analysis.

courses.title: Highway Capacity Analysis
courses.description: Provide students with detailed instruction on the procedures defined within the 2010 Highway Capacity Manual (HCM), including analytical chapters for uninterrupted and interrupted flow.

courses.title: Transportation Systems Analysis
courses.description: Systems analysis in transportation planning and engineering, including supply, demand, equilibrium, evaluation and decision analysis.

courses.title: Transportation Facility Design
courses.description: Simulates a comprehensive design of a transportation facility, specifically an arterial-freeway interchange. Utilizes state and national-level design manuals in preparation of standard plans. Applies the theoretical background gained in supporting classes, in areas such as traffic analysis, roadway design, roadway drainage, and pavement design. Some review of this material is provided, as well as introduction of several new concepts. Emphasizes teamwork skills and technical communication skills.

courses.title: Honors Professional Development
courses.description: Develop Career Related Skills to Succeed At Uf and Beyond.

courses.title: (Un)common read
courses.description: Discussion oriented courses centered around a single book.

courses.title: Honors Seminar
courses.description: Special topics restricted to those in the university-wide Honors Program. (WR)

courses.title: Interdisciplinary Junior Honors
courses.description: Special topics restricted to those in the university-wide honors program.

courses.title: Professional Development Strategies
courses.description: Helps select undergraduate students identify and compete for the most prestigious career-making scholarships by determining the activities and ideas most important and attractive to selection committees.

courses.title: Honors Tutorial
courses.description: Must be taken in conjunction with other courses at the 3000 and 4000 level. Students must secure instructor permission of the course to which they wish to add this credit.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: Restricted to those in the university-wide honors program.

courses.title: Honors Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Experiential learning in a variety of work locations. Permission of program director required. Supervision by a faculty member or delegated authority, daily journal and a post-internship report are required.

courses.title: Introduction to Czech Language and Culture 1
courses.description: CZE 1130 and its sequel, CZE 1131, offer a comprehensive introduction to Czech, using interactive methods to develop competence in speaking, listening, reading, writing and cultural interaction.

courses.title: Introduction to Czech Language and Culture 2
courses.description: Continuation of series. A comprehensive introduction to Czech, using interactive methods to develop competence in speaking, listening, reading, writing and cultural interaction.

courses.title: Intermediate Czech 1
courses.description: Builds reading and writing skills while continuing to develop conversational ability and listening comprehension. Using a communicative approach, provides an overview of Czech grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Czech 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study. Goal is to further develop speaking, listening, reading and writing skills.

courses.title: Modern Czech Culture and Society
courses.description: Overview of Czech literature, film, music, pop culture, and visual arts as shaped by the events from 1918 to the present.

courses.title: Personal Growth
courses.description: Introduces the concepts and techniques in psychology that apply to personal growth and development. All students have the opportunity to participate in research projects or alternative experiences. (S)

courses.title: Abnormal Psychology
courses.description: The varieties of disordered experience and conduct, and their contribution to an understanding of more effective personal and social adjustment. Includes the neuroses, psychoses and psychosomatic and conduct disturbances. (S)

courses.title: Introduction to Clinical Research
courses.description: Hands-on, faculty-supervised research experience in an area of interest. Introduces current research techniques, including the design and development of clinical research projects and data analysis. Three hours of laboratory work or other research activity (e.g., literature searches, grant preparation, recruitment of study participants, etc.) are required for each credit.

courses.title: Eating Disorders
courses.description: Overview of the causes and treatments associated with the full range of recognized eating disorders, including anorexia, bulimia and binge eating disorder, as well as a variety of subclinical forms of problematic eating behaviors and their surrounding factors and issues.

courses.title: Introduction to Clinical Child/Pediatric Psychology
courses.description: Survey and exploration of the science and practice of clinical child/pediatric psychology, including application of clinical science to problems faced by children and their families. Course also emphasizes assessment and intervention methodologies related to child behavior and health.

courses.title: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
courses.description: Survey and exploration of contemporary roles of clinical psychologists. Also emphasizes the integration of science and practice when solving problems of individuals, families, and groups.

courses.title: Introduction to Health Psychology
courses.description: Survey and exploration of the science and practice of clinical health psychology. Also emphasizes application of the biopsychosocial model of health and illness to health promotion, disease prevention, and the treatment and rehabilitation of existing illness and disability.

courses.title: Introduction to Neuropsychology
courses.description: Survey and exploration of the science and practice of clinical neuropsychology. Course also emphasizes discussion of major neuropsychological disorders and the mechanisms underlying higher cognitive function.

courses.title: Clinical and Behavioral Neuroanatomy and Lab
courses.description: Provides lecture and laboratory study of the human central nervous system and behaviors. Gain knowledge for engaging in basic clinical problem solving by laying a foundation of neurophysiological and neuroanatomical principles.

courses.title: Artificial Intelligence in Psychological and Brain Sciences
courses.description: Builds upon the artificial intelligence (AI) foundations taught in PHC 3793 to train health science-focused students to examine how AI and Machine Learning (ML) methods are applied in psychology and related brain sciences, as well as to address the factors that contribute to appropriate use of AI. The course neither provides nor necessitates prior programming knowledge, advanced statistical, or machine learning training.

courses.title: Body Basics: An Introduction to Human Anatomy and Physiology
courses.description: This introductory integrated anatomy and physiology course covers a broad range of basic biological and physiology concepts in the context of the human body. The presented concepts provide a basis for understanding the relations between structure and function from the chemical to organismal levels.

courses.title: Applied Human Anatomy with Laboratory
courses.description: Study of general anatomy of the human body from a systematic approach. Understanding anatomical terminology, gross structures, and locations of different body structures are primary concerns. Cells, tissues and organs of the integumentary, skeletal, muscular, nervous, circulatory, respiratory, digestive, urinary and reproductive systems are emphasized. (B)

courses.title: Applied Human Physiology with Laboratory
courses.description: Introduces body functions at the cellular, tissue, organ and systems level with emphasis on the mechanisms of operation. Designed for students interested in pursuing study in the health professions. (B)

courses.title: Physiology of Exercise and Training
courses.description: Survey in exercise physiology which provides an overview of the acute and chronic responses to exercise. Particular attention is placed on understanding muscle bioenergetics and metabolism as well as the cardiopulmonary responses to exercise. Special topics include exercise testing, training technologies and exercise in hot and cold environments.

courses.title: Principles of Strength and Conditioning
courses.description: For those interested in becoming certified personal trainers (NSCA-PT) or certified strength and conditioning specialists (CSCS) through the National Strength and Conditioning Association.

courses.title: Sport Nutrition
courses.description: Addresses the aspects of nutrition that are related to exercise performance. Emphasis is on bioenergetic systems, nutrient components, nutritional and body composition assessments, ergogenic aids and diet modifications for physically active individuals and athletes.

courses.title: Motor Learning
courses.description: Provides background for understanding, analyzing and teaching skills in sports and dance. Attention to specific aspects of psychomotor developments and theoretical models of skill acquisition.

courses.title: Biomechanical Basis of Movement
courses.description: Fundamentals of kinematics and kinetics related to human movement. Basics of biomechanics applied to the concepts of injury prevention and performance improvement. Overview of various biomechanical data collection and analysis.

courses.title: Introduction to Sport Psychology
courses.description: Provides an understanding of the science and practice of sport psychology from both a theoretical and applied perspective. The primary emphasis is on the educational and performance enhancement roles of the field with little discussion of clinical issues.

courses.title: Exercise Psychology
courses.description: Introduces exercise psychology. Topics include the effects of exercise on psychological well-being, exercise adherence and intervention from both theoretical and applied perspectives.

courses.title: Research Methods
courses.description: Provides an understanding of basic research methods and techniques used in applied physiology and kinesiology. Students will demonstrate their knowledge of the course materials by analyzing, interpreting and summarizing research writing in professional journals and by planning a research study.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Skeletal Muscle
courses.description: Provides a comprehensive background of skeletal muscle properties, focusing on key aspects of function at the protein, cellular, and whole organ level. Major topics include muscle contraction and force generation, fuel sources and energy utilization, growth and development, and an introduction to pathology.

courses.title: Kinetic Anatomy
courses.description: Provides in-depth coverage of musculoskeletal anatomy as a foundation for learning components of simple and complex motor tasks; emphasizes proper execution and analysis of joint movement and common exercises.

courses.title: Clinical Anatomy for the Exercise Sciences
courses.description: The course is designed for students to learn advanced dissection skills from a whole systems approach with the intent of practical application. The primary focus will involve human cadaver dissection. The role of anatomical structures as they relate to musculoskeletal injury mechanisms, evaluation, and rehabilitation will be emphasized.

courses.title: Advanced Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Provides a detailed understanding of acute and chronic responses to exercise. Particular attention is placed upon understanding the physiological responses to exercise at both a systems and cellular level. Emphasis is placed on muscle contractile properties, muscle bioenergetics and the endocrine responses to exercise.

courses.title: Neuromuscular Aspects of Exercise
courses.description: Provides an in-depth analysis of muscle structure and function; how muscles produce movement; adaptation of muscle to resistance training, endurance training and various manipulations used in rehabilitations; adaptation of muscle to disuse; and muscle responses to injury.

courses.title: Clinical Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Provides an understanding of recent advances in exercise physiology and exercise prescription for clinical populations. Particular attention is placed upon the study of acute and chronic responses to exercise in patients with cardiac, pulmonary, metabolic and musculoskeletal diseases.

courses.title: Physical Fitness Assessment and Exercise Prescription
courses.description: Techniques of assessing physical fitness using traditional and state of the art processes. Techniques of prescribing exercise programs based upon assessments of physical parameters. Supervised practical lab experiences in assessment and prescription in a clinical setting.

courses.title: Movement Neuroscience
courses.description: Covers both anatomical and physiological aspects of movement-related components of the nervous system from a functional perspective. Topics include: neuronal signaling; somatosensation; proprioception; nociception; vision and eye movements; audition; lower vs. upper motor neurons; cortical, basal ganglia and cerebellar regulation of movement; and posture.

courses.title: Artificial Intelligence for Movement Sciences
courses.description: Students will learn to apply AI technologies to the study of movement in healthy and diseased human populations. This course introduces students to programming and data visualization while covering classical concepts of machine learning (e.g. linear regression and classification, ensemble-based algorithm, clustering, and neural networks) and modern machine learning methods for images and video processing (e.g. convolutional neural networks and transformers).

courses.title: Variable Topics in Exercise and Sport Sciences
courses.description: Offered upon request to meet special interests that are not adequately provided in other courses.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Provides APK students the opportunity for involvement in supervised research experiences. "Research" is operationally defined here as mentored, but self-directed work that enables students to explore an issue of interest to them and to communicate the results to others.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Internship in applied physiology and kinesiology.

courses.title: Teaching Experience in APK
courses.description: Experience teaching as an undergraduate assistant; responsibilities meet the needs of the particular course and instructor, including, but not limited to, giving short lectures, holding study/discussion sections, grading, and helping with exam/quiz/assignment preparation and proctoring.

courses.title: Prevention and Care of Athletic Injuries
courses.description: Prevention of athletic injuries, including protective equipment, safe facilities and proper supervision of practice and contests. Recognition, referral and follow-up of injuries in athletics. Legal implications of athletic training.

courses.title: Principles of Athletic Training
courses.description: Provides the student with knowledge of basic principles of athletic training, including prevention, recognition and treatment of athletic injuries. Addresses the proper application of protective equipment, bracing/wrapping/taping techniques utilized by athletic trainers and introduces emergency management skills appropriate for sport.

courses.title: Professionalism and Communication in Sports Healthcare
courses.description: Foundational knowledge in professionalism, inter-professional cooperation, cultural competence, client interactions, and basic legal concepts related to sport and exercise.

courses.title: Emergency Management of Athletic Trauma
courses.description: Learn to recognize, assess, treat, and refer traumatic injury and acute emergent illness.

courses.title: Athletic Injury Assessment: Upper Extremity
courses.description: Provides background information to conduct a thorough initial evaluation of upper extremity injuries commonly sustained by the physically active population.

courses.title: Athlete Injury Assessment: Lower Extremity
courses.description: Provides background information to conduct a thorough initial evaluation of lower extremity injuries commonly sustained by the physically active population.

courses.title: Therapeutic Modalities in Athletic Training
courses.description: Introduces physiological principles, concepts and operational procedures of contemporary therapeutic modalities as they relate to the care and treatment of athletic injuries.

courses.title: Rehabilitation Techniques in Athletic Training
courses.description: Introduces the concepts and principles of a comprehensive rehabilitation program including determination of therapeutic goals and objectives, selection of therapeutic exercises, methods of evaluating and recording rehabilitation progress, development of criteria for progress and return to competition and the physiological effects of trauma/wound healing and inactivity/immobilization.

courses.title: Functional Sport Conditioning
courses.description: Enhances knowledge in design and implementation of functional exercise techniques as it relates to injury rehabilitation. Nutritional considerations for the injured athlete and proper design of the pre and post event meal planning for optimal performance and recovery are also covered.

courses.title: Clinical Pathology and Pharmacology
courses.description: Provides a thorough understanding of injury, illness and/or disease of various body systems; addresses specific understanding of medical diagnostics, interventions (including pharmacology) and participation considerations for the athletic population.

courses.title: Athletic Training Administration
courses.description: In-depth background of the standards, policies and practices of organization, supervision and administration of athletic training programs.

courses.title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience 1
courses.description: Provides the student with the opportunity necessary to grow both clinically and professionally within the field of athletic training through attendance at seminars, and the integration and synthesis of cognitive and psychomotor skills learned in previous semesters.

courses.title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience 2
courses.description: Provides the student with the opportunity necessary to grow both clinically and professionally within the field of athletic training through attendance at seminars, and the integration and synthesis of cognitive and psychomotor skills learned in previous semesters.

courses.title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience 3
courses.description: Provides the student with the opportunity necessary to grow both clinically and professionally within the field of athletic training through attendance at seminars, and the integration and synthesis of cognitive and psychomotor skills learned in previous semesters.

courses.title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience 4
courses.description: Provides the student with the opportunity necessary to grow both clinically and professionally within the field of athletic training through attendance at seminars, and the integration and synthesis of cognitive and psychomotor skills learned in previous semesters.

courses.title: Human Physiology
courses.description: Functioning of human tissues, organs and organ systems, emphasizing the physical, chemical and mechanistic bases of normal physiology and the integrated function of the human body. Also introduces pathophysiological changes associated with human diseases.

courses.title: Variable International Topics
courses.description: Provides the opportunity to study in a wide range of cultural settings.

courses.title: Practicum in Exercise and Sport Sciences
courses.description: Practical experience in such specialty areas as adult fitness programs, health clubs, exercise testing laboratories, clinical laboratories and athletic training rooms. May include senior thesis with oral defense.

courses.title: Composition Skills 1
courses.description: Required for all majors in theory/composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.title: Composition Skills 2
courses.description: Required for all majors in theory/composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.title: Composition Skills 3
courses.description: Required for all majors in composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.title: Composition Skills 4
courses.description: Required for all majors in composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through use of finale.

courses.title: Composition 1
courses.description: Composition in simple and extended forms supplemented by analysis of selected compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.title: Composition 2
courses.description: Composition in simple and extended forms supplemented by analysis of selected compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.title: Composition 3
courses.description: Composition in extended forms supplemented by analysis of selection compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.title: Composition 4
courses.description: Composition in extended forms supplemented by analysis of selection compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

courses.title: Introduction to Electroacoustic Music
courses.description: Survey of the techniques, history, literature and materials of electroacoustic music.

courses.title: Composition of Electroacoustic Music
courses.description: Continuation of MUC 4313. Projects in electroacoustic music dealing with real-time, interactivity, live-electronic and solo digital media music composition issues.

courses.title: Electroacoustic Music Composition: Digital 1
courses.description: Continuation of skills developed through MUC 4401, Composition of Electroacoustic Music.

courses.title: Electroacoustic Music Composition: Digital 2
courses.description: Continuation of skills developed through MUC 4441, Electroacoustic Music Composition: Digital 1.

courses.title: Senior Composition Recital
courses.description: Organization and presentation of a recital of original compositions.

courses.title: Exploring Music Teaching and Learning
courses.description: Introductory overview of music teaching as a profession. For those majoring in music education and those who are interested in a possible career as a music educator.

courses.title: Music Teaching as a Profession
courses.description: Overview of philosophical, historical, psychological, and sociological perspectives on music education in schools. Discusses contemporary topics and trends including diversity, special needs students, and culturally responsive pedagogy; introduces the Florida Educator Accomplished Practices (FEAPs). Field experience in schools.

courses.title: Voice Skills
courses.description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical technique for voice.

courses.title: String Skills 1
courses.description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for the upper string instruments: violin/viola.

courses.title: String Skills 2
courses.description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for the lower string instruments: cello and double bass.

courses.title: Woodwind Skills 1
courses.description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for clarinet and flute.

courses.title: Woodwind Skills 2
courses.description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for alto saxophone, bassoon and oboe.

courses.title: Brass Skills 1
courses.description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for two brass instruments.

courses.title: Brass Skills 2
courses.description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for two brass instruments, other than those studied in MUE 3460.

courses.title: Percussion Skills
courses.description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for percussion instruments.

courses.title: Percussion Skills 2
courses.description: Continuation of percussion teaching and performance skills.

courses.title: Music Learning with Technology
courses.description: Explores the role of digital technologies in creating, performing, and responding to music, with applications to the practice of K-12 music educators and the cultivation of lifelong music learning and participation.

courses.title: Music for the Elementary Child
courses.description: Helps meet state certification requirements for elementary classroom teachers. Function of elementary school music in aiding the developmental growth of children.

courses.title: Music in Elementary Schools
courses.description: Fundamental principles and procedures of music education in elementary school.

courses.title: Music in Secondary Schools
courses.description: Fundamental principles and procedures of music education in the secondary school.

courses.title: Materials and Methods of String Class Teaching
courses.description: The study of contemporary materials and methods suitable for use in public school string classes.

courses.title: Literature and Arranging for School Choirs
courses.description: Become familiar with techniques and approaches for selecting and programming literature for K-12 performing ensembles. Introduces fundamental techniques used to create arrangements of choral and vocal works in order to better meet the needs of individual singers or ensembles. Also addresses arranging for instruments.

courses.title: Literature and Arranging for Instrumental Ensembles
courses.description: Techniques for selecting, programming, and arranging music for school instrumental ensembles. Overview of repertoire and arranging techniques including genres, established works, composers, and publishers; pedagogical and practical considerations related to the selection and modification of music. Discussion of relevant copyright laws.

courses.title: Music Student Teaching Seminar
courses.description: Principles and practices of developing, teaching, and administering K-12 public school music programs.

courses.title: Teaching Secondary Choral Music
courses.description: Develop techniques and skills necessary to build and sustain a successful and comprehensive choral program in a secondary school setting. Students will synthesize and apply previous knowledge and skills related to vocal physiology and pedagogy, lesson and curriculum planning, sight-singing and musicianship, and other topics. Field experience in schools.

courses.title: Teaching Instrumental Music
courses.description: Develop musical and pedagogical knowledge, skills, and dispositions essential for teaching elementary, middle school, and high school instrumental music. Field work in schools.

courses.title: Marching Band Techniques
courses.description: Examination, evaluation and practical application of marching band techniques for the high school and college band director.

courses.title: Student Teaching in Music Education
courses.description: Student teaching in selected classrooms of public schools. Special seminars and continuous evaluation of teaching experiences.

courses.title: Internship in Music Teaching
courses.description: Build on the work done in previous music education coursework to develop competence in applying the principles of learning in K-12 music classrooms.

courses.title: Conducting 1
courses.description: Basic techniques of choral and instrumental conducting.

courses.title: Choral Conducting and Materials
courses.description: Basic techniques of choral conducting, score analysis, interpretation and use of basic choral materials.

courses.title: Instrumental Conducting and Materials
courses.description: Basic techniques of instrumental conducting, score analysis, interpretation and use of basic instrumental materials.

courses.title: Introduction to World Musics
courses.description: Introduction to musics of non-western cultures in comparison with music of Western European civilizations; the nature of music and the realm of ethnomusicology. (H and N)

courses.title: Popular Music in the USA: From Ragtime to Hip-Hop and Beyond
courses.description: Surveys the musical styles, artists, audiences, and eras of American popular music in relation to the social, cultural, political, and historical contexts in which they emerged. Gives special attention to the diversity and intersecting nature of musical voices in the USA through the examination of musical styles including rock, rhythm and blues, country, punk, hip-hop, salsa, and beyond.

courses.title: Music History Survey 1
courses.description: A survey of music literature, styles, and techniques from antiquity to c. 1750. Examines representative repertoire from historical, theoretical, and cultural contexts and develops critical thinking skills in reading, writing, analysis, and listening.

courses.title: Music History Survey 2
courses.description: Surveys music literature, styles, and techniques from c. 1750 to the present day, and examines representative repertoire from historical, theoretical, and cultural contexts. Also develops critical-thinking skills in reading, writing, analysis, and listening.

courses.title: Popular and Traditional Musics of Africa
courses.description: A study of traditional and popular African musical styles placed within their historical, social and cultural environments. (H and N)

courses.title: Music and Healing in Contemporary Africa
courses.description: Explores the historical role of music in healing traditions across African by exploring practices based around dance, religion, ritual and modern health care methodologies. Outlines the changing historical perspectives of Western rational thought on art-based practices, contextualizing contemporary approaches throughout the continent.

courses.title: Latin American Music
courses.description: The variable musical expressions of Latin America (including the Caribbean), their historical formations and social importance. (H and N)

courses.title: Jewish Art Music in Western Culture
courses.description: Cultural history of western art music inspired by Jewish subjects, Biblical and non-Biblical, composed by both Jewish and non-Jewish composers, and a survey of Jewish performing musicians from the Renaissance to the present. (H and N)

courses.title: History of Jazz
courses.description: From African, Latin American, and Black American sources through contemporary development.

courses.title: African Popular Music and Globalization
courses.description: This course engages with a wide variety of African popular musics in different contexts of transformation, with the main objective of developing and nuancing our understanding of what “popular music” means in Africa within histories of culture contact. The course will provide foundational understanding of the field of ethnomusicology and popular music studies, with particular attention to how African music has been impacted by globalization through its contact with the West.

courses.title: Jazz, Hip Hop, and African Connections
courses.description: Considers how African music and culture have influenced African American musical expression since the beginning of the transatlantic slave trade and up through the development of the blues, jazz, soul music, hip hop, and RB. Also considers how such cultural flows have moved in both directions, from the foundations of African American music in African aesthetics, to the ways that jazz and hip-hop musicians have made explicit reference or taken inspiration from Africa.

courses.title: Timbre: Critical Discussions
courses.description: Critically examines timbre by engaging with the following questions: What is timbre, and how is it related to sound? What scholarship has addressed timbre and in what ways? How can timbre be effectively discussed and written about? By exploring timbre in classical and popular music genres, as well as in specific works, and by considering timbre through lenses such as music education and race, seek to better understand what some scholars argue is a rather nebulous phenomenon.

courses.title: Music and Audience
courses.description: Considers the role and function of the audience in conjunction with the symphony, opera, and ballet. Historical readings cover what audiences were like in the Classical Period, Romantic Era, and the Twentieth Century, and major masterworks of those time periods are discussed. The modern audience is considered by discussing recent publications in various mediums and attending two live concerts.

courses.title: Special Topics in Music History
courses.description: Rotating topics of current or special interest to students or instructors.

courses.title: Experiencing Music
courses.description: In this course, students will survey the history of classical music from antiquity to the modern period, focusing on Western music. The curriculum may also integrate a variety of popular and global styles where appropriate.

courses.title: Baroque Literature
courses.description: Compositions of Monteverdi, Gabrieli, Schultz, Buxtehude, Bach, Handel and others.

courses.title: The American Musical: Broadway and Beyond
courses.description: Provides non-music majors and music minors with an introduction to the history and development of the American musical, focusing on the genre's relationship to American culture and society. Topics include musical and dramatic features of specific works, principal creators and performers, commercialization and popularity, the genre's relationship to film, its role in the formation of America's national identity, and its communication of American values, attitudes and norms with regard to different cultures. (H)

courses.title: Renaissance Literature
courses.description: Renaissance literature surveys the music from the period roughly 1430-1600, stressing the major genres of mass, motet, madrigal and chanson, and touching on less prominent regional practices and instrumental music. The music is placed into social and historical context. (H and N)

courses.title: Romantic Literature
courses.description: Representative Romantic literature in such genres as the symphony, symphonic poem, opera, song, chamber music, piano music and sacred music. Composers from Beethoven through Mahler. (H and N)

courses.title: Contemporary Literature
courses.description: Twentieth-century music literature, including works of Debussy, Ravel, Stravinsky, Schoenberg, Webern, Berg, Hindemith, Bartok, Copland, Sessions, Boulez and Stockhausen. (H and N)

courses.title: Piano Literature Seminar
courses.description: A survey of piano literature from early keyboard works to the present.

courses.title: Woodwind Literature Seminar
courses.description: An intensive, investigative study of representative repertoire for woodwind instruments.

courses.title: Brass Literature Seminar
courses.description: An intensive, investigative study of standard repertoire for brass instruments.

courses.title: Percussion Literature Seminar
courses.description: An intensive, investigative study of standard repertoire for solo percussion and percussion ensemble.

courses.title: Organ Literature Seminar
courses.description: A survey of the major trends and styles of organ composition from the Renaissance to the present.

courses.title: Song Literature Seminar
courses.description: The study and performance of representative literature for the voice from each style period.

courses.title: History and Literature of Opera
courses.description: Offered in Miami only.

courses.title: The Music of J.S. Bach
courses.description: Offered in Miami only. The works of Bach with special emphasis on the historical sources of his choral and instrumental styles and detailed study of a selection of his chief works.

courses.title: The Music of W.A. Mozart
courses.description: Offered in Miami only. The music, life and times of Mozart.

courses.title: Found Music Business
courses.description: This course is intended (1) to foster a comprehensive and chronological understanding of the music business, and (2) to observe how rapid changes in the global music industry challenge music professionals and music business organizations to become more entrepreneurial in their planning and practice.

courses.title: Music Entrepreneurship Dev
courses.description: This course is intended to equip music students with a comprehensive foundation, resources, and skill set for improving marketability and success as a music entrepreneur upon graduation. Students will develop various skills for understanding and engaging in business, legalities, communication arts, innovative content creation, and niche development within music entrepreneurship.

courses.title: Music Production in Commercial Media
courses.description: Equips music students with a comprehensive foundation, resources, and skill set for improving marketability and success as a music entrepreneur upon graduation. Students will develop various skills for understanding and engaging in business, legalities, communication arts, innovative content creation, and niche development within music entrepreneurship.

courses.title: Multimedia Production for the Music Industry
courses.description: This course is intended to develop independent music professionals’ skills for creating enthralling multimedia content and implementing strategic communication strategies for (1) applying effective target marketing via online platforms, (2) increasing employability for multimedia music presentations, and (3) expanding vocational opportunities within various sectors of the music industry.

courses.title: Capstone Project I
courses.description: Synthesizing vocational interests with theory and practice by engaging in music business/entrepreneurship-related research and practice in the early stages of development of, or refinement of, a business plan, Projects reflect a comprehensive application of music business and entrepreneurship concepts. First of two capstone courses.

courses.title: Capstone Project 2
courses.description: Synthesize vocational interests with theory and practice by engaging in music business/entrepreneurship-related research and practice in the final stages of development of, or refinement of, a business plan. Projects reflect a comprehensive application of music business and entrepreneurship concepts. Second of two capstone courses.

courses.title: Marching Band
courses.description: Performance of marching band literature.

courses.title: Concert Band
courses.description: Performance of general and popular band literature. (H)

courses.title: Symphonic Band
courses.description: Performance of traditional and contemporary band literature. (H)

courses.title: Wind Symphony
courses.description: Performance of wind ensemble literature. (H)

courses.title: University Orchestra
courses.description: Standard orchestra literature. (H)

courses.title: University Choir
courses.description: An advanced choral group providing specialized study performance opportunities for vocally qualified students. (H)

courses.title: Women's Chorale
courses.description: Vocal training and public performances of standard female chorus repertoire. (H)

courses.title: Men's Glee Club
courses.description: Vocal training and public performance of tenor-bass chorus repertoire. Course literature is drawn from a variety of historical periods (including selections from the Western canon), cultures, and musical styles, presenting students with varied perspectives and experiences. Students explore the key elements of the literature including the origin, historical context, and form of song texts, compositional techniques, and performance practices.

courses.title: Choral Union
courses.description: Mixed choral ensemble open to students, faculty, staff, and local residents who have previous choral experience. Course literature is drawn from a variety of historical periods, cultures, and musical styles, presenting students with varied perspectives and experiences.

courses.title: Percussion Ensemble
courses.description: The study and performance of ensemble literature for percussion instruments. (H)

courses.title: Chamber Music Ensemble
courses.description: Examination and performance of standard repertoire for chamber ensembles.

courses.title: Jazz Bands
courses.description: Standard and experimental jazz ensembles. A jazz laboratory. (H)

courses.title: World Music Ensemble – African Popular Music Ensemble
courses.description: Specializes in the popular music of the African continent, with a special focus on Afrobeat, highlife, soukous, African jazz, and the brass band traditions of Africa and the diaspora.

courses.title: Laptop and Electronic Arts Ensemble
courses.description: Explores composing and coding for and performance with live electronic musical instruments. Also covers fundamentals of sound synthesis, audio programming, instrument design, human-computer interaction, sound-driven multimedia, data sonification, and electronic concert production and documentation. Using the instruments that they design, students perform their electronic works and works of their colleagues during a two concert experiences over the course of the semester.

courses.title: World Music Ensemble
courses.description: The rehearsal and performance of folk and traditional musics of the world. (H)

courses.title: Commercial Music Ensemble
courses.description: Provides the tools and experience necessary to excel as musicians in the commercial music world. Analyze, study, arrange, and perform a variety of commercial styles including rock, pop, jazz, funk, alternative, country, soul, RB, Latin, World, and more.

courses.title: Marching Band
courses.description: Performance of marching band literature.

courses.title: Concert Band
courses.description: Performance of general and popular band literature.

courses.title: Symphonic Band
courses.description: Performance of traditional and contemporary band literature.

courses.title: Wind Symphony
courses.description: Performance of wind ensemble literature. (H)

courses.title: University Orchestra
courses.description: Standard orchestra literature. (H)

courses.title: University Choir
courses.description: An advanced choral group providing specialized study performance opportunities for vocally qualified students. (H)

courses.title: Women's Chorale
courses.description: Vocal training and public performances of standard female chorus repertoire.

courses.title: Men's Glee Club
courses.description: Vocal training and public performance of standard male chorus repertoire.

courses.title: University Chamber Singers
courses.description: Study and performance of early and contemporary vocal literature. (H)

courses.title: Choral Union
courses.description: Mixed choral ensemble open to students, faculty, staff, and local residents who have previous choral experience. Course literature is drawn from a variety of historical periods, cultures, and musical styles, presenting students with varied perspectives and experiences.

courses.title: Two Piano Literature
courses.description: Offered in Miami only.

courses.title: Chamber Music
courses.description: Exploration of the assigned repertoire through weekly one-hour coaching sessions with the instructor, a minimum of three hours weekly of unsupervised group rehearsal and a final performance by each group on the class recital. Students will study the art of chamber music interpretation and performance and develop effective group rehearsal technique.

courses.title: New Music Ensemble
courses.description: Rehearsal and performance of repertoire for small ensembles written in the 20th and 21st centuries.

courses.title: Musical Theatre Ensemble
courses.description: Offered in Miami only. Examination and performance of standard repertoire for the musical theatre.

courses.title: Jazz Bands
courses.description: Standard and experimental jazz ensembles. A jazz laboratory.

courses.title: Jazz Chamber Music 1
courses.description: Small group ensemble performance experience in the jazz idiom. Students will memorize jazz standards and learn melody interpretation techniques, rhythmic techniques to communicate to other members of the ensemble and small group compositional techniques for harmonizing jazz standards and original compositions.

courses.title: World Music Ensemble - African Popular Music Ensemble
courses.description: Specializes in the popular music of the African continent, with a special focus on Afrobeat, highlife, soukous, African jazz, and the brass band traditions of Africa and the diaspora.

courses.title: Ensemble Participation
courses.description: Ensemble of variable instrumentation and/or voices performing traditional and contemporary repertoire. For upper-division students who have completed required credits of ensemble participation or elective credits for their degree program, this ensemble exists to allow them to continue performing in ensembles without impacting semester load credits, or excess hours credits. This course allows students from any degree to continue participation in ensembles in support of the university.

courses.title: Musical Theatre Instrumental Ensemble
courses.description: Provides an intermediate understanding of musical theatre instrumental styles and practices from the 1930s to the present. Incorporating one or more of these forms and techniques each semester, it’s recommended for musicians who would like to broaden their commercial repertoire and enhance their skills for professional engagements.

courses.title: Music Internship Ensemble
courses.description: Provides supervised, evaluated, and practical music business-related training in music ensembles on- and off-campus, such as facilitating audio and media products (recordings and promotional videos), marketing materials (flyers and social media advertisements), and managerial tasks that advance designated ensemble success.

courses.title: Opera Workshop
courses.description: Study and performance of works from opera and operetta.

courses.title: Music and the Catholic Church
courses.description: Examines the music of the Catholic Church from historical and artistic perspectives and presents issues that have surrounded major changes in the church's music. Focuses on six historical periods in which the church was significantly focused on musical developments or changes. Views the music from various cultural perspectives, primarily US and European.

courses.title: Recital Attendance
courses.description: Attendance at concerts and recitals. Check the School of Music student's handbook for specific attendance requirements.

courses.title: Digital Musicianship and Production
courses.description: Provides the fundamentals of music technology in the context of its historical and cultural use. Addresses scientific foundations of acoustics, hearing, and digital audio as well as technical skills for music production; students will work on practical applications of these concepts and techniques. Furthermore, the instructor will encourage students to critically explore cultural aspects of music technology.

courses.title: An Echo of the Invisible World: Exploring the Relationship Between Music & Spirituality
courses.description: Examines the relationship between music and spirituality, within and outside the context of organized religion. Consider the underlying philosophies in spiritual music and practices, compare them to contemporary American culture, and address their own beliefs and practices through selected case studies and projects.

courses.title: English Diction
courses.description: An English diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.

courses.title: French Diction
courses.description: A French diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.

courses.title: German Diction
courses.description: A German diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.
