courses.description: Examines key issues of politics that exist at regional, state and local levels such as campaign finance reform, lobbying, political action committees, political corruption, racial and civil rights issues, and state and local relations.

courses.title: Asian American Politics
courses.description: Examines the political behavior, attitudes and mobilization of Asian Americans in America by studying the racial stereotypes that plague them, their electoral behavior, the mobilizations tactics utilized in their communities, their response to violent crimes against members of their group and crime within their communities, Asian American conservatism, their views on affirmative action and the politics of Asian American women.

courses.title: American Politics and the Media
courses.description: Addresses changes in American media over time as they relate to American politics. Includes attention to print media, talk radio, social media, bias, fake news, how media shape citizen behavior and attitudes, and media coverage of political institutions, campaigns, domestic politics, and foreign policy.

courses.title: Politics in Fiction and Film
courses.description: Uses make-believe stories told in popular novels and Hollywood motion pictures to provide insights into the nature of real-life politics in the United States. (WR)

courses.title: Ethics in American Politics
courses.description: The problem of unethical behavior involving elected officials is a perennial concern in American politics. How do political ethics differ, if at all, from private ethics? What causes corruption? What have been the aims of good-government reformers?

courses.title: Modern Political Campaigns
courses.description: Explores major issues associated with modern political campaigns. Presidential campaigns are a primary, but not exclusive, focus. Investigates why modern campaigns take the forms they do, and to place them in broader American and political contexts. This is not a course on how to run campaigns; it is a course on understanding campaign politics.

courses.title: Religion and Politics in the United States
courses.description: Investigates the role of religious institutions, values and communities in contemporary American political life. (WR)

courses.title: Politics of Modernity
courses.description: Focuses on the core elements of modernity: the transitions from traditional to modern political identities, from subsistence production to capitalism, and from less to more complex forms of political authority, whether democratic or not. This course also introduces advanced undergraduates in political science to the development of the central themes in comparative politics.

courses.title: The Presidency
courses.description: The central role of the American Presidency in the political process. Emphasizes the contemporary institutional nature of that office and the behavior of its occupants.

courses.title: Legislative Politics
courses.description: The politics of the legislative process, recruitment of legislators, formal and informal rules of behavior, legislative-executive relations and the committee system. Also discusses the impact of political parties, interest groups and constituents on the legislative process.

courses.title: Political Parties and Elections
courses.description: Composition, organization and structure of political parties and their roles and relationships in the political process.

courses.title: Interest Group Politics
courses.description: Examines the theoretical foundations, historical context and current activities of special interest groups in the United States.

courses.title: Race, Law and the Constitution
courses.description: Surveys the historical and contemporary response of the law enforcement, civil and criminal justice, and corrections systems to minority and ethnic groups in the United States.

courses.title: Political Change and Legal Development
courses.description: Introduces the role of law in political and social development by providing a background in social theory and the history of legal systems, beginning with Roman law.

courses.title: Research Methods in Political Science
courses.description: Introduces the theory and method of contemporary political analysis. Emphasizes alternative analytical frameworks, concepts, research design, variables, measurement, and quantitative analysis of political data.

courses.title: Survey Research
courses.description: Prepares students to understand, conduct, analyze and assess opinion surveys and polls. Covers how to decide whether and when surveys are appropriate means of data collection, how to put together a survey, how to conduct basic quantitative analysis of survey data and how to report the findings.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: Readings and discussion in advanced topics of political science.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in American Politics
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Special Topics in Political Science
courses.description: Selected topics in political science; precise course content will be announced in advance.

courses.title: Honors Preparation
courses.description: Must be taken in conjunction with other political science courses at the 3000/4000 level. Required for students pursuing the department honors program.

courses.title: Political Internship
courses.description: Internship in government and politics. Internships are available at all levels - local, state and federal - and in every branch of government - executive, legislative and judicial. Other internships are available with political parties, interest groups, lobbying organizations, international organizations and private companies engaged in governmental relations and issue research. Readings and paper required. Only three credits of POS /PAD 4940 credit may be counted toward the major.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.description: One of three required courses for students who are writing an honors thesis. Students work under the supervision of their thesis advisor. Generally, this course is taken in the second semester of the one-year thesis process. Students receive a letter grade for their work.

courses.title: Introduction to Political Theory
courses.description: Basic principles of political thought. Examines the nature of the state and of the relationship between the individual and the state. Covers topics such as authority, consent, freedom and obligation. (H)

courses.title: Political Ideologies
courses.description: Seeks understanding of the contemporary spectrum of political beliefs from liberal democracy to the ideological ideas of the far right. Examines the effects of ethical, historical, political, and psychological perspectives on these belief systems.

courses.title: Environmental Ethics and Politics
courses.description: An intensive investigation into the history and theory of environmental ethical and political thought.

courses.title: Great Political Thinkers: Ancient and Medieval
courses.description: Major early political theorists including Plato, Aristotle, St. Augustine, and St. Thomas Aquinas. Emphasizes the principles of a just political order: natural law, civic virtue, and constitutionalism. Analysis of church-state struggles and the emergence of the modern state.

courses.title: Great Political Thinkers: Machiavelli to Marx
courses.description: Studies selected political theorists from Machiavelli to Marx. Emphasizes the ideas of authority and freedom, obligation and consent in the writing of Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, etc. Liberalism, conservatism, utilitarianism, and idealism.

courses.title: American Political Thought
courses.description: Examines the history of American political thought, including an analysis of Thomas Jefferson and the Declaration of Independence, the federalist papers and the ideology of Thomas Paine. Also includes African American political thought, feminist political theories, liberalism, and the contribution of Mark Twain.

courses.title: Problems of Democracy
courses.description: The theory and practice of democracy, especially ideas that define a democratic order. Studies selected topics ranging from equality and majority rule to technology and the globalization of democracy. (WR)

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Political Theory
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Current Controversies in Public Policy
courses.description: Framework to understand the formation, adoption, budgeting, implementation and evaluation of public policy. This framework provides a basis for detailed discussions and debates about current policy issues.

courses.title: Women in Politics
courses.description: Analyzes the roles women play in American politics, including political behavior and public policy issues.

courses.title: Florida Environmental Politics
courses.description: Examines the politics of environmental transformation in Florida, including issues of water supply, growth management and Everglades restoration. Supplements the department's offerings in environmental politics. Can be used to satisfy requirements for the major or minor in political science, but it is also intended for (and accessible to) interested students in any major.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Public Policy
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Public Policy. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Public Policy.

courses.title: Introduction to Russian Language and Culture 1
courses.description: RUS 1130 and its sequel, RUS 1131, offer a comprehensive introduction to Russian, using interactive methods to develop competence in speaking, listening, reading, writing and cultural interaction.

courses.title: Introduction to Russian Language and Culture 2
courses.description: Continuation of introductory language and cultural study.

courses.title: Intermediate Russian 1
courses.description: Intermediate study with exercises in sentence patterns, vocabulary building and oral and written discourse in Russian.

courses.title: Russian for Heritage Learners
courses.description: A practical overview of Russian grammar and writing for those with significant bilingual speaking and listening backgrounds. Devotes special attention to reading, writing and vocabulary development.

courses.title: Oral Practice in Russian
courses.description: Development of advanced speaking and listening skills in conversational Russian.

courses.title: Intermediate Russian 2
courses.description: Continued study with exercises in sentence patterns, vocabulary building and sustained oral and written discourse.

courses.title: Advanced Russian 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Russian 2
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Grammar and Composition
courses.description: Study of advanced grammar and composition in Russian.

courses.title: Advanced Oral Practice
courses.description: Continued development of advanced speaking and listening skills based on authentic written, audio and video texts from contemporary Russian culture.

courses.title: Russian Studies Research Seminar
courses.description: Introduces significant trends and ideas in Russian literary, cultural, historical, and critical studies. Develop the ability to understand and produce critical scholarly argument in a variety of formats, including class discussion, formal presentation, and a written research project.

courses.title: Language and Culture of the Russian Business World
courses.description: Combines advanced language training, a practical introduction to the language and culture of the contemporary Russian business world, and extensive practice translating and interpreting texts used in business settings. Focuses on issues such as starting companies and joint ventures, advertising, and setting up and conducting official meetings and telephone calls. Basic Russian business ethics are also studied.

courses.title: Theory and Practice of Russian-English Translation 1
courses.description: First part of a two-part translation series focusing on the theory and practice of conveying word semantics in Russian-English and English-Russian translation.

courses.title: Theory and Practice of Russian-English Translation 2
courses.description: Second part of the translation series focusing on the theory and practice of conveying sentence and paragraph semantics in Russian-English and English-Russian translation.

courses.title: Structure of the Russian Language
courses.description: Introduction to the phonology, morphology and syntax of contemporary standard Russian from a formal and semantic standpoint. Also includes the development of Russian word stress and a survey of the development of Russian verb tense, aspect and mood.

courses.title: Corrective Phonetics and Intonation
courses.description: Develops advanced-level phonetic and intonational skills via a variety of genres of authentic texts from Russian culture.

courses.title: Individual Work in Russian
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Russian Language
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Russian Language. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Russian Language.

courses.title: Special Topics in Russian
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Russian studies. New, experimental, or one-time offerings.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Russian Masterpieces
courses.description: Introduces the Russian literature of the 19th-21st centuries. Read some of the most influential works by Pushkin, Gogol, Tolstoy, Dostoevsky, Chekhov, Nabokov, Pasternak and Sorokin, thereby gaining essential knowledge of Russian history, culture and the authors personal lives. Readings and discussions in English. (H and N)

courses.title: Tolstoy and Dostoevsky
courses.description: Introduction to the major 19th century Russian novelists and their contemporaries. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Themes from Russian Literature
courses.description: Examines Russian everyday life and institutions of the 19th and 20th centuries through the media of literature and film.

courses.title: War and Peace
courses.description: Offers a close reading of Tolstoys epic novel War and Peace. Examines the literary and historical origins of the novel, its reflection of Tolstoy's obsession with history, and the emerging picture it presents of Russian identity. Taught in English.

courses.title: Russian Literature of the Twentieth Century
courses.description: Authors, movements, and genres in Russian literature from the Revolution of 1917 to the present. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Russian Cultural Heritage
courses.description: Introduces the culture of pre-revolutionary Russia. Philosophical, religious, artistic, and literary currents in relation to Western civilization. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Contemporary Russian Culture and Society
courses.description: Patterns of continuity and change in the philosophical and cultural values of Russian society as they explain the Soviet Union and contemporary Russia. Readings and discussions in English. (H)

courses.title: Violence and Terror in the Russian Experience
courses.description: Examines the impact of violence and terror on the human condition as reflected and expressed in well-known works of Russian literature (fiction and historical narratives), art and film. Taught in English. No knowledge of other languages required.

courses.title: Russia Today
courses.description: Patterns of continuity and change in the philosophical and cultural values of Russian society as they explain the Soviet Union and contemporary Russia. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Creative Lives: Writers, Artists, and Extraordinary People
courses.description: Explores Russian visions of creativity and creative people in Russian culture by placing them in dialogue with broader European and American models and considerations of creativity.

courses.title: Russian Fairy Tales
courses.description: Critical introduction to Russian fairy tales and folklore and an examination of the aesthetic, social, cultural, and psychological values they reflect.

courses.title: Russia through Film
courses.description: Examines Russian life, institutions, and the arts against the background of period-defining historical, political, and cultural events from the early twentieth century to the present day as reflected and refracted in some emblematic feature films, documentaries, and animated cartoon films produced in the Soviet Union and post-Soviet Russia.

courses.title: Russia's Struggle with Nature: Legacies of Destruction and Preservation
courses.description: Explores competing concepts of nature in modern Russian culture through works of Russian fiction and non-fiction in translation. Emphasis falls on environmental problems in Russia and the former Soviet Union (desiccation of the Aral Sea, pollution of Lake Baikal, the Chernobyl nuclear accident etc.) and their impact on Russian thought.

courses.title: The Twentieth Century through Slavic Eyes
courses.description: Introduces the literature, film, and culture of 20th century Eastern and Central Europe.

courses.title: Variable Topics in Russian Studies
courses.description: Variable topics in Russian studies, taught in English translation.

courses.title: Pushkin and Gogol
courses.description: Major works of Russian literature written in the first half of the 19th century. Readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Russian Modernism
courses.description: Introduces the major artistic contributions of Russian modernism in the context of the political, social, and cultural upheavals of late Imperial to Stalinist Russia (1890 - 1939).

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Russian Studies, English Translation
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Variable Topics in Russian Studies
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in Russian studies, taught in English translation.

courses.title: Reading Russian Literature
courses.description: In-depth study of the vocabulary, structures, reading strategies and cultural background needed for understanding and interpreting a broad range of Russian prose fiction.

courses.title: Russian Drama and Poetry
courses.description: Study of plays and poems by major Russian writers from the 19th and 20th centuries. Readings in Russian.

courses.title: Russian Media Culture
courses.description: In-depth study of the history and recent trends in the Russian mass media and web-based technology and their impact on culture and society.

courses.title: Russian Short Prose
courses.description: Critical study of selected Russian short stories. Readings in Russian.

courses.title: Reading Eugene Onegin: Pushkin and Nabokov
courses.description: An in-depth study of one of Russia's most revered literary works, combining close readings of Pushkin's original with analyses of operatic, artistic and cinematic adaptations by Chaikovsky, Nabokov and others. Readings and discussions primarily in Russian.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Russian Studies, Target Language
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Selected Readings in Russian
courses.description: Special topic, author, genre, or movement in Russian literature.

courses.title: The Culture of the Cold War
courses.description: Examines Soviet and American cultural responses to the Cold War across a wide range of media (literature, film, propaganda). Consideration of how relations between the US and the USSR were framed as a global ideological contest.

courses.title: African Humanities
courses.description: Similar in philosophy and purpose to the basic sequence, with content selected from the philosophies, literature, arts, and music of various African countries and regions.

courses.title: African Cultures and Literatures
courses.description: A culturally based study of folktales, proverbs, drama, poetry and novels; and how these forms are used to portray African arts and ideas.

courses.title: Language in African Society
courses.description: The role of language in the development of African societies. Language and nation building.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course.

courses.title: Special Topics in African Studies
courses.description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in African studies.

courses.title: African Elements in the Americas
courses.description: Traces African influence in the Americas from the arrival of Africans on the continent until the present.

courses.title: Africa through Film & Media
courses.description: Explore the African continent through film and media to provide a critical analysis of issues of (mis)/representation of Africans in selected moving images and printed materials both in Africa and in diaspora.

courses.title: African Oral Literature
courses.description: An overview of African oral literature, introduces methodological and theoretical problems, and examines the sociopolitical and cultural relevance of the literature.

courses.title: Beginning Akan 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Akan 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Akan 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Akan 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study.

courses.title: Advanced Akan 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Akan 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study.

courses.title: Beginning Amharic 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Amharic 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermed Amharic 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Amharic 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study.

courses.title: Advanced Amharic 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Amharic 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study.

courses.title: Swahili Oral Literature
courses.description: Introduces various genres of Swahili oral literatures and shows their importance, relevance, and function within Swahili culture.

courses.title: Beginning Swahili 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Swahili 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Swahili 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Swahili 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Advanced Swahili 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Swahili 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course.

courses.title: Readings in Swahili
courses.description: Readings in Swahili

courses.title: Beginning Wolof 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Wolof 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Wolof 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Wolof 2
courses.description: Continuation of intermediate study.

courses.title: Advanced Wolof 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Wolof 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Language in African Society
courses.description: The role of language in the development of African societies. Language and nation building.

courses.title: Beginning Yoruba 1
courses.description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.title: Beginning Yoruba 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Yoruba 1
courses.description: Intermediate study of the four skills with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Yoruba 2
courses.description: Continued study of the four skills with additional vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Advanced Yoruba 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Advanced Yoruba 2
courses.description: Continuation of advanced study of the four skills with attention to more complex structures.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course.

courses.title: Yoruba Diaspora in the New World
courses.description: Introduction to the scope and importance of Yoruban culture in the New World and its role and significance in the resilience of African cultures in North America, South America and the Caribbean. (WR)

courses.title: Readings in Yoruba Literature
courses.description: Reading skills and the analysis of literature in the original language.

courses.title: American Sign Language 1
courses.description: First in a series on American Sign Language concepts and principles; introduces receptive and expressive skills in formal and informal interactions. Signs, fingerspelling, numbers, and classifiers are practiced in conversational and storytelling contexts. Also introduces ASL literature and cultural information.

courses.title: American Sign Language 2
courses.description: Second in a series on American Sign Language concepts and principles; develops receptive and expressive skills in formal and informal interactions. Signs, fingerspelling, numbers, classifiers, and indexing are practiced in conversational and storytelling contexts. Familiarization with ASL culture and literary genres continues.

courses.title: American Sign Language 3
courses.description: Advanced study of American Sign Language.

courses.title: Special Topics in Communication
courses.description: Seminar study of theory and research in a specific area of communication.

courses.title: Honors Seminar
courses.description: Special topics restricted to those in the university-wide Honors Program. (WR)

courses.title: The Sounds of Human Language
courses.description: Emphasizes the sounds employed in languages of the world for a comprehensive understanding of the mechanism underlying the production of speech sounds and the ability to recognize, distinguish and phonetically transcribe speech sounds from an unfamiliar language. Includes investigation of the patterning and functions of sounds in languages of the world and application of the methods of analyzing a language sound system.

courses.title: Individual Study in Linguistics
courses.description: Individual study for linguistics majors.

courses.title: Phonetics
courses.description: Phonetics is the study of speech sounds. Phonology is the study of the sound system of a language. In this class we are particularly interested in how the speech sounds of American English are made, and how we use the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) to represent sounds but we also will look at the science behind the production of speech sounds.

courses.title: Speech Acoustics
courses.description: Introduces scientific methodologies, physics of sound, acoustics and elementary instrumentation related to human speech communication.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Hearing
courses.description: Concepts and principles relevant to the normal hearing processes: acoustics, gross anatomy, psychophysical methods, and basic subjective correlates of the auditory system.

courses.title: Speech Anatomy and Physiology
courses.description: Introduces elementary anatomy, physiology and neurophysiology of the speaking mechanism.

courses.title: Deaf Culture in America
courses.description: Provides an overview of the lives and experiences of deaf and hard of hearing persons and examines the reasons why many deaf people consider themselves to belong to a unique cultural group. Discussions focus on deaf communities and cultures, signed languages, education, accessibility, literature, and other issues.

courses.title: Critical Review of Scientific Evidence
courses.description: Provides scientific process concepts (inductive and deductive reasoning, foundations of inductive statistics, research design) as well as offering practice in critical thinking and avoiding the cognitive illusions that lead to invalid conclusions. The goal is to become critical consumers of information.

courses.title: Language Development
courses.description: Examines typical patterns of language development across the life span. Various theoretical perspectives on language acquisition are presented and current information regarding the biological, social, and cognitive bases for language will be reviewed. Major communicative achievements that characterize the various stages of language development will be discussed.

courses.title: Clinical Observations in Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology
courses.description: Supervised clinical observations of diagnostics and remediation at the UF Speech and Hearing Clinic.

courses.title: Neural Basis of Communication
courses.description: Understanding the structures and functions of the human nervous system and the neurological processes involved in communication and communication disorders.

courses.title: Neuroplasticity and Rehabilitation
courses.description: Introduces foundational knowledge about neuroplasticity and how it impacts treatment design and implementation across all health sciences. Also introduces different types of rehabilitation approaches offered by the various health sciences.

courses.title: Introduction to Speech Disorders
courses.description: Studies speech-based disorders of communication: phonology, motor speech, resonation, voice, and stuttering.

courses.title: Intro to Audiology and Hearing
courses.description: Introduces the psychophysics of sound and the practice of audiology, as well as the anatomy and physiology of the auditory system. Also presents the common pathologies of the auditory system, the impact of hearing loss, the types and characteristics of hearing loss, the conventional procedures used to assess hearing, the interpretation of audiological test findings, and the criteria for initiating audiological referrals.

courses.title: Audiologic Rehabilitation
courses.description: Overview of aural rehabilitation and methods in auditory training and speech reading with hearing-impaired individuals.

courses.title: Introduction to Language Disorders
courses.description: Studies language-based disorders of communication: specific language impairment in children, traumatic brain injury, aphasia and dementia.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: A project, reading, or research course.

courses.title: Honors in Communication Sciences and Disorders
courses.description: The design,  implementation and reporting of an original research project.

courses.title: Rhetorical Criticism
courses.description: Critical analyses of rhetorical elements and processes in oratorical and non-oratorical forms.

courses.title: Nanotechnology in Food, Agriculture, and Environment
courses.description: Application of nanotechnology in crop production, food processing and preservation, and environmental remediation; behavior of engineered nanoparticles in plant, soil and the environment, and environmental toxicology and regulations of engineered nanoparticles.

courses.title: Agricultural and Environmental Quality
courses.description: Analysis of effects of agriculture on environmental quality; emphasis on agricultural wastes and practices; potential for using agricultural systems for disposal of other wastes; effects of pollution on the agricultural environment.

courses.title: The World of Water
courses.description: The full range of water issues including abundance and quality of water in the environment, water policy and conflict. (P)

courses.title: Land and Life
courses.description: Relationships between human activities and soil and environmental quality. Lectures concentrate on the fundamentals of soil and environmental science using case studies to illustrate basic principles. Intended for non-majors. (B)

courses.title: Introduction to Soils in the Environment
courses.description: Fundamentals of soil science emphasizing the physical, chemical, and biological properties of soils in relation to growth of native and agricultural plants and environmental uses.

courses.title: Introduction to Soils in the Environment Laboratory
courses.description: Hands-on exposure to soils-related properties and processes.

courses.title: Environmental Nutrient Management
courses.description: Consumption, existing reserves, formulation, chemical and physical properties, and manufacture of commercial fertilizers; basic chemical reactions of fertilizer materials with the soil and the fate of the nutritional elements whether it be loss by leaching, plant uptake, fixation or soil retention. (P)

courses.title: Earth System Analysis
courses.description: Analysis of global-scale interdependences between climate, biogeochemical cycles and humans using a systems approach.

courses.title: Urban Soil and Water Systems
courses.description: Issues and opportunities related to soil and water quality in urban systems. Students will learn and discuss consequences of human population growth on soil and water systems in urban areas.

courses.title: Sustainable Agricultural and Urban Land Management
courses.description: Agricultural and urban water quality issues in Florida, their bases, land and nutrient management strategies and the science and policy behind Best Management Practices (BMPs). Students will learn to evaluate BMP research and analyze its role in determining practices and policies that protect water quality.

courses.title: Environmental Biogeochemistry
courses.description: To gain understanding of the earth as a biogeochemistry system in the context of global change.

courses.title: Soil, Water and Land Use
courses.description: Suitabilities and limitations of soils for different uses; using soil surveys and related information to plan use/management of land; behavior of water in soils and landscapes; policies for and implications of water allocation among urban, agricultural and natural resource uses.

courses.title: Soil and Water Conservation
courses.description: Soil and water resources, historical erosions and sediment problems, geologic vs. accelerated erosion, erosion prediction equations and government conservation programs; water conservation, irrigation, drainage and salinity; stormwater management; and case studies in erosion and sedimentation.

courses.title: Wetlands
courses.description: Introduces wetland ecosystems with emphasis on principles and problems associated with their functions and values as related to water quality. Become familiar with basic and applied concepts in hydrology, soils, and vegetation of both constructed and natural wetlands.

courses.title: Water Resource Sustainability
courses.description: Quantitative effects of human impacts on hydrologic ecosystems (aquifers, watersheds, coastal zones, lakes, and wetlands). Case studies illustrate detrimental effects of unsustainable resource utilization and beneficial management strategies.

courses.title: Soil Microbial Ecology
courses.description: Occurrence and activities of soil microorganisms and their influence on soil productivity and environmental quality.

courses.title: Ecology of Waterborne Pathogens
courses.description: Survival strategies, gene regulation and metabolism of waterborne pathogens. Methods for microbe detection and control.

courses.title: Soil and Water Chemistry
courses.description: Physico-chemical processes such as mineral weathering and formation, sorption, and ion exchange. Also includes introduction to diffuse double-layer theory.

courses.title: Aquatic Toxicology: Science and Applications
courses.description: Introduces foundational knowledge and concepts of the field of aquatic toxicology. Examines how environmental and chemical properties influence the fate and bioavailability of contaminants in aquatic environments; introduces principles of toxicology and methods used to study aquatic toxicology, as well as applications of knowledge gained from aquatic toxicology studies.

courses.title: Soils, Water and Public Health
courses.description: Important instances where soil and water science and public health overlap; develop skills required for competency in both disciplines.

courses.title: Soil Physics
courses.description: Physical processes and properties of soils that influence optimum growth of plants as well as potential for groundwater pollution from agrochemicals and applied wastes. Primary emphasis is given to basic concepts of transport and retention for water and solutes; secondary emphasis is given to air and heat in the root zone of the soil profile; and limited attention is given to mechanical properties of soil that affect the proliferation of plant roots. (P)

courses.title: Environmental Pedology
courses.description: Study and analysis of soil in the environment and the factors responsible for soil formation and geographic distribution. Development of hydric soil criteria and hydric soil indicators. Emphasis on morphology or hydric/ non-hydric soils and introduction to diagnostic horizons and soil classification. Course also includes abs on soil field techniques.

courses.title: GIS in Soil and Water Science
courses.description: Basic, practical understanding of GIS concepts, technical issues, and applications to soil and water science using ArcGIS geographic information system.

courses.title: Environmental Soil and Water Monitoring Techniques
courses.description: Introduces the principles, objectives, and practices in environmental monitoring. Learn the proper techniques in planning for monitoring projects, sampling design, sample collection, basic principles of laboratory analysis, and basic data analysis. Also introduces and emphasizes quality assurance and quality control requirements.

courses.title: Supervised Extension Experience in Soil and Water Sciences
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: Selected topics for qualified students.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Soil and Water Science
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Soil and Water Science
courses.description: Independent research in soil and water science leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Special Topics in Soil and Water Science
courses.description: Variable topics designed to meet students' needs and interests.

courses.title: Full-time Practical Work Experience in Soil and Water Science
courses.description: Practical work must be a new experience and related to field of study.

courses.title: Beginning Modern Hebrew 1
courses.description: Beginning Hebrew covers four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing. For those with no prior exposure to the language.

courses.title: Beginning Modern Hebrew 2
courses.description: Continues beginning Hebrew, covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.title: Intermediate Modern Hebrew 1
courses.description: Intermediate Hebrew study covers four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with new vocabulary and grammar.

courses.title: Intermediate Modern Hebrew 2
courses.description: Continues intermediate Hebrew covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.title: Advanced Modern Hebrew 1
courses.description: Advanced study of the four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with attention to more complex structures. (H and N)

courses.title: Advanced Modern Hebrew 2
courses.description: Continues advanced Hebrew study of the four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing with attention to more complex structures. (H and N)

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: Individual work on an approved topic.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for in-depth study of special topics in Israeli literature, history, or culture.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Introduction to Israeli Culture
courses.description: Presentation and analysis of some key facets of Israeli culture. Topics include Jewish vs. Zionist (and Israeli non-Jewish) identities, Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Israeli-American relations, gender, and function of art in Israeli society.

courses.title: Identity and Dissent in the Hebrew Short Story
courses.description: Traces the tension between the individual and the collective in Zionist/Israeli society over the last 100-plus years as illustrated in Hebrew short fiction.

courses.title: Israeli History and the Contemporary Novel
courses.description: Studies Israeli history through the lens of the contemporary novel.

courses.title: Readings in Modern Hebrew Literature 1
courses.description: Readings in modern Hebrew novels, short fiction and poetry. While the study of literature is emphasized, some language work is presented to help with reading comprehension. Texts and instruction are in Hebrew.

courses.title: Readings in Modern Hebrew Literature 2
courses.description: Readings in modern Hebrew texts, including recently published stories and poems. Class is instructed in Hebrew.

courses.title: Democracy in Theory and Action
courses.description: The birth and evolution of democracy and its revival—democracy in theory and action. The lively dialogue between ancient democracy and modern through a comparative analysis, tackling some of the most pressing issues, such as limits of political participation and free speech, the role of the press/media, and elitism in politics.

courses.title: Gardens to Read and Visit
courses.description: Investigation of gardens as cultural artifacts in literature and art to discover the extent to which gardens are sites of comfort as well as contest, through analysis of the tension between the experience (“to visit”) and the representations (“to read”) of gardens in written and visual forms.

courses.title: Medicine, Science, and the Dawn of Reason
courses.description: This interdisciplinary course invites students to examine the passage of humanity into the era of Reason and the Development of Medical Science and Ethics. As part of the “Nature and Culture” theme, it presents a historical narrative on the passage of humanity from superstition to the era of scientific inquiry

courses.title: Magic and the Supernatural: From Greece and Rome to the Present
courses.description: Explores beliefs in magic and the supernatural and how they are shaping our culture, values and legal system. Considers how reason, belief, faith and the supernatural interact with each other our life experiences.

courses.title: The Glory That Was Greece
courses.description: A broad cultural view of the classical Greek world. Greek sources are read in translation. (H and N)

courses.title: The Grandeur That Was Rome
courses.description: Provides a multi-faceted introduction to the culture of Rome. Primary source material is read in translation. (H and N)

courses.title: Classical Antiquity and Sustainability
courses.description: Examines classical antiquity, applying methods and theories of sustainability to explore the impact of the ancient Greeks and Romans on their environment and focusing on the distribution of wealth, social stratification, land use and classical representations of the natural world. (H)

courses.title: Athens in Topography and Monuments
courses.description: Explores the topography and monuments of ancient Athens to understand social, historical, economic, and religious institutions.

courses.title: Greece Today and Yesterday
courses.description: Interdisciplinary examination of various aspects of ancient and modern Greek life and culture.

courses.title: Rome of Augustus
courses.description: Studies the political, social, and cultural developments of Rome during the age of Augustus.

courses.title: Pompeii: An Archaeological Laboratory
courses.description: Studies the material remains of a Roman town through an examination of the excavated finds: architecture, wall-paintings, and inscriptions.

courses.title: Ancient Egypt
courses.description: Studies the civilization, culture, and monuments of ancient Egypt from prehistoric times to the New Kingdom and Late period.

courses.title: Introduction to Hieroglyphics
courses.description: A beginner's course in Egyptian hieroglyphics of the Middle Kingdom. Also designed for students with no former instruction in ancient languages.

courses.title: The Athenian Democracy
courses.description: Studies ancient Athens from c.650-322 BCE, with attention to the political, social, and cultural institutions of the democracy, drawing on primary sources and modern theory to explain democratic changes from the archaic to the classical period.

courses.title: Classical Greece
courses.description: Studies the social, political, and cultural developments of classical Greece from the Persian Wars to the death of Alexander (500-322 BCE).

courses.title: Sport and Recreation in the Ancient World
courses.description: Examines literary and archaeological sources to determine the social, economic, political and cultural importance of games in the ancient Mediterranean world from the time of Homer to the fall of the Roman Empire.

courses.title: Gender and Sexuality in Classical Antiquity
courses.description: Explores perceptions of the masculine and feminine in Ancient Greece and Rome, discussing these stereotypes in their political, social, economic, and cultural contexts.

courses.title: Slavery in the Ancient World
courses.description: Examination of slavery in the ancient Greek and Roman world from the late Bronze Age to the end of the Roman empire.

courses.title: Classical Archaeology
courses.description: Illustrated lectures on archaeology, its process of discovery, and methods. History of major archaeological exploration in Mediterranean lands compared with extant literary information.

courses.title: The Ancient City: Greek Cities
courses.description: Covers the development of the cities of classical Greece from Minoan centers through Byzantium. All aspects of city life: design, building techniques, culture, and ideas.

courses.title: The Ancient City: Roman Cities
courses.description: Studies the cities of the Roman Empire from the founding of Rome to the establishment of Constantinople as the Eastern capital. Emphasizes life in imperial Rome and in European and North African cities.

courses.title: AI in Antiquity and Today
courses.description: Examines AI’s origins in ancient Greece and compares it to AI’s acceptance and use in modern society. Pairs discussion of Greek and Roman philosophical and other literary texts on the soul and identity and the boundaries between the natural and artificial with emerging societal issues related to AI, including gender, racism, and slavery.

courses.title: Crime and Punishment in Ancient Athens
courses.description: Examines how the Athenians defined, regulated, and suppressed crime and what the political discourse on crime reveals about Classical Athens.

courses.title: Special Topics in Classical Civilization
courses.description: Examines various aspects of Greek and Roman culture based on the ancient sources, literary, and archaeological.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: Reading, conference and reports. All work in will be in translation.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Classical Civilization
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Classical Civilization. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Classical Civilization.

courses.title: Classics Capstone Seminar
courses.description: Introduces scholarly literature on a significant topic in classics. Students will write a research paper showing proper use of primary and secondary sources on the topic.

courses.title: Overseas Studies 1
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: English Vocabulary from Greek and Latin
courses.description: Historical study of the origins, development, and lexicography of English vocabulary with emphasis on elements derived from Greek and Latin.

courses.title: Survey of Roman Literature
courses.description: Critical study of the development of Roman literature. Includes readings from Plautus, Cicero, Catullus, Vergil, Ovid, and Tacitus. Read in translation.

courses.title: Greek Drama
courses.description: Classical Greek theater: archaeological remains of important theaters and selected plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides, Aristophanes, and Menander. Read in translation.

courses.title: Ancient Greek and Roman Epic
courses.description: Examines the origin and development of the ancient Greek and Roman epic traditions in the political and social context of the Mediterranean region and Near East from the first millennium BCE through the first century CE.

courses.title: Myths of the Greeks and Romans
courses.description: Development, importance, and influence of Graeco-Roman mythology. The main Greek and Latin literary sources are read in translation.

courses.title: Religions of the Graeco-Roman World
courses.description: Development, importance, and influence of Greek and Roman religion and cult practice. The main literary and epigraphical sources are read in translation.

courses.title: Classics and Science Fiction
courses.description: Studies science fiction's origins in Greek and Roman texts to investigate the influence of Greco-Roman literature on modern works of science fiction.

courses.title: Ancient World in Film
courses.description: Examines film and television characterizations of the ancient world and how these accord with known facts through historical and archaeological evidence. Viewing of selected movies along with background readings, lectures, and discussion.

courses.title: Legendary Rome
courses.description: Myths and history associated with Rome's early foundation stories and examination of works of literature about Rome's foundation in their political, social, and cultural contexts.

courses.title: Special Topics in Classical Literature
courses.description: Examines various aspects of Greek and Roman literature with focus on special genres (e.g., historiography), periods (e.g., the age of Augustus), or subjects (e.g., slavery).

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: Reading, conference and reports. All works are read in translation.

courses.title: Greece in the European Context in the 20th Century
courses.description: Overview of Greek politics, society, and culture in the 20th century.

courses.title: The Literature of Byzantium
courses.description: Overview of major genres of Byzantine literature (Patristic literature, oratory, historiography, chronicle, hagiography, hymnography, epic poetry) from the years CE 330-1453.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Modern Greek Language and Literature
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Beginning Ancient Greek 1
courses.description: The basics of ancient Greek grammar, morphology, syntax and vocabulary.

courses.title: Beginning Ancient Greek 2
courses.description: The basics of ancient Greek grammar, morphology, syntax and translation, with special attention to irregular verbs.

courses.title: Accelerated Beginning Ancient Greek 1
courses.description: This course and its sequel, GRE 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.title: Accelerated Beginning Ancient Greek 2
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.title: Beginning Modern Greek 1
courses.description: This course and its sequel, GRK 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.title: Beginning Modern Greek 2
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.title: Intermediate Modern Greek 1
courses.description: Readings in modern Greek literature, history and culture. (H and N)

courses.title: Intermediate Modern Greek 2
courses.description: Additional readings in modern Greek literature, history and culture. (H and N)

courses.title: Modern Greek Literature Since 1830
courses.description: Advanced study of representative modern Greek prose, poetry and drama in the original from independence (1830) to the present. The course combines the study of the modern Greek language with readings, analysis and discussion of major literary works.

courses.title: Individual Work in Modern Greek
courses.description: For advanced students who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Greek faculty.

courses.title: Intermediate Greek Prose
courses.description: Readings selected from Attic Greek prose authors designed to aid students in the transition from grammar to connected prose passages.

courses.title: New Testament Greek
courses.description: Reviews grammar and forms. Readings from several books of the New Testament. (H and N)

courses.title: Survey of Greek Literature 2
courses.description: Studies representative texts from various periods of Greek literature.

courses.title: Greek Drama
courses.description: Selected plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles or Euripides.

courses.title: Plato
courses.description: Studies Plato's Meno and Apology.

courses.title: Greek Lyric Poetry
courses.description: Translation and analysis of Greek lyric poetry, from Archilochus to Bacchylides.

courses.title: Homer and Greek Epic
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections from Homer's Iliad and Odyssey.

courses.title: Greek Historians
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections of Herodotus, Thucydides, Xenophon, and Plutarch.

courses.title: Greek Orators
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections from Lysias, Demosthenes and Isocrates. (H and N)

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: Reading, conference and reports.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Greek Language and Literature
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Studies in Greek Literature
courses.description: Advanced study of a particular author, genre, period or subject.

courses.title: Beginning Latin 2
courses.description: The second part of the sequence for those with little or no background in Latin.

courses.title: Beginning Latin 3
courses.description: The third part of the sequence for students with little background in high-school Latin.

courses.title: Beginning Latin 1
courses.description: The first of a 3-semester sequence for students with little or no background in Latin. Others enrolling in the course will be required to take it for an S/U grade.

courses.title: Accelerated Beginning Latin 1
courses.description: This course and its sequel, LAT 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language. Students are expected students to have little or no background in Latin. Others enrolling in the course will be required to take it for an S/U grade.

courses.title: Accelerated Beginning Latin 2
courses.description: Continuation of the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

courses.title: Introduction to Literature
courses.description: In this course, students will be assigned readings representative of a broad range of literary genres and cultures. These readings will cover a variety of literary movements and historical eras. The readings will include selections from the Western canon. Written analysis of literary works may be required. Students will be provided with opportunities to practice critical interpretation.

courses.title: Introduction to Vergil
courses.description: Readings in Vergil's Eclogues, Georgics and/or the Aeneid, with emphasis on introducing Vergilian style, diction poetic techniques and basic genre differences. Review of Latin grammar and syntax. (H)

courses.title: Readings in Latin Literature
courses.description: Examines various aspects of Roman life through readings in Latin literature (with a focus on either special subjects, authors, genres or periods) and a review of Latin grammar.

courses.title: Latin Love Poetry
courses.description: Translation and interpretation of selected poems of Catullus and a thorough review of Latin grammar.

courses.title: The Ancient Novel
courses.description: Readings from Petronius, Apuleius or the Historia Apollonii Regis Tyri.

courses.title: Roman Drama
courses.description: Translation and analysis of the comedies of Plautus and Terence or the tragedies of Seneca.

courses.title: Roman Elegy and Lyric
courses.description: Selected poems of Catullus, Horace, Tibullus, Propertius or Ovid. (H and N)

courses.title: Roman Satire
courses.description: Translation and analysis of the Roman satirists Horace, Persius, Juvenal, or Martial.

courses.title: The Roman Historians
courses.description: Readings in Latin from one of the Roman historians: Sallust, Caesar, Livy, or Tacitus.

courses.title: Medieval Latin
courses.description: Readings from Medieval Latin 350 - 1200 A.D. (H and N)

courses.title: Cicero
courses.description: Essays, speeches and letters of Cicero. (H and N)

courses.title: Vergil and Roman Epic
courses.description: Translation and analysis of selections from Vergil's Aeneid in the light of his epic techniques and the spirit of the Augustan Age.

courses.title: Studies in Latin Literature
courses.description: A rotating topics course providing in-depth study of a particular author (e.g., Suetonius), genre (e.g., didactic poetry) or period (e.g., The Silver Age).

courses.title: Special Study in Latin
courses.description: Readings, conferences and reports.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Latin Language and Literature
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Discovering the Universe
courses.description: This course provides a comprehensive look at modern astronomy, emphasizing the use of the scientific method and the application of physical laws to understand the universe including earth and its environment. Throughout this course, students will develop the ability to discern scientific knowledge from non-scientific information by using critical thinking.

courses.title: Astronomy Laboratory
courses.description: Introduces experimental work in astronomy including scheduled laboratory exercises during the day in the teaching lab and evening observational astronomy at the on campus teaching observatory. (P)

courses.title: Cosmology
courses.description: Overview of cosmology, the study of the large-scale structure and history of the universe, in four components: ideas about the universe as a whole predating the twentieth century; ideas from twentieth century physics that impact modern cosmology; stars, black holes, galaxies and quasars as probes of the universe; and the Hot Big Bang Model.

courses.title: Introduction to the Solar System
courses.description: Survey of the solar system including the sun, planets, satellites, asteroids, meteorites and comets. (P)

courses.title: Life in the Universe
courses.description: The origin of life on Earth and the possibility of life elsewhere. A multidisciplinary approach is followed. Conditions for life to form and the likelihood that such conditions may exist elsewhere in the universe are discussed. Also considered are schemes proposed for the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI). (P)

courses.title: Introduction to Python for Physical Sciences
courses.description: Learn syntax, capabilities, and foundations of Python and basic numerical methods to address physical problems with a computational approach. Covers basics of dataset manipulation, algorithm development, and plotting.

courses.title: Astronomy and Astrophysics 1
courses.description: First part of a two part sequence. Survey of astronomy and astrophysics for physical science, engineering, or mathematics majors. Covers gravitation, orbits and tides; the Moon's phases and eclipses; light and spectra; the solar system; and a few historical milestones. (P)

courses.title: Astronomy and Astrophysics 2
courses.description: Second part of a two part sequence. Survey of astronomy and astrophysics for physical science, engineering or mathematics majors. Covers compact objects; the Solar System; exoplanets; the Milky Way and galaxies; cosmology and relativity.

courses.title: History of Astronomy through Newton
courses.description: Astronomy from its beginnings through Newton. Emphasizes the works of Ptolemy, Copernicus, Kepler, Galileo, and Newton.

courses.title: Techniques of Observational Astronomy 1
courses.description: First part of the AST 3722C-4723C sequence. The fundamental principles and techniques used in planning, making, reducing and analyzing modern astronomical observations. Includes classroom lectures and discussion, indoor laboratory work, data analysis and outdoor night observations. Introduces numerical treatment of observations, CCD imaging, digital imaging processing and astronomical spectroscopy.

courses.title: Essentials of Astrophysics
courses.description: Foundation and background on topics in astrophysics, including broadening mechanisms of spectral lines, equations of state of gases, thermodynamics, radiation sources, radiative transport, kinetic theory of gases and stellar structure.

courses.title: Galactic Astronomy
courses.description: Intensive introduction to the fundamental properties of the Milky Way and its system of satellite galaxies. Course is intended for astronomy majors and natural science students. Topics include the ages, chemical abundances and kinematics of field stars and star clusters, the properties of the interstellar medium and its role in star formation, the dark matter content and models of the Milky Way's physical structure.

courses.title: Galaxies and Cosmology
courses.description: An investigation into the properties of galaxies and their distribution in space. Some cosmological implications of this distribution are discussed. Intended for astronomy majors and advanced students of other mathematical sciences.

courses.title: Techniques of Observational Astronomy 2
courses.description: Second part of a sequence. The fundamental principles and techniques used in planning, making, reducing, and analyzing modern astronomical observations. Includes classroom lectures and discussion, indoor laboratory work, data analysis, and outdoor night observations. Introduces numerical treatment of observations, CCD imaging, digital imaging processing, and astronomical spectroscopy.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: Assigned reading or research for qualified undergraduates.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Astronomy
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Astronomy. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Astronomy.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Lecture, seminar or laboratory sessions covering selected topics of current interest in astronomy.

courses.title: Advanced Computational Techniques
courses.description: Advanced Computational Techniques in Astronomy and Physics. Advanced techniques in computational methods in the natural sciences and numerical analysis. Includes version controlling and programming in distributed environments; grid construction and convergence techniques; numerical differentiation; linear algebra; root finding; differential equations; Monte Carlo simulations; open source project development.

courses.title: Introduction to Real Analysis 1
courses.description: Theory of real numbers, functions of one variable, sequences, limits, continuity and differentiation; continuity and differentiability of functions of several variables. Those who plan to do graduate work in mathematics should take MAA 4211. Credit will be given for, at most, one of MAA 4102, MAA 4211, or MAA 5104.

courses.title: Introduction to Real Analysis 2
courses.description: Continues the advanced calculus for engineers and physical scientists sequence. Theory of integration, transcendental functions and infinite series. MAA 4102 is not recommended for those who plan to do graduate work in mathematics; these students should take MAA 4212. Credit will be given for, at most, one of MAA 4103, MAA 4212 and MAA 5105.

courses.title: Real Analysis and Advanced Calculus 1
courses.description: Advanced treatment of limits, differentiation, integration and series. Includes calculus of functions of several variables. Credit will be given for, at most, one of MAA 4211, MAA 4102 and MAA 5104.

courses.title: Real Analysis and Advanced Calculus 2
courses.description: Continues the advanced calculus sequence in limits, differentiation, integration and series. Credit will be given for, at most, one of MAA 4212, MAA 4103 and MAA 5105.

courses.title: Introduction to Modern Analysis 1
courses.description: Topology of metric spaces, numerical sequences and series, continuity, differentiation, the Riemann-Stieltjes integral, sequences and series of functions, the Stone-Weierstrass theorem, functions of several variables, Stokes' theorem and the Lebesgue theory. Credit will be given for, at most, MAA 4226 or MAA 5228.

courses.title: Introduction to Modern Analysis 2
courses.description: Continues the modern analysis sequence discussing the topology of metric spaces, numerical sequences and series, continuity, differentiation, the Riemann-Stieltjes integral, sequences and series of functions, the Stone-Weierstrass theorem, functions of several variables, Stokes' theorem and the Lebesgue theory. Credit will be given for, at most, MAA 4227 or MAA 5229.

courses.title: Functions of a Complex Variable
courses.description: Complex numbers, analytic functions, Cauchy-Riemann equations, harmonic functions, elementary functions, integration, Cauchy-Goursat theorem, Cauchy integral formula, infinite series, residues and poles, conformal mapping. Credit will be given for, at most, MAA 4402 or MAA 5404.

courses.title: Basic College Algebra
courses.description: In this course, students will develop problem solving skills, critical thinking, computational proficiency, and contextual fluency through the study of equations, functions, and their graphs. Emphasis will be placed on quadratic, exponential, and logarithmic functions. Topics will include solving equations and inequalities, definition and properties of a function, domain and range, transformations of graphs, operations on functions, composite and inverse functions, basic polynomial and rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, and applications.

courses.title: Trigonometry
courses.description: Exponential and logarithmic functions, trigonometry and analytic and additional applications of trigonometry. (M)

courses.title: Precalculus Algebra
courses.description: College algebra, functions, coordinate geometry, exponential and logarithmic functions. (M)

courses.title: Precalculus Algebra and Trigonometry
courses.description: College algebra, functions, coordinate geometry, exponential and logarithmic functions, and trigonometry. Fast-paced review of algebra and trigonometry to prepare for calculus. Assumes prior knowledge of intermediate algebra (Algebra 2) and trigonometry. (M)

courses.title: Survey of Calculus 1
courses.description: Geometric and heuristic approach to calculus; differentiation and integration of simple algebraic and exponential functions; applications to graphing, marginal analysis, optimization, areas and volumes. (M)

courses.title: Survey of Calculus 2
courses.description: Sequences, geometric and Taylor series; systems of linear equations, Gaussian elimination, matrices, determinants and vectors; partial differentiation, multiple integrals; applications to marginal analysis, least-squares and Lagrange multipliers. (M)

courses.title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 1
courses.description: In this course, students will develop problem solving skills, critical thinking, computational proficiency, and contextual fluency through the study of limits, derivatives, and definite and indefinite integrals of functions of one variable, including algebraic, exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions, and applications. Topics will include limits, continuity, differentiation and rates of change, optimization, curve sketching, and introduction to integration and area.

courses.title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2
courses.description: Techniques of integration; applications of integration; differentiation and integration of inverse trigonometric, exponential and logarithmic functions; sequences and series. (M) Credit will be given for, at most, one of MAC 2312, MAC 2512 and MAC 3473.

courses.title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 3
courses.description: Solid analytic geometry, vectors, partial derivatives and multiple integrals. (M) Credit will be given for, at most, MAC 2313 or MAC 3474.

courses.title: Honors Calculus 1
courses.description: Topics covered in the MAC 3472/MAC 3473/MAC 3474 sequence closely parallel those covered in MAC 2311/MAC 2312/MAC 2313, but are treated in greater depth. Credit will be given for, at most, MAC 2311 or MAC 3472.

courses.title: Honors Calculus 2
courses.description: Continues the honors calculus sequence. Credit will be given for, at most, one of MAC 2312, MAC 2512 and MAC 3473.

courses.title: Honors Calculus 3
courses.description: Continues the honors calculus sequence.  Credit will be given for, at most, MAC 2313 or MAC 3474.

courses.title: Intro to Computational Math
courses.description: Introduces mathematical computation and the Python programming language. Emphasizes using mathematical algorithms to solve problems in analysis, number theory, combinatorics, algebra, linear algebra, numerical analysis, and probability.

courses.title: Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Logic, sets, functions; algorithms and complexity; integers and algorithms; mathematical reasoning and induction; counting principles; permutations and combinations; discrete probability. Advanced counting techniques and inclusion-exclusion.

courses.title: Introduction to Combinatorics 1
courses.description: Permutations and combinations, binomial coefficients, inclusion-exclusion, recurrence relations, Fibonacci sequences, generating functions and graph theory.

courses.title: Introduction to Combinatorics 2
courses.description: Matching theory, block designs, finite projective planes and error-correcting codes. Does not require MAD 4203.

courses.title: Graph Theory
courses.description: Theory and applications of graphs including connectivity, planarity, coloration, algorithms, and network flow.

courses.title: Introduction to Numerical Analysis
courses.description: Numerical integration, nonlinear equations, linear and nonlinear systems of equations, differential equations and interpolation.

courses.title: Elementary Differential Equations
courses.description: First-order ordinary differential equations, theory of linear ordinary differential equations, solution of linear ordinary differential equations with constant coefficients, the Laplace transform and its application to solving linear ordinary differential equations. (M)

courses.title: Probability Theory and Stochastic Processes 2
courses.description: Random walks and Poisson processes, martingales, Markov chains, Brownian motion, stochastic integrals and Ito's formula.

courses.title: Differential Equations for Engineers and Physical Scientists
courses.description: The second course in differential equations. Topics include systems of linear differential equations, stability theory and phase plane analysis, power series solutions of differential equations, Sturm-Liouville boundary-value problems and special functions. Credit will be given for, at most, MAP 4305 or MAP 5304.

courses.title: Elements of Partial Differential Equations
courses.description: Introduces second-order linear partial differential equations (heat, wave and Laplace equations), separation of variables in PDEs, Sturm-Liouville eigenvalue problems, method of eigenfunction expansions (Fourier analysis) and Green's functions. Possible introduction to first-order PDEs and the method of characteristics. Credit will be given for, at most, MAP 4341 or MAP 5345.

courses.title: Fourier Analysis
courses.description: Introduces linear systems and transforms; Laplace, Fourier and Z transforms and their mutual relationship; convolutions. Operational calculus; computational methods including the fast Fourier transform; second-order stationary processes and their autocorrelation functions; and problems of interpolation, extrapolation, filtering and smoothing of second-order stationary processes.

courses.title: Modeling in Mathematical Biology
courses.description: Mathematical models of biological systems. Topics include models of growth, predator-prey populations, competition, the chemostat, epidemics, excitable systems and analytical tools such as linearization, phase-plane analysis, Poincaré–Bendixson theory, Lyapunov functions and bifurcation analysis.

courses.title: Computational Linear Algebra
courses.description: Linear equations, matrices and determinants. Vector spaces and linear transformations. Inner products and eigenvalues. Emphasizes computational aspects of linear algebra.

courses.title: Linear Algebra 1
courses.description: Linear equations, matrices, vector spaces, linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues and inner-product spaces. Includes both theory and computational skills. Develops the ability to reason through, and coherently write, proofs of theorems. For math majors, this course serves as a transition from a study of techniques into more conceptual math; for engineering and science majors, it serves also as a coherent foundation in linear algebra.

courses.title: Linear Algebra for Data Science
courses.description: A second course in linear algebra, focusing on topics that are the most essential for data science. Introduces theory and numerical methods required for large data-sets and machine learning. Topics include LU, QR, and singular-value decompositions; conditioning and stability; the DFT and filters; deep learning; fully connected and convolutional nets.

courses.title: Introduction to Number Theory
courses.description: Introduces elementary number theory and its applications to computer science and cryptology. Divisibility, primes, Euclidean Algorithm, congruences, Chinese Remainder Theorem, Euler-Fermat Theorem and primitive roots. Selected applications to decimal fractions, continued fractions, computer file storage and hashing functions, and public-key cryptography.

courses.title: Abstract Algebra 1
courses.description: Sets and mappings, groups and subgroups, homomorphisms and isomorphisms, permutations, rings and domains, arithmetic properties of domains, and fields. Requires facility in writing proofs.

courses.title: Abstract Algebra 2
courses.description: A second course in Abstract Algebra, focusing on Galois Theory, the algebraic theory of fields and polynomial equations. Introduces concepts of abstract algebra used in settling famous historical problems including the problems of angle trisection and duplication of cubes by ruler and compass constructions, and the insolubility of polynomial equations of the fifth degree by radicals.

courses.title: Functions and Modeling
courses.description: Group activities strengthen knowledge of secondary mathematics, especially topics from precalculus and the transition to calculus, including contexts that can be modeled using linear, exponential, polynomial or trigonometric functions. Topics include conic sections, parametric equations and polar equations. Explorations involve multiple representations, transformations and data analysis techniques, and are facilitated by various technologies.

courses.title: Individual Work
