courses.description: Special topics not obtainable in regular course offerings.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Mathematics
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in mathematics. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics in Mathematics
courses.description: Qualified undergraduates take part in seminars or classes on special topics.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Mathematics for Liberal Arts Majors 1
courses.description: For non-science and non-business majors. Includes an introduction to set theory, logic, number theory, probability, statistics, graphing, and linear programming.

courses.title: Mathematics for Liberal Arts Majors 2
courses.description: Demonstrates the beauty and utility of mathematics through topics which include financial management, linear and exponential growth, mathematics in the arts, and discrete mathematics. Does not require MGF 1106.

courses.title: Mathematical Thinking
courses.description: In this course, students will utilize multiple means of problem solving through student-centered mathematical exploration. The course is designed to teach students to think more effectively and increase their problem-solving ability through practical application and divergent thinking. This course is appropriate for students in a wide range of disciplines/programs.

courses.title: Sets and Logic
courses.description: Examples of sets, operations on sets, set algebra, Venn diagrams, truth tables, tautologies, applications to mathematical arguments, and mathematical induction. Can also be very useful for prospective and in-service secondary and middle school teachers. Taking one, but not both, of MAS 3300 or MHF 3202 is required of mathematics majors.

courses.title: Elements of Set Theory
courses.description: Basic axioms and concepts of set theory. Students present proofs. Credit will be given for, at most, MHF 4102 or MHF 5107.

courses.title: Foundations of Mathematics
courses.description: Models and proofs. Foundations of real and natural numbers, algorithms, Turing machines, undecidability and independence. Examples and applications in algebra, analysis, geometry and topology. Credit will be given for, at most, MHF 4203 or MHF 5207.

courses.title: Geometry
courses.description: Axiomatic treatment of topics in Euclidean, non-Euclidean, projective geometry and (time permitting) fractal geometry. Particularly useful for prospective secondary-school mathematics teachers.

courses.title: Elements of Topology 1
courses.description: Basic concepts of general topology. Credit will be given for, at most, MTG 4302 or MTG 5316.

courses.title: Elements of Topology 2
courses.description: Continues the basic concepts of general topology. Credit will be given for, at most, MTG 4303 or MTG 5317.

courses.title: Wildlife Issues in a Changing World
courses.description: The biological and ecological basis of wildlife issues and the pathways humans use to resolve these issues. Topics include major animal phyla; evolutionary history of vertebrates; state, federal and international agencies that manage wildlife worldwide; and the impact of human activities on wildlife. (B)

courses.title: The Future of Tropical Rain Forests
courses.description: This course investigates the essential question “What is the Future of Tropical Rain Forests?” Students will investigate fundamental issues addressed by scientists studying rain forests, including what gave rise to their biodiversity, the drivers and consequences of deforestation, cultural stereotypes, and if conservation is compatible with socioeconomic development.

courses.title: Biodiversity Conservation: Global Perspectives
courses.description: The relationship between humans and the global biotic environment that supports them. This course explores human patterns of resource use and population biology that determine the status of the earth's biodiversity resources. Helps students understand how today's human society affects global life support systems, and how individuals can make lifetime contributions to environmental solutions. (B and N)

courses.title: Wildlife Colloquium
courses.description: Wildlife ecology and conservation as a major and career.

courses.title: Wildlife Ecology and Management
courses.description: Wildlife as a natural resource with emphasis on principles of conservation, ecology and management.

courses.title: Wildlife of Florida
courses.description: Diversity of wildlife species in Florida with emphasis on amphibians, reptiles, mammals, and birds.

courses.title: Wildlife of Florida Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory exploring the diversity of wildlife in Florida's ecosystems with emphasis on field identification, natural history, and ecology of birds, mammals, amphibians, and reptiles.

courses.title: Natural Resource Ecology
courses.description: Application of ecological principles and natural history information to conserve and sustainably manage natural resources with an emphasis on animals and plants.

courses.title: The Ecology of Climate Change
courses.description: Provide a broad overview of the ecological responses to climate change on the Earth. Students will learn about ecological processes, spanning genetics, physiology and behavior, morphology, phenology and distribution, and up through species interaction, communities and ecosystems and how climate change impacts them.

courses.title: Tropical Wildlife
courses.description: An interdisciplinary course that teaches the ecology of animals and the socio-economics of wildlife use. The first part of the course deals with the biology of tropical wildlife and the second with the historical, economic and political aspects of the use and management of tropical wildlife.

courses.title: Introduction to Conservation Genetics
courses.description: Types of molecular polymorphisms found in nature, including how genetic information is organized, what evolutionary and demographic forces act to shape genetic polymorphisms, and how and why genetics are useful in population conservation and management.

courses.title: Landscape Ecology and Conservation
courses.description: Central constructs and methods of landscape ecology are applied to wildlife ecology and conservation.

courses.title: Large Mammal Ecology and Management
courses.description: Large mammals are fascinating creatures that interact with the coupled human and natural systems that they occupy in complex ways. Abiotic and biotic conditions as well as human impacts drive their dynamics, while they in turn play significant roles in shaping the diverse landscapes they inhabit. Take a critical approach to examining current advances and controversies involving large mammals.

courses.title: Wildlife Habitat Management
courses.description: Application of land management practices and their effects on wildlife habitats in Florida.

courses.title: Wetland Management
courses.description: Prepare students for basic monitoring, field research, and management of wetlands, using ecological principles and knowledge of community variation in relation to stressors. Identification, monitoring techniques, and management and restoration techniques will be taught through a combination of class lectures and hands-on field exercises and labs.

courses.title: Wetland Wildlife Ecology
courses.description: Ecological principles of conservation and management of wildlife in wetland environments, including a survey of the structure and function of major wetland types.

courses.title: Ecology of Bird Introductions and Invasions
courses.description: Ecology and conservation implications of introductions and invasions of birds. The course covers the invasion pathway model as well as the four levels of factors that can influence introduction outcomes.

courses.title: Introduction to Wildlife Population Ecology
courses.description: The dynamics and regulation of biological populations and life-history theory.

courses.title: Human Dimensions of Natural Resource Conservation
courses.description: Local and international models are used to provide an interdisciplinary overview of the theory and practice of conservation education, environmental communication and integrated resource management and conservation.

courses.title: Avian Field Techniques
courses.description: Intensive advanced field experience in scientific study design and ecology of wild bird populations and communities.

courses.title: Diverse Perspectives in Conservation
courses.description: As the population of the United States becomes increasingly diverse, the integration and participation of diverse communities is essential with respect to successful management and conservation of wildlife and natural resources. Examines current and historical factors that influence the interaction of marginalized communities such as indigenous and communities of color with the natural environment, including natural resource management decision-making structures.

courses.title: Conservation Biology
courses.description: Overview of the major problems in conservation and of the biological principles and theories to preserve this diversity.

courses.title: Wildlife Behavior and Conservation
courses.description: Concise, current, and thorough grounding to the field (theory, practice, and relevance) of animal behavior, with a strong focus on applications of wildlife behavior to achieve successful wildlife conservation gains.

courses.title: Quantitative Wildlife Ecology
courses.description: Concepts and applications of quantitative techniques in ecology and wildlife management.

courses.title: Supervised Extension Experience in Wildlife Ecology and Conservation
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.title: Individual Problems
courses.description: Individual study of a selected topic related to wildlife ecology and conservation as contracted with the instructor at the start of the term.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Wildlife Ecology and Conservation
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Wildlife Ecology and Conservation
courses.description: Independent research in wildlife ecology and conservation leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Topics in Wildlife Ecology and Conservation
courses.description: Variable current issues and in-depth study in wildlife, forestry, range, recreation, and fisheries issues not covered in other courses.

courses.title: Internship in Wildlife Ecology and Conservation
courses.description: Practical teaching, research, and extension experience in the field of wildlife ecology and conservation. Offered every semester.

courses.title: Wildlife Techniques
courses.description: Evaluate the theories, strengths, and weaknesses behind the use of standard wildlife techniques by researchers and managers. Major topics covered include study design, radio telemetry, passive monitoring techniques, animal capture and handling, sexing and aging wildlife, population estimation, and habitat selection.

courses.title: Field Wildlife Techniques
courses.description: Students will examine and apply the wildlife techniques used by managers and researchers when working with wildlife. Major topics covered in the course include: animal capture and handling, sexing and aging wildlife, radio telemetry, population estimation methods, passive monitoring techniques, quantifying vegetation, and habitat usage.

courses.title: Environment, Food and Society
courses.description: Global issues and trends in population growth, natural resource (soil, water, and plant genetic biodiversity) utilization, climate change, and potential impacts of current trends on agriculture, natural resources, global food security, and sustainability.

courses.title: Nanotechnology in Food, Agriculture, and Environment
courses.description: Application of nanotechnology in crop production, food processing and preservation, and environmental remediation; behavior of engineered nanoparticles in plant, soil and the environment, and environmental toxicology and regulations of engineered nanoparticles.

courses.title: Challenge 2050: Global Uncertainty
courses.description: Explores questions in human well-being and sustainability building a foundation for addressing global challenges associated with global population. Transdisciplinary experts lead diverse and innovative discussions, complex adaptive problem solving; and the integration of economic, environmental, food, health, and social system perspectives.

courses.title: Agricultural Honors
courses.description: Various courses offered. (WR)

courses.title: Urban Agriculture
courses.description: Work with faculty and guest field experts to explore the concepts, issues, and opportunities for urban agricultural sustainability, and on the development and implementation of demonstrations of community urban agricultural projects. Culminates in a group presentation for campus and community stakeholders.

courses.title: Home and Community Gardening: Collegiate Master Gardener
courses.description: The Florida Master Gardener Program trains UF/IFAS Extension volunteers to provide horticultural education to residents and communities. Receive training to become a Master Gardener and learn horticulture, Integrated Pest Management, plant pathology, and garden planning. This online course is composed of digital lectures, discussions, and hands-on activities.

courses.title: Agricultural and Environmental Quality
courses.description: Analysis of effects of agriculture on environmental quality; emphasis on agricultural wastes and practices; potential for using agricultural systems for disposal of other wastes; effects of pollution on the agricultural environment.

courses.title: Agricultural Ecology
courses.description: Introduces the study of ecology from an agricultural perspective. Emphasizes ecological principles with examples and applications from agriculture.

courses.title: AI in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Artificial intelligence (AI) is used to solve problems in research and industry. This course provides students with understanding of and practical hands-on experience building and using AI systems. Students will obtain the skills and knowledge they need to use AI to solve real-world problems in agricultural and life sciences.

courses.title: Challenge 2050: Developing Tools for Changing the World
courses.description: The global population is projected to exceed 9 billion by the year 2050. Challenge 2050 requires innovative development of transdisciplinary solutions to complex, global issues. This course explores individual and team-based skills, competencies, and dispositions necessary to addressing the complex adaptive issues surrounding the challenge.

courses.title: Honors Orientation
courses.description: Introduces the CALS honors program and develop the skills needed to complete a creative, scholarly project and an honors thesis. A variety of guest speakers, in-class and outside activities, discussion, writing and oral presentation are used to accomplish the learning objectives.

courses.title: Challenge 2050: the Experience
courses.description: Emphasizes trust building, accompaniment, and community development experiences within developing global contexts. Uses immersion experience to gain an understanding for concerns relating to population fluctuation, including issues related to economics, environment, food, health, and social systems. International immersion facilitates applying sustainable practices in developing areas.

courses.title: Exotic Species and Biosecurity Issues
courses.description: Studies US policies and programs affecting agricultural biosecurity as applied to current agricultural and extension and regulatory programs. Emphasizes policies and procedures used to detect and report non-indigenous species. Develop the analytical capabilities to assess the consequences of agricultural biosecurity threats.

courses.title: Consequences of Biological Invasions
courses.description: Non-native species invasions and environmental effects of these invaders. Students will develop analytical capabilities to assess the consequences of biological invasions.

courses.title: Challenges in Plant Resource Protection
courses.description: Applied training in the regulatory aspects of plant protection, using real-world case studies, scenarios and issues.

courses.title: Controlled Environment Plant Production
courses.description: Foundational information on the principles of controlled environment plant production, including the interactions between plants and their microenvironments, climate control technologies and strategies, and economic principles and analysis methods.

courses.title: International Studies
courses.description: Supervised study abroad.

courses.title: Challenge 2050: Creating Solutions
courses.description: Through this capstone experience course, students demonstrate and apply knowledge, skills, and dispositions in assigned transdisciplinary teams. Students complete a comprehensive proposal for a developmental initiative focused on addressing the 2050 Challenge of sustaining a global population.

courses.title: Supervised Extension Experience in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.title: Individual Study in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Individual study in agricultural and life sciences.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in agricultural and life sciences under faculty supervision. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Project Team Research: Building Skills in Agrobiology
courses.description: Hands-on experience in addressing a real-world problem faced by an agricultural industry partner. Production of a detailed plan, project design, and preliminary data for evaluating and solving the problem. Offered every term.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Independent research in agricultural and life sciences leading to an honors thesis. Student are mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Variable subjects provide content for the study of agricultural topics not offered in other courses.

courses.title: CALS Leadership Institute Seminar 1
courses.description: Discussion-based seminar provides an introduction to leadership studies and personal leadership development. Exploration of personal leadership characteristics through various assessments and the development of a personal leadership development plan.

courses.title: CALS Leadership Institute Seminar 2
courses.description: Discussion-based seminar provides an introduction to group and organizational leadership in local and global contexts. Personal assessment of strengths and further application of developed personal leadership plan to a global vision are included.

courses.title: CALS Leadership Institute International Service and Learning Experience
courses.description: This seminar focuses on an international service and learning experience as a context for application of course content previously covered in the program. A compilation of documentation supporting leadership growth and reflection serve as closure to leadership institute.

courses.title: Full-time Practical Work Experience in Agriculture
courses.description: Variable subjects provide content for the study of agricultural topics not offered in other courses.

courses.title: Challenge 2050: Taking Action
courses.description: Through supervised practical training, in conjunction with academic assignments at professional organizations, the Taking Action internship provides the opportunity to professionally examine and engage the global challenges associated with Challenge 2050.

courses.title: Computer Engineering Design 1
courses.description: Reinforce basic computer engineering skills; design, produce, and report on a computer engineering project, meeting defined specifications and using a structured design methodology and project management.

courses.title: Computer Engineering Design 2
courses.description: Second course in computer engineering design sequence; students will complete a technical design, testing regimen, product, and technical report as part of a computer engineering capstone project. The project will meet defined specifications and will be completed using a structured design methodology and project management techniques.

courses.title: Electronic Circuits 1
courses.description: Fundamentals of electronic circuits and systems. Laboratory.

courses.title: Solid-State Electronic Devices
courses.description: Introduces the principles of semiconductor electron device operation. Laboratory.

courses.title: Introduction to Machine Learning
courses.description: Covers introductory topics in pattern recognition and machine learning and use of these methods towards a variety of real world applications. The focus of this course is to be introduced to basic machine learning concepts and how to use associated state-of-the-art machine learning tools.

courses.title: Introduction to Biophotonics
courses.description: Introduces the principles of optics, lasers and biology, the interaction of light with cells and tissues, and various optical imaging, sensing and activation techniques and their applications in biomedicine.

courses.title: Resonant MEMS
courses.description: Fundamentals of resonant micro-electro-mechanical systems (resonant MEMS) and their applications.

courses.title: Bioelectrical Systems
courses.description: Covers the theoretical and quantitative perspective of bioelectrical signals reflecting the activity of the brain, the muscles, and the heart. Examines bases of modeling, measuring, processing and analyzing bioelectrical signals and systems, as well as common clinical applications. Laboratory.

courses.title: Electronic Circuits 2
courses.description: Design-oriented continuation of EEE 3308C; feedback, op amp circuits and applications, digital electronics.

courses.title: VLSI Circuits and Technology 1
courses.description: Introduction to VLSI circuit technology and manufacturing. Fabrication, device models, layout, parasitics, and simple gate circuits.

courses.title: Future of Microelectronics Technology
courses.description: Surveys state-of-the-art microelectronics technology and prospects for future technologies. Topics include nanoscale MOSFETs, strained Si, high-k gate dielectrics, carbon nanotubes, molecular electronics and single-electron devices.

courses.title: Microelectronic Fabrication Technologies
courses.description: Principles of microelectronic device fabrication. Emphasis on the fundamentals of microfabrication processing and microelectronic device process flows.

courses.title: Radio Frequency Integrated Circuits 1
courses.description: Fundamental RF theory (such as resonant circuits, matching, noise and transmission lines), radio operation and design of key RF circuit blocks (such as amplifiers, mixers, and oscillators).

courses.title: Introduction to RF Circuits
courses.description: Introduction to radio frequency (RF) fundamentals and related circuits with topics of impedance matching, Smith Chart, s-parameters, waveguides, resonators, filters, active devices, and amplifiers.

courses.title: Mixed Signal IC Testing I
courses.description: Fundamentals of testing IC devices and systems: test specifications, parametric training, measurement accuracy, test hardware, sampling theory, digital signal processing based testing, and calibrations. Circuit analysis and design with analog and mixed-signal systems. Labs on testing passive components, LDOs, Op-amps, DACS/ADCs, Mixed-Signal ICs LabVIEW and the National Instruments Savage Tester.

courses.title: Modern Memory Device Technologies
courses.description: State-of-the-art volatile and nonvolatile memory device technologies and their limitations. Emerging memory device technologies, including those that could be adopted by industry in the next decades due to their potential performance, density, power and cost advantages.

courses.title: Introduction to Nanodevices
courses.description: Physical principles of modern solid-state devices and their applications, quantum mechanics and fundamentals of nanoelectronics.

courses.title: Introduction to Quantum Computing
courses.description: Introduces quantum computing concepts and hardware implementations in a self-contained manner and discusses fundamentals of quantum mechanics. Also introduces important concepts of superposition and entanglement, hardware realization of quantum computing technologies, and quantum computing algorithms.

courses.title: Real Time Digital Signal Processing Applications
courses.description: Real world digital signal processing (DSP) tasks are presented and solved in a lab environment that utilizes a Floating Point DSP and a development simulation and hardware emulation tool. Laboratory.

courses.title: Automated Hardware/Software Verification
courses.description: Develop modeling, formal specification, and automated verification skills for analyzing complex hardware and/Or software systems. Hands-on experience with model checking tools.

courses.title: Introduction to Hardware Security and Trust
courses.description: Fundamentals of hardware security and trust for integrated circuits. Cryptographic hardware, invasive and non-invasive attacks, side-channel attacks, physically unclonable functions (PUFs), true random number generation (TRNG), watermarking of Intellectual Property (IP) blocks, FPGA security, counterfeit detection, hardware Trojan detection, and prevention in IP cores and integrated circuits.

courses.title: Acoustics
courses.description: Governing equations for wave theory of sound; Character of plane acoustic waves and 3-D acoustic fields; Sound transmission/reflection at an interface between two media; Waves transmission/attenuation inducts; Low frequency approximations (lumped-element modeling) and transducers; sources of sound.

courses.title: Physical Attacks and Inspection of Electronics
courses.description: Focuses on the physical inspections, physical attacks, reverse engineering, counterfeit detection, etc. of electronics from the device to system level using advanced microscopy, failure analysis techniques combined with image analysis and machine learning. In additions, students will also learn about the associated countermeasures.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Machine Learning
courses.description: Overview of machine intelligence and the role of machine learning in a variety of real-world problems. Probability and statistics to handle uncertain data. Topics covered include: learning models from data in both a supervised and unsupervised fashion, linear models and non- linear models for classification, and linear dimensionality reduction.

courses.title: Neural Signals, Systems, and Technology
courses.description: Biophysical principles of neural signaling; characterization of neural circuits and systems; technology design principles for interfacing with biological neural systems; overview of clinical and consumer applications for neurotechnology and artificial intelligence.

courses.title: Introduction to Electrical Engineering
courses.description: Introduces the profession of electrical engineering. Presents career development and enhancement, professional codes of conduct, ethics, entrepreneurship, intellectual property, professional societies. Projects provide hands-on experience with soldering, MATLAB programming, and microcontrollers.

courses.title: Physics of Electrical Engineering
courses.description: Introduces the fundamental physics underlying components and devices and their application to electronics, power, and wireless.

courses.title: Circuits 1
courses.description: Basic analysis of DC and AC electric circuits. Laboratory.

courses.title: Circuits 2
courses.description: Continuous-time signals and linear systems: Fourier series and transforms, frequency, response, Laplace transform and system function, analog filters; emphasis on electrical circuits. Sampling.

courses.title: Introduction to Signals and Systems
courses.description: Continuous-time and discrete-time signal analysis including Fourier series and discrete-time and discrete Fourier transforms; sampling; discrete-time linear system analysis with emphasis on FIR and IIR systems: impulse response, frequency response, and system function; MATLAB-based programming for Signals and Systems.

courses.title: Basic Electric Energy Engineering
courses.description: Analysis and modeling of power system components. Magnetic circuits, energy conservation, transformers, and AC and DC rotating machines. Laboratory.

courses.title: Remote Sensing in Engineering: Science, Sensors and Applications
courses.description: Remote sensing theory, systems and applications using information obtained from the visible/near infrared, thermal infrared and microwave regions of the EM spectrum.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Electromagnetic Fields
courses.description: Transmission lines, vector analysis, electrostatics, magnetostatics, time-varying fields, plane waves.

courses.title: Digital Logic and Computer Systems
courses.description: Overview of logic design, algorithms, computer organization and assembly language programming and computer engineering technology. Laboratory.

courses.title: Programming for Electrical Engineering 1
courses.description: Develops computer skills and the art of writing sound computer programs using examples and exercises relevant to electrical and computer engineering.

courses.title: Data Science for ECE
courses.description: Analysis, processing, simulation, and reasoning of data. Includes data conditioning and plotting, linear algebra, statistical methods, probability, simulation, and experimental design.

courses.title: Electrical Engineering Design 1
courses.description: Teams design, produce, and report on a hardware prototype, meeting defined specifications and using a structured design methodology. Includes project management, hardware prototyping, and project reporting.

courses.title: Power Electronic Circuits
courses.description: Circuit topologies, analysis, design and simulation of electronic circuits such as power supplies, and motor drives.

courses.title: Fundamentals of RF and Power Electronic Devices
courses.description: Introduces important semiconductor device technologies for high speed electronics, power electronics, and energy harvesting applications.

courses.title: Power System Analysis
courses.description: Development of power system equivalents by phase network analysis, load flow, symmetrical components, sequence networks, and fault analysis.

courses.title: Power System Protection
courses.description: Power systems protection analytical methodologies and algorithms. Analyzes different methods for equipment and systems protection and discusses wide-area monitoring techniques, which allow real-time operation and control. Introduces cyber-physical security approaches for the smart grid and realizes numerical construction of protection methods considering realistic engineering hypothesis.

courses.title: Smart Grid for Sustainable Energy
courses.description: Survey of power grid operations and markets for students with interest in power systems and/or sustainable energy. Characteristics of traditional and new energy resources; how resources impact the grid; control on many time-scales; how the power grid and power markets of tomorrow will differ from those of today.

courses.title: Computational Photography
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational photography, sensing, imaging and illumination.

courses.title: Applied Magnetics and Magnetic Materials
courses.description: Introduces magnetism, magnetic materials, and magnetic devices; offers a balance of theory and application from an applied engineering perspective.

courses.title: RF/Microwave Passive Circuits
courses.description: Radio frequency (RF)/microwave passive components and circuits such as transmission lines, waveguides, couplers, filters, and resonators.

courses.title: Optical Communication Systems
courses.description: Introduces electromagnetic waves, dielectric waveguides and fibers, propagation characteristics of fibers, characterization methods, LEDs and laser diodes, photodetector optical receivers and communication systems.

courses.title: Laser Theory and Design
courses.description: Studies the field of semiconductor optoelectronics and the physics of optoelectronic devices including the interaction of photons with electrons and holes in a semiconductor leading to the realization of optoelectronic devices such as photon amplifiers, LEDs, diode lasers, electro-absorption modulators, and detectors, including their design and application-specific characteristics.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Photonics
courses.description: Reviews electromagnetic fields and waves, energy bands in semiconductors, p-n junctions and optical properties of semiconductors. Fundamentals of optical modulators and waveguides and photonic applications.

courses.title: Antenna Systems
courses.description: Electromagnetic field theory and its application to antenna design.

courses.title: Electromagnetic Fields and Applications
courses.description: Rigorously develops the properties of electric and magnetic fields. Maxwell’s Equations form the foundation for understanding the fundamental nature and application-driven aspect of static and dynamic fields and their derivation from scalar and vector potentials. Fields in media is examined along with energy considerations and propagation effects.

courses.title: Lightning
courses.description: Introduces lightning discharge processes. Electromagnetics relevant to lightning measurements. Applications for determining lightning charge, current, location and characteristics. Lightning protection.

courses.title: Communication Systems and Components
courses.description: Theory of communication and applications to radio, television, telephone, satellite, cellular telephone, spread spectrum and computer communication systems. Laboratory.

courses.title: Noise in Devices and Communication Systems
courses.description: Origin, characterization and measurement of random noise. Calculation of signal-to-noise ratios and probability of errors in communication systems.

courses.title: Audio Engineering
courses.description: Introduces audio and sound engineering that includes the underlying theory of acoustics, electronics and signal processing; demonstrates modern audio engineering practice as applied to music, home audio, recording and sound reinforcement.

courses.title: Introduction to Radar
courses.description: Basic principles of cw and pulsed radar; angle, range, and Doppler tracking; accuracy and resolution; signal design.

courses.title: Computer Communications
courses.description: Introduces the principles and practice of computer networking, emphasizing data communication, and the lower layers of the OSI and TCP/IP protocol architectures.

courses.title: Wireless and Mobile Networks
courses.description: Senior-level study of wireless and mobile networks. Investigates telecommunication architectures and protocols for wireless sensor networks and wireless embedded systems; Wi-Fi and wireless local area networks; mobile ad-hoc networks; next generation cellular systems and satellite networks.

courses.title: State Variable Methods in Linear Systems
courses.description: Development of state-variable approach to linear continuous-time and discrete-time systems with emphasis on the design of feedback control systems.

courses.title: Control of Biological Systems
courses.description: The automatic control principles that govern critical processes in human biology are explored. Through the development of mathematical models of biological systems, the course creates an understanding of metabolic, immunologic, and genetic processes. Applications include the manufacture of vaccines, monoclonal antibodies, cancer treatments, insulin, and many others.

courses.title: Linear Control Systems
courses.description: Theory and design of linear control systems.  Laboratory.

courses.title: Intelligent Machines Design Laboratory
courses.description: Design simulation, fabrication, assembly and testing of intelligent robotic machines. Laboratory.

courses.title: Digital Design
courses.description: Advanced modular logic design, design languages, finite state machines and binary logic. Laboratory.

courses.title: Digital Computer Architecture
courses.description: The use of electronic digital modules to design computers. Includes the organization and operation of computers, hardware/software trade-offs and design of computer interfacing. Laboratory.

courses.title: Reconfigurable Computing
courses.description: Fundamental concepts at advanced undergraduate level in reconfigurable computing based upon advanced technologies in field-programmable logic devices. Topics include general concepts, device architectures, design tools, metrics and kernels, system architectures and application case studies.

courses.title: Advanced Systems Programming
courses.description: Develop a deep understanding of operating system concepts and systems programming fundamentals and gain hands-on experience in systems programming by using Pthreads as well as implementing Linux device drivers and testing/verifying systems code for deadlock and race-freedom.

courses.title: Principles of Computer System Design
courses.description: Broadly introduces the main principles and abstractions for engineering hardware and software systems. Includes in-depth studies of their use on computer systems across a variety of designs, be it an operating system, a client/server application, a database server or a fault-tolerant disk cluster.

courses.title: Microprocessor Applications
courses.description: Experience in the elements of microprocessor-based systems, hardware interfacing and software design for their application. Laboratory.

courses.title: Microprocessor Applications 2
courses.description: Implementation of a Real-Time Operating System on an ARM Cortex M processor to create more robust and complex microprocessor applications. Introduction to IoT applications.

courses.title: Foundations of Digital Signal Processing
courses.description: Analysis and design of digital filters for discrete signal processing, spectral analysis and fast Fourier transform.

courses.title: Programming for Electrical Engineering 2
courses.description: Fundamentals of data structures and algorithms, including lists, queues, stacks, divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, trees, tables, graphs and recursive techniques. The role of specific data structures in electrical engineering applications.

courses.title: Cross Layered System Security
courses.description: Develop an understanding of the principles of computer security, as it crosses layers of abstraction (application, operating system, hardware, and network). Learn the challenges of building secure computer systems with examples and hands-on assignments. Current research on these challenges will be discussed. Students will review and present conference papers.

courses.title: Individual Problems in Electrical Engineering
courses.description: Selected problems or projects in the student's major field of engineering study.

courses.title: Integrated Product and Process Design 1
courses.description: First part of two in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic products and processes, on time and within budget. Working closely with industry liaison engineers and a faculty coach, students gain practical experience in teamwork and communication, problem solving and engineering design, and develop leadership, management and people skills.

courses.title: Integrated Product and Process Design 2
courses.description: Second part of two in which multidisciplinary teams of engineering and business students partner with industry sponsors to design and build authentic products and processes, on time and within budget. Working closely with industry liaison engineers and a faculty coach, students gain practical experience in teamwork and communication, problem solving and engineering design, and develop leadership, management and people skills.

courses.title: Electrical Engineering Design 2
courses.description: Selected design projects involving engineering applications in the various areas of electrical engineering.  Laboratory.

courses.title: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering
courses.description: Special courses covering selected topics in electrical engineering.

courses.title: Practical Work in Electrical and Computer Engineering
courses.description: One term industrial employment, including extra work according to a pre-approved outline. Practical engineering work under industrial supervision, as set forth in the Herbert Wertheim College of Engineering regulations.

courses.title: Co-op Work Experience
courses.description: Practical co-op engineering work under approved industrial supervision.

courses.title: Special Topics in Freshman Engineering
courses.description: Laboratory, lectures or conferences cover selected topics in engineering.

courses.title: Engineering Directed Independent Research
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research with a faculty advisor or postdoctoral or graduate student mentor. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Beginning Haitian Creole 1
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: HAI 1130 and its sequel, HAI 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of conversational skills and grammar essentials in the language.

courses.title: Beginning Haitian Creole 2
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: Second part of the basic Haitian Creole sequence for development of conversational skills and grammar essentials in the language.

courses.title: Intermediate Haitian Creole 1
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: Concentrates on conversation and readings and provides an introduction to Haitian culture through music and film.

courses.title: Intermediate Haitian Creole 2
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: Continued concentration on conversation with added emphasis on reading and perspectives on issues related to the Haitian way of living.

courses.title: Topics in Haitian Language and Culture
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: Variable topics in Haitian language, culture, and society.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Haitian faculty.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Haitian Creole
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in language, linguistics, literature, culture in Haitian Creole. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Haitian Culture and Literature in Translation
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: Examines representations of Haiti and its culture through Haitian literature, art, film, and music.

courses.title: Haitian Culture and Society
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: Addresses central aspects of history, politics, environment, and development, including attention to gender relations, medicine, education, work, race, and class. No knowledge of Haitian Creole is required.

courses.title: Introduction to Haitian Creole Linguistics
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: Examines the major sub-fields of linguistics by means of the Haitian Creole language. Introduces Haitian Creole syntax, morphology, phonology, semantics, and lexicon, as well as sociolinguistics, dialectology, language planning, bilingualism, and language contact.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in English, Haitian Creole or French
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application in some combination of English, Haitian Creole or French.

courses.title: Jamaican Creole, Reggae, and Rastafari
courses.department: Haitian Creole | Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
courses.description: Studies Jamaican Creole, reggae music, and Rastafari religion and culture; introduces the language, music, and religion of the Caribbean island. Methodology includes linguistics, ethnomusicology, and religious studies to read Jamaican Creole, interpret reggae songs, and analyze the Rastafari culture to which they link.

courses.title: Plants, Plagues and People
courses.description: Biology and history of the human species for non-science majors. A chronological presentation from the origin of life to the present with emphasis on the impact that plants, animals and diseases have had and are having on human civilizations. (B or H)

courses.title: Fungus among Us: Mushrooms, Molds and Civilization
courses.description: Role of fungi in human affairs, including their historical use as food or medicine or in religious activities. Also includes their current impact on society as pathogens of plants and animals, in the deterioration of food and fabric and in the synthesis of important drugs. (B)

courses.title: What Are Plants Talking About?
courses.description: Emerging pathogens and pests threaten our plants. Are plants crying for help and we can’t hear? Do plants talk? Remember? Feel? These and other intriguing and scientifically pressing questions will be addressed in this multi-disciplinary course and addresses topics about plant physiology, plant pathology, entomology, and microbiology.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Plant Pathology
courses.description: Principles and practices of plant pathology. (B)

courses.title: Survey of Plant Pathogens
courses.description: Introduces the main groups of pathogens that cause plant disease, how they spread and affect plants and how they are identified and managed. Also includes specific examples of how plant pathogens have changed the course of human history and culture.

courses.title: Applied Plant Disease Management
courses.description: Summarizes the methods and strategies used to manage plant disease by targeting vulnerable points in the pathogen life cycle and disease epidemic. Utilize knowledge of organismal biology, epidemiology, management chemistry, and economics to develop strategies for managing plant diseases.

courses.title: Introduction to Plant Virology
courses.description: Introduces plant virology by covering the principles of plant virology, symptomatology, virus groups, structure, function, spread, detection and control.

courses.title: Introduction to Plant Bacteriology
courses.description: Discusses the main characteristics and properties of bacteria that cause disease in plants with emphasis on problems unique to plant pathology. Offered every other year.

courses.title: Introduction to Plant Pathogenic Fungi
courses.description: Introduces the groups of fungi that cause disease in plants, including morphology, taxonomy, physiology, genetics and control of these fungi.

courses.title: Basic Fungal Biology
courses.description: Introduces the groups of fungi and fungi-like organisms. Discusses the structure, development, physiology, genetics, ecology and systematics of fungi.

courses.title: Supervised Extension Experience in Plant Pathology
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural and life sciences under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.title: Problems in Intermediate Plant Pathology
courses.description: Individual study and research in areas of special interest to undergraduates whose major field is plant pathology.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Plant Pathology
courses.description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Plant Pathology
courses.description: Independent research in plant pathology leading to an honors thesis; mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Seminar in Plant Pathology
courses.description: Discusses current concepts and procedures related to the practice of plant pathology as a profession.

courses.title: Special Topics in Plant Pathology
courses.description: Special topics in plant pathology.

courses.title: Practical Work Experience
courses.description: Practical, hands-on experience in the plant sciences through a paid internship in the industry. This must be a new experience and related to the student's field of study. One month of full-time work is required for each credit.

courses.title: Introduction to Health Professions
courses.description: Lecture, discussion and group assignments provide the opportunity to learn about different disciplines making up a health care team and their role in both the science and practice of health care.

courses.title: Professional Development for the Health Sciences
courses.description: Fosters the professional development needed to transition into the health and public health professions. Enrichment activities include diversity training, presentation skills training, career planning, and developing an online portfolio.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: Supervised program of study to investigate problems significant to health professions.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics in health science. Refer to the department for specific topic information. Can be repeated with change in content for up to 12 credits.

courses.title: Honors Seminar in the Health Professions
courses.description: Philosophy and implementation of scientific work, including an introduction to faculty research. Provides the opportunity to explore and discuss potential honors thesis topics.

courses.title: Public Health and Health Professions Senior Honors Thesis
courses.description: Special project leading to the distinction of magna or summa cum laude at graduation. The project can be any creative work that focuses on a specific topic or issue in the health professions. The student develops an outline of the special project prior to project initiation and produces a final paper at project completion. The paper must be approved by the program and dean's office for the student to graduate magna or summa cum laude.

courses.title: Public Health Concepts
courses.description: Introduces the basic tenets, applications, and foci of public health, including integrating public health with other health professions.

courses.title: Environmental Concepts in Public Health
courses.description: Surveys major environmental health topics by examining sources, routes, media, and health outcomes associated with biological, chemical, and physical agents in the environment. Introduces the economic and legal frameworks associated with environmental health issues and public health.

courses.title: Special Topics in Public Health
courses.description: Exploration of a general or a specific area of public health.

courses.title: The Legal Environment of Business
courses.description: Introduces the legal environment of business and organizations. Emphasizes public and regulatory law and on the social, political and ethical aspects of legal issues in business. Subjects include the nature of law and legal process; administrative law of contracts and torts; business and the constitution; statutory and common law; contracts and torts; business organizations and securities, antitrust, consumer protection and employment law.

courses.title: Ethics in Global Business
courses.description: Explores issues involving the role of individuals, citizens, business, and government in promoting profitable but responsible commerce and socially beneficial business activity. (WR)

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: Requires written report.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Variable content provides an opportunity for study in-depth of topics not offered in other courses and of topics of special current significance.

courses.title: International Studies in Business Law
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Principles of Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Practical, hands-on understanding of the stages of entrepreneurial process. Focus on the decision-making process within a start-up company.

courses.title: Introduction to Social Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Social entrepreneurship involves using the skills and strategies of business to innovatively and sustainably solve social, environmental, and economic problems. The ventures created by social entrepreneurs can be non-profits, for-profits, or innovative hybrid models. This course aims to educate, inspire, and empower students to become changemakers.

courses.title: The Venture Accelerator
courses.description: A team-based, experiential program focused on the start-up process; includes lectures, readings, discussions, workshops, and a team-based project. As deliverables, each team must deliver weekly lessons-learned presentations, complete business canvas updates, and prepare a final presentation.

courses.title: Creativity and Innovation in the Business Environment
courses.description: Examination of the creativity process and the organizational environment of several organizations recognized as creative and innovative. Course is organized around class discussions, workshops, projects, both individual and team-based, cases, a field trip and visiting experts. The course is very interactive and is based in experiential learning.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics in entrepreneurship-related fields of study.

courses.title: Entrepreneurship Practicum
courses.description: Provides a forum for completing a portfolio of supervised experiential learning activities related to entrepreneurship and the entrepreneurial mindset. Through these activities, students enhance their mastery of such entrepreneurial competencies as opportunity recognition, opportunity assessment, resource leveraging, bootstrapping, risk mitigation, value innovation, and guerrilla behavior.

courses.title: Principles of Management
courses.description: Fundamentals of management underlying the solution of problems of organization and operation of business enterprises. (S)

courses.title: Organizations: Structure and Behavior
courses.description: Individual group and organizational issues that affect and shape businesses. Topics include individual differences, motivation, communication, decision making, leadership, power, organizational structure and design and change.

courses.title: Human Resource Management
courses.description: Major human resource management functional areas. Topics include organizational employment planning, employment regulation, job analysis, performance assessment, recruitment and selection, training and development, employee/labor relations and compensation.

courses.title: Strategic Management
courses.description: Evaluation of the key functions of organizations and integration of these functions to achieve competitive advantages. Topics include strategic formulation, implementation and evaluation.

courses.title: Individual Work in Management
courses.description: Written report is required.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Variable content provides an opportunity for study in-depth of topics not offered in other courses and of topics of special current significance.

courses.title: International Studies in Management
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.description: A thesis is required for magna cum laude or summa cum laude designations. To qualify, students normally have completed 90 semester credits of coursework (exceptions may be made) and have at least a 3.6 GPA at the time they enroll. The thesis will be reviewed by at least one faculty member chosen by the honors coordinator from the student's department.

courses.title: Effective Oral Communication
courses.description: Strategies and techniques for effective presentations in the food, agricultural, and natural resource professions. Emphasizes oral and visual techniques for formal and informal situations, including leadership and group settings.

courses.title: Research and Business Writing in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Establishes the importance of effective communication to success in both the educational and professional environments; emphasizes writing as a primary form of communication; examines the elements of effective written communication in organizational and scholarly areas; and explores the causes of ineffective writing and ways to correct them. (WR)

courses.title: Communication and Leadership for Agricultural and Life Sciences Policy Issues
courses.description: Teaches about major policy issues in Agricultural and Life Sciences (ALS) by exposing a variety of methods used to effectively communicate, inform, and influence decisions about these issues. All discussions and activities involve “real world” practices.

courses.title: Issues in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Methods used to effectively communicate, inform, and influence policy decisions about agricultural and life sciences issues.

courses.title: Digital Media Production in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Introduces the history and incorporation of electronic media used in agricultural and natural resources sciences. Emphasizes hands-on learning of electronic media technology as it relates to agriculture.

courses.title: Social Media Strategy and Leadership for Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Learn how, when, and why to use various social media tools. Also learn to measure the effectiveness of these tools in reaching audiences with agricultural and life science messages.

courses.title: Intercultural Communication
courses.description: Basic culturally coded communication behaviors, such as cultural values and beliefs, attitudes and verbal and non-verbal behavior, are examined to identify basic differences among individuals from diverse cultural backgrounds. Special emphasis on cultural communication issues in the agricultural and natural resources sciences are addressed. (S and N OR S and D)

courses.title: Instructional and Event Planning in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Instructional methodology that focuses on the selection and use of innovative teaching, presentation, meeting planning, and evaluation strategies for teaching agricultural subjects in various educational settings.

courses.title: Development and Role of Extension Education
courses.description: Extension philosophy, programs, methods, and leadership principles, and history of federal, state, and local leadership in the development of the cooperative extension service.

courses.title: Moral Leadership in Agriculture and Natural Resources
courses.description: Explores ethical and moral foundations for organizational and personal practice within the context of agriculture, natural resources, and beyond; gain a greater understanding for the intersection between morality and ethics, effective decision-making, and applied organizational ethics.

courses.title: Fostering Innovation through Leadership
courses.description: By studying key leadership theories and models students will develop the basic skills and knowledge necessary to move an innovation from creation to implementation. Using specifically designed experiences, students will be able to think critically about leadership's direct application to innovation and change.

courses.title: Working with People: Interpersonal Leadership Skills
courses.description: Identifies and defines leadership in terms of intrapersonal and interpersonal skills.

courses.title: Leadership Development
courses.description: An understanding of the dynamic interactions of personal characteristics, technical skills, interpersonal influence, commitment, goals, and power necessary for effective organizational leader and follower behaviors.

courses.title: The Communication Process in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Survey of basic communication concepts as they apply to agriculture and natural resource industries.

courses.title: Communication Practices for Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: This course provides students the opportunity to master a variety of writing styles used in corporate and mass media settings. Emphasis is placed on mastery of writing skills. (WR)

courses.title: Advanced Agricultural Communication Production
courses.description: Provides directed experience in the following areas of agricultural communication: video production, graphic design, visual composition, desktop publishing and multimedia development.

courses.title: Communication Campaign Strategies in Agricultural and Life Sciences
courses.description: Examines the role of communication in agriculture, focusing on strategies and methods for agricultural information transfer.

courses.title: Teaching Methods in Agricultural Education
courses.description: Focuses on the selection and use of teaching strategies, methods/ approaches and techniques; evaluating learning; managing learning environments; and classroom management for teaching agricultural subjects in formal educational settings.

courses.title: Curriculum Development and Assessment Techniques in Emerging Agricultural Technologies
courses.description: Introduces new and emerging areas in food agriculture and natural resource sciences. Emphasizes appropriate teaching techniques, curricula, and resources.

courses.title: Special Methods in Teaching Agricultural Education
courses.description: Emphasizes supervised agricultural experience programs, record keeping, and related FFA awards. Classroom management techniques, discipline and liability issues are also discussed.

courses.title: Laboratory Practices in Teaching Agricultural Education
courses.description: Laboratory practices in teaching mechanics and other operative skills, conducting field and laboratory classes and providing space and teaching facilities.

courses.title: Development and Philosophy of Agricultural Education
courses.description: Analyzes evolving concepts and philosophies of agricultural education programs by emphasizing the history, legislation, and principles underlying organization and practice.

courses.title: Leadership for Personal and Organizational Change
courses.description: To prepare students for addressing complex personal and organizational issues related to leading change.

courses.title: Communication and Leadership in Groups and Teams
courses.description: Focuses on leadership and communication in groups and teams. Topics include what makes effective groups and teams, processes of groups and teams, relationships of members, and improving group/team performance.

courses.title: Global Leadership
courses.description: Integrated, practical, and dynamic framework for students to develop global literacy and leadership competencies. (N and S)

courses.title: Program Development and Evaluation
courses.description: In-depth analysis of the development and evaluation of human and community resource programs based on programming theories, concepts, and research. Emphasizes dimensions of responsive communities, determination of community needs, and goals.

courses.title: Curriculum and Program Planning for Agricultural Education
courses.description: Principles and practices used in designing courses of instruction for effective teaching and total program development.

courses.title: Supervised Extension in Agricultural Education and Communication
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic extension experiences in agricultural education and communication under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve program planning, development, implementation, and evaluation.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.description: Topics and special problems selected from fields such as 4-H and FFA work, demonstrations, farm and home management, rural development, pre-school planning and post-school evaluation and planning.

courses.title: Supervised Research in Agricultural Education and Communication
courses.description: Firsthand, authentic research in Agricultural Education and Communication under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research in Agricultural Education and Communication
courses.description: Independent research in Agricultural Education and Communication leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

courses.title: Communication and Leadership Development Capstone Experience
courses.description: Integrates content and skills that communication and leadership development students have learned in their prerequisite courses.

courses.title: Special Topics in Agricultural Education and Communication
courses.description: Special topics in Agricultural Education and Communication.

courses.title: Agricultural Education Internship
courses.description: Practical experience in agricultural training and development through agricultural education organizations, agribusiness and natural resources education, and/or agricultural and outreach programming.

courses.title: Agricultural Education Internship
courses.description: Individual capstone internship within a school-based setting where students observe, participate in, and lead educational instruction, curricula development, assessment of school-based student learning, supervision, and assist in advising a student leadership organization.

courses.title: Leadership Development Internship
courses.description: An individual program whereby students are apprenticed to officials to gain practical experience in agricultural organizations,  industry and/or the county extension program.

courses.title: Cooperative Extension Internship
courses.description: The cooperative extension internship provides students the opportunity to develop practical on-the-job supervised experience in cooperative extension, primarily at the county level.

courses.title: Comm and Lead Dev Internship
courses.description: An individual program whereby students are apprenticed to officials to gain practical experience in agricultural organizations, industry, extension, reporting, writing, editing, photography, graphics, broadcasting, advertising or public relations.

courses.title: Agricultural Communication Internship
courses.description: An individual program whereby students gain supervised experience in agricultural communications including reporting, writing, editing, photography, graphics, broadcasting, advertising or public relations.

courses.title: Challenge 2050: Global Uncertainty
courses.description: Explores questions in human well-being and sustainability building a foundation for addressing global challenges associated with global population. Transdisciplinary experts lead diverse and innovative discussions, complex adaptive problem solving; and the integration of economic, environmental, food, health, and social system perspectives.

courses.title: Challenge 2050: Developing Tools for Changing the World
courses.description: The global population is projected to exceed 9 billion by the year 2050. Challenge 2050 requires innovative development of transdisciplinary solutions to complex, global issues. This course explores individual and team-based skills, competencies, and dispositions necessary to addressing the complex adaptive issues surrounding the challenge.

courses.title: Challenge 2050: the Experience
courses.description: Emphasizes trust building, accompaniment, and community development experiences within developing global contexts. Uses immersion experience to gain an understanding for concerns relating to population fluctuation, including issues related to economics, environment, food, health, and social systems. International immersion facilitates applying sustainable practices in developing areas.

courses.title: Challenge 2050: Creating Solutions
courses.description: Through this capstone experience course, students demonstrate and apply knowledge, skills, and dispositions in assigned transdisciplinary teams. Students complete a comprehensive proposal for a developmental initiative focused on addressing the 2050 Challenge of sustaining a global population.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Variable subjects provide content for the study of agricultural topics not offered in other courses.

courses.title: Challenge 2050: Taking Action
courses.description: Through supervised practical training, in conjunction with academic assignments at professional organizations, the Taking Action internship provides the opportunity to professionally examine and engage the global challenges associated with Challenge 2050.

courses.title: Introduction to Literature
courses.description: In this course, students will be assigned readings representative of a broad range of literary genres and cultures. These readings will cover a variety of literary movements and historical eras. The readings will include selections from the Western canon. Written analysis of literary works may be required. Students will be provided with opportunities to practice critical interpretation.

courses.title: Beginning Portuguese 1
courses.description: First course in the basic Portuguese language sequence, which emphasizes the language as spoken in Brazil. Develops basic communication skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Not open to proficient speakers of Spanish.

courses.title: Beginning Portuguese 2
courses.description: Continuation of the series in basic Portuguese, which emphasizes the language as spoken in Brazil. Develops basic communication skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Not open to proficient speakers of Spanish.

courses.title: Introduction to Portuguese and Brazil: Accelerated
courses.description: Designed for those with knowledge of another Romance language (usually Spanish) through study or home experience. A complete introduction to the language, assuming that students have no previous study of Portuguese. It also satisfies the CLAS and Journalism foreign-language requirement in one semester.

courses.title: Applied Portuguese
courses.description: Portuguese-language reading and discussions to accompany and complement courses of diverse content offered in other departments. Readings and discussions are in Portuguese to develop vocabulary and fluency related to the content of the companion course and to provide an international perspective on the issues of the main course. (N)

courses.title: Oral and Written Practice
courses.description: Intermediate-level course emphasizing all four skills; consists of printed and electronic readings, writing essays and taking notes, oral discussions and presentations, lab activities and grammar review.

courses.title: Composition and Conversation
courses.description: An intermediate-level course with continued expansion of vocabulary, review of essential grammar and structures and development of reading, writing and speaking skills.

courses.title: Introduction to Portuguese Translation and Interpretation
courses.description: Improve Portuguese language skills through application of the principles of translation while gaining information on professional opportunities in the field.

courses.title: Luso-Brazilian Civilization
courses.description: Introduction to the central historical events, political institutions, intellectual currents and artistic movements in the foundation and development of Portugal, Brazil and Lusophone Africa. Preview of topics studied in other literature and culture courses. (H and N)

courses.title: Brazilian Culture
courses.description: Introduction to the study of modern cultural forms, including folk pageantry, performance arts, literature, film and television.

courses.title: Brazil Beyond the Beaches: Tourism and Brazilian Culture
courses.description: Explores the economic and cultural impacts of the multi-billion dollar tourism industry on the cultural products and practices of Brazil.

courses.title: Introduction to Portuguese Linguistics
courses.description: An introduction to the basic concepts and analytical techniques of linguistics, applied specifically to the Portuguese language. Practices the linguistic analysis of the sounds, words and sentences of Portuguese, with relevant comparisons to Spanish and English where applicable.

courses.title: Topics in Brazilian Culture and Civilization
courses.description: Variable topics in Brazilian culture and civilization, including racial identity, feminism, regionalism, music, film, art, religion, sports, and more.

courses.title: Internship in Portuguese
courses.description: This course complements the students' internship with guided reflection. Given the nature of our Portuguese program, students can complete their internship wherever there is interaction with Portuguese speaking communities. This program offers an open alternative so that they can customize their professional interests.

courses.title: Advanced Composition and Syntax
courses.description: A language course that distinguishes Portuguese from related Romance tongues, including the more difficult aspects of grammar and structure, specialized vocabulary, different stylistic registers, and application of these to translation and original composition.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.description: Honors thesis preparation.

courses.title: Overseas Studies
courses.description: Provides a mechanism by which coursework taken as part of an approved study abroad program can be recorded on the UF transcript and counted toward graduation.

courses.title: Monsters of the Portuguese-Speaking World
courses.description: A survey of short narrative works from Portugal, Brazil, Angola and Mozambique with an emphasis on the effects of oppression and colonialism through the figure of the monster and the literary fantastic.

courses.title: Colonial Brazil: Cannibalism, Enslavement and Monarchy
courses.description: Interdisciplinary approach to Brazilian culture 1500-1900 to decolonialize the “myths” of the past and understand the complexities of Brazil’s society through film, art, history, anthropology, and literature.

courses.title: Brazilian Short Story: Conflict and Citizenship
courses.description: Overview of 20th and 21st century short story by contemporary writers, with an emphasis on the social themes of conflict and citizenship.

courses.title: Dystopian Narrative in Brazil
courses.description: Examination of dystopian narrative as a unique vehicle for understanding the cultural and political consequences of modernity and social disparities in Brazil.

courses.title: Contemporary Brazilian Poetry
courses.description: A study of lyric, both literary and musical, in the second half of the 20th century, including experimental trends, political verse, popular music and youth movements.

courses.title: Brazilian Drama
courses.description: A survey of the milestones of Brazilian theatre with an emphasis on 20th century plays. In addition to the plays, the course also presents the theoretical framework and political context of theatrical production in Brazil.

courses.title: The Modernist Movement in Brazilian Literature
courses.description: Readings in fiction, poetry and essay of the nationalist and avant-garde decades of the 1920s and 1930s. Discussions are designed to situate Brazilian letters in diverse national and international contexts. Literary works are complemented by considerations of concurrent production in music and the arts.

courses.title: Becoming Brazil: Nineteenth Century to the Present
courses.description: Surveys nineteenth-century literature and history that examines the cultural figures, institutions and historical moments that have shaped modern Brazil and their continued relevance in contemporary Brazilian society.

courses.title: Contemporary Brazil Narrative
courses.description: Rotating topics may include studies in genre (the short story, the novel), theme (science fiction) or author (Rubem Fonseca, Clarice Lispector, Guimaraes Rosa).

courses.title: Race and Gender in Machado de Assis
courses.description: A survey of the thought of the 19th century master of Brazilian letters Machado de Assis, with an emphasis on the themes of race and gender in his short stories, chronicles and essays.

courses.title: Deep Brazil: Culture of North and Northeast
courses.description: Study of the narrative and culture of the North/Northeast, including the complex histories and political conflicts of these culturally rich regions.

courses.title: Crime Fiction in Brazil
courses.description: Surveys crime fiction and the adaption of the genre to portray Brazilian reality from 1920 to the present.

courses.title: Individual Work
courses.description: Individual work in Portuguese.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Portuguese
